user_requirement: Conduct a supersonic corner flow simulation using dsmcFoam solver for Direct Simulation Monte Carlo (DSMC) analysis. The domain consists of a 3D L-shaped geometry with dimensions 30×18×18 units scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.01, creating an effective domain of 0.3m×0.18m×0.18m, meshed with two hexahedral blocks: a 10×36×36 grid for the initial 5×18×18 section and a 50×36×36 grid for the extended 25×18×18 section. Set boundary conditions with flow patches having zeroGradient for density and momentum fields, fixedValue temperature of 300K at flow boundaries and 1000K at walls, fixedValue velocity of 1936 m/s in x-direction at flow inlet, and noSlip conditions at wall surfaces. Configure entrance1 and entrance2 patches as symmetryPlane boundaries. Initialize the simulation with Argon gas at number density of 1.0e20 particles/m³, temperature of 300K, and inlet velocity of 1936 m/s in x-direction. Use DSMC molecular properties for Argon with mass 66.3e-27 kg, diameter 4.17e-10 m, omega 0.81, and nEquivalentParticles of 1.2e12. Apply VariableHardSphere binary collision model with reference temperature 273K, MaxwellianThermal wall interaction model, and FreeStream inflow boundary model. Run simulation from time 0 to 0.01 seconds with timestep of 1e-6 seconds, outputting results every 1e-3 seconds, and enable field averaging for density, momentum, kinetic energy, internal energy, and heat flux fields.

Perform a Direct Simulation Monte Carlo (DSMC) free space periodic simulation using dsmcFoam solver. The domain is a rectangular box with dimensions 10 x 8 x 8 units scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.01 (making actual dimensions 0.1m x 0.08m x 0.08m), meshed with 20x16x16 cells using simple grading. All boundaries (xPeriodic_half0/1, yPeriodic_half0/1, zPeriodic_half0/1) are set as cyclic boundary conditions to simulate periodic flow in all three directions. Initialize the gas mixture with N2 at number density of 0.777e20 m^-3 and O2 at 0.223e20 m^-3, both at temperature of 300K with initial velocity of (1950, 0, 0) m/s. Use LarsenBorgnakkeVariableHardSphere binary collision model with reference temperature of 273K and relaxation collision number of 5.0, SpecularReflection wall interaction model, and 1e12 equivalent particles per computational particle. Set molecular properties for N2 (mass 46.5e-27 kg, diameter 4.17e-10 m, 2 internal DOF, omega 0.74) and O2 (mass 53.12e-27 kg, diameter 4.07e-10 m, 2 internal DOF, omega 0.77). Run simulation from time 0 to 1e-3 seconds with timestep of 1e-6 seconds, outputting results every 1e-4 seconds with field averaging for density, momentum, kinetic energy, internal energy, and heat flux fields.

Conduct a Direct Simulation Monte Carlo (DSMC) free space stream simulation using dsmcFoam solver. The domain is a rectangular box with dimensions 10 x 8 x 8 units scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.01 (making it 0.1m x 0.08m x 0.08m in actual size), discretized with a 20x16x16 mesh. The simulation models a gas mixture of N2 (77.7%) and O2 (22.3%) with number densities of 0.777e20 and 0.223e20 particles/m³ respectively at 300K temperature. All boundary patches (inlet, outlet, and sides) have fixed boundary velocity of (1325, -352, 823) m/s and fixed temperature of 300K, with zeroGradient conditions for all other field variables. Use Larsen-Borgnakke Variable Hard Sphere binary collision model with reference temperature of 273K and relaxation collision number of 5.0, Maxwell-Boltzmann thermal wall interaction model, and FreeStream inflow boundary model. The simulation runs from 0 to 0.02 seconds with timestep of 1e-6 seconds, outputting results every 1e-3 seconds, using 1e12 equivalent particles per simulated particle with molecular properties: N2 (mass 46.5e-27 kg, diameter 4.17e-10 m, omega 0.74) and O2 (mass 53.12e-27 kg, diameter 4.07e-10 m, omega 0.77).

Conduct a Direct Simulation Monte Carlo (DSMC) hypersonic flow simulation using dsmcFoam solver for a 15-degree wedge obstacle in Mach 5 flow. The domain geometry consists of a 2D wedge configuration with dimensions spanning from x=-0.15242 to x=0.3048 meters, y=0 to y=0.3 meters (first blockMeshDict) or y=0 to y=0.1524 meters (second blockMeshDict), and z=-0.0042 to z=0.0042 meters thickness with convertToMeters factor of 1. Use a structured mesh with 20x40x1 cells for the upstream block and 40x40x1 cells for the downstream block around the wedge. Set boundary conditions with flow patch having zeroGradient for flow properties, obstacle patch as wall type with fixedValue temperature of 550K and noSlip velocity condition, and frontAndBack patches as empty for 2D simulation. Initialize the flow with freestream conditions of N2 (0.777e20 number density) and O2 (0.223e20 number density) at temperature 300K and velocity 1736 m/s in x-direction. Configure DSMC properties with 5e12 equivalent particles, MaxwellianThermal wall interaction model, and LarsenBorgnakkeVariableHardSphere collision model with Tref=273K and relaxation collision number=5.0. Run simulation from startTime 0 to endTime 0.02 seconds with timestep 2e-6 seconds and output writeInterval of 1e-3 seconds, including field averaging and force calculations on the obstacle patch.

Perform a molecular dynamics equilibration simulation using mdEquilibrationFoam solver for a periodic cubic water domain. The domain is a cube with vertices ranging from -1 to 1 in all three directions with a convertToMeters scaling factor of 2.10840e-9, creating a nanoscale simulation box. Use cyclic boundary conditions on all six faces (periodicX_half0/half1, periodicY_half0/half1, periodicZ_half0/half1) to simulate an infinite periodic system. Initialize liquid water with a mass density of 980 kg/m³ at a temperature of 298 K with zero bulk velocity, using a face-centered cubic lattice structure with water and water2 molecules at positions (0,0,0), (0,0.5,0.5), (0.5,0,0.5), and (0.5,0.5,0) with unit cell shape (1,1,1). Apply Lennard-Jones potential for O-O interactions with sigma=3.154e-10 m and epsilon=1.07690722e-21 J, dampedCoulomb electrostatic interactions with alpha=2e9, and restrainedHarmonicSpring tether potential for oxygen atoms with spring constant 0.277 and rR=1.2e-9 m. Use a mesh of 12x12x11 cells with simple grading, run the simulation from time 0 to 5e-12 seconds with a timestep of 1e-15 seconds, output results every 2e-13 seconds, and maintain target equilibration temperature at 298 K.

Perform a molecular dynamics equilibration simulation using mdEquilibrationFoam solver for a periodic cubic domain containing liquid argon. The domain is a cube with dimensions from -1 to 1 in each direction (x, y, z) scaled by a convertToMeters factor of 2.462491658e-9, creating an effective cube size of approximately 4.92 nanometers. Use a 12x12x12 mesh grid with cyclic boundary conditions on all six faces (periodicX_half0/half1, periodicY_half0/half1, periodicZ_half0/half1) to simulate periodic boundaries in all three directions. Initialize the argon liquid with a mass density of 1220 kg/m³, temperature of 300 K, zero bulk velocity, and target equilibration temperature of 300 K. Configure argon molecules with site mass of 6.63352033e-26 kg, zero charge, and Maitland-Smith pair potential with cutoff radius of 1.0e-9 m, minimum radius of 0.15e-9 m, and epsilon value of 1.990108438e-21 J. Set simulation time parameters with start time 0, end time 5e-11 seconds, timestep of 1e-14 seconds, and output interval of 5e-12 seconds for equilibration analysis.

Perform a molecular dynamics simulation of water flow through a nano-scale nozzle using mdFoam solver. The domain consists of three sections (sectionA, sectionB, sectionC) representing a nozzle geometry with water molecules initialized at a mass density of 1004 kg/m³ and temperature of 298 K with zero initial bulk velocity in all sections. Apply no-slip boundary conditions to all walls including sectionAEnd, sectionCEnd, front, back, top, and bottom surfaces. Use a timestep of 1e-15 seconds, run the simulation from time 0 to 2e-13 seconds, and output results every 5e-14 seconds. Configure water molecules with 4 sites (H, H, O, M) where oxygen atoms interact via Lennard-Jones potential with sigma of 3.154e-10 m and epsilon of 1.07690722e-21 J, plus electrostatic interactions using damped Coulomb potential with alpha of 2e9 m⁻¹, both with cutoff radius of 1e-9 m. Set potential energy limit to 1e-18 J and include tethering forces for oxygen atoms using restrained harmonic spring potential with spring constant of 0.277 N/m and reference distance of 1.2e-9 m. Initialize the molecular lattice with unit cell shape (1 1 1) and decompose the domain into 4 subdomains using scotch method for parallel processing.

Conduct a magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) Hartmann flow simulation using mhdFoam solver. The domain is a 2D rectangular channel with dimensions 20 units in length (x-direction) and 2 units in height (y-direction), with a thin depth of 0.1 units in the z-direction making it effectively 2D, using convertToMeters factor of 1. Use a structured mesh with 100x40x1 cells in the x, y, and z directions respectively. Apply boundary conditions with fixed velocity of 1 m/s in x-direction at the inlet, zero gradient velocity at the outlet, no-slip conditions on both upper and lower walls, and empty conditions on front and back faces. Set magnetic field B to uniform (0 20 0) throughout the domain with fixed values on walls and zero gradient at inlet/outlet. Initialize magnetic pressure pB to zero with fixed values at inlet and outlet and zero gradient on walls. Use PISO algorithm with 3 pressure correctors and BPISO with 3 correctors for magnetic field coupling. Set physical properties with density rho=1 kg/m³, kinematic viscosity nu=1 m²/s, magnetic permeability mu=1, and electrical conductivity sigma=1. Run simulation from time 0 to 2 seconds with timestep of 0.005 seconds, outputting results every 100 timesteps.

Perform an electrostatic simulation using electrostaticFoam solver to analyze a charged wire configuration. The domain is a 2D geometry with a central hole representing the charged wire and symmetry boundaries. Boundary conditions specify symmetryPlane conditions for left, right, and down boundaries, fixedValue of 0 V for the upper boundary (phi field), and fixedValue of 45000 V for the hole boundary representing the charged wire. For the charge density field (rho), apply symmetryPlane conditions on left, right, and down boundaries, zeroGradient on the upper boundary, and fixedValue of 3.57e-05 C/m³ on the hole boundary. The simulation runs from time 0 to 0.02 seconds with a timestep of 5e-05 seconds, outputting results every 100 timesteps. Physical properties include vacuum permittivity (epsilon0) of 8.85419e-12 F/m and conductivity (k) of 0.00016 S/m. Use PCG solver with DIC preconditioner for the electric potential field and smoothSolver with symGaussSeidel smoother for the charge density field, both with tolerance of 1e-08 and relative tolerance of 0.2. Apply Euler time discretization scheme and leastSquares gradient scheme with Gauss linear corrected for Laplacian operations.

Perform a Direct Numerical Simulation (DNS) of turbulent flow using dnsFoam solver in a cubic domain with dimensions 1x1x1 units (convertToMeters = 1). The domain uses a uniform 16x16x16 grid with all boundaries set as cyclic (patch0_half0/patch0_half1, patch1_half0/patch1_half1, patch2_half0/patch2_half1) to simulate periodic turbulence in all three directions. Initialize the velocity field as uniform zero and pressure field as uniform zero. Set kinematic viscosity (nu) to 0.025 m²/s with turbulence parameters Ea=10, k0=5, UOsigma=0.090295, UOalpha=0.81532, UOKupper=10, and UOKlower=7. Use PISO algorithm with 2 correctors and 0 non-orthogonal correctors, Euler time scheme for temporal discretization, cubic scheme for convection terms, and linear schemes for gradient and Laplacian terms. Run simulation from time 0 to 10 seconds with timestep of 0.025 seconds, outputting results every 0.25 seconds using PCG solver with DIC preconditioner for pressure and smoothSolver with symGaussSeidel smoother for velocity.

Perform a buoyant natural convection heat transfer simulation using buoyantFoam solver with k-epsilon RAS turbulence model and PIMPLE algorithm. The domain is a 3D rectangular room with dimensions 4m x 3m x 1.6m (length x width x height) using a mesh of 40x20x60 cells with convertToMeters factor of 1. Set inlet boundary conditions with fixed velocity of 0.2 m/s in x-direction at temperature 290K located at coordinates (0, 0.25-0.75, 1.1-1.3), outlet with pressureInletOutletVelocity and zeroGradient temperature at coordinates (1.75-2.25, 3, 0.3-0.5), and walls with noSlip velocity and fixed temperature of 302K. Use Boussinesq approximation with reference density 1 kg/m³, thermal expansion coefficient 3e-03 K⁻¹, reference temperature 300K, dynamic viscosity 1e-05 Pa·s, Prandtl number 0.7, and specific heat 712 J/kg·K. Initialize with uniform pressure 1e5 Pa, internal temperature 302K, turbulent kinetic energy 8e-2 m²/s², and dissipation rate 0.23 m²/s³. Run steady-state simulation for 3000 timesteps with deltaT of 1 second, output results every 100 timesteps, and include comfort analysis with clothing factor 0.5, metabolic rate 1.2, and relative humidity 60%.

Conduct a natural convection heat transfer simulation using buoyantFoam solver with a rectangular cavity geometry of dimensions 76mm x 2180mm x 520mm (convertToMeters factor of 0.001). Use a structured mesh of 35x150x15 cells in x, y, and z directions respectively. Apply noSlip boundary conditions for velocity on all walls (frontAndBack, topAndBottom, hot, cold), with the hot wall using externalCoupledTemperature boundary condition initialized at 307.75K and the cold wall at 288.15K, while topAndBottom walls have zeroGradient temperature conditions. Set initial temperature field to uniform 293K with pressure at 1e5 Pa and gravity acting in negative y-direction at 9.81 m/s². Use air as working fluid with molecular weight 28.96 kg/kmol, specific heat 1004.4 J/kg-K, dynamic viscosity 1.831e-05 Pa-s, and Prandtl number 0.705. Employ kOmegaSST turbulence model with initial turbulent kinetic energy 3.75e-04 m²/s² and specific dissipation rate 0.12 s⁻¹. Run simulation from time 0 to 100 seconds with timestep of 1 second using PIMPLE algorithm with momentum predictor enabled, output results every 10 timesteps, and apply relaxation factors of 0.7 for p_rgh, 0.3 for velocity and enthalpy, and 0.7 for turbulence quantities.

Perform a buoyant natural convection simulation with thermal radiation in an enclosed room using buoyantFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm and k-epsilon turbulence model. The domain contains a room with a heated box inside, where all surfaces (floor, ceiling, fixedWalls, and box) have no-slip velocity boundary conditions. Temperature boundary conditions specify the floor and ceiling at 300K, fixedWalls with zero gradient, and the heated box at 500K. Radiation boundary conditions use MarshakRadiation with emissivity of 1.0 for all surfaces. The pressure field uses fixedFluxPressure boundary conditions on all walls with initial pressure of 1e5 Pa. Use air as the working fluid with molecular weight of 28.9 kg/kmol, constant specific heat of 1000 J/kg-K, dynamic viscosity of 1.8e-05 Pa-s, and Prandtl number of 0.7 modeled as a perfect gas. Include P1 radiation model with constant absorption and emission coefficients of 0.5. Set gravity to -9.81 m/s² in the z-direction. Run the simulation from time 0 to 1000 seconds with a timestep of 1 second using steady-state time derivatives, outputting results every 100 timesteps. Initialize the domain with uniform temperature of 300K, zero velocity, turbulent kinetic energy of 0.1 m²/s², and epsilon of 0.01 m²/s³.

Perform a buoyant natural convection simulation with thermal radiation in an enclosed room using buoyantFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm. The domain represents a 3D room containing a heated box obstacle with floor, ceiling, and fixedWalls boundaries. Set initial temperature to 300K throughout the domain, with boundary conditions specifying fixedValue temperature of 300K at floor and ceiling, zeroGradient temperature at fixedWalls, and a heated box at 500K acting as the heat source. Apply noSlip velocity conditions on all walls (floor, ceiling, fixedWalls, box) with initial velocity field at rest. Use fixedFluxPressure boundary conditions for p_rgh on all boundaries with initial pressure of 1e5 Pa. Implement RAS turbulence modeling with k-epsilon model having initial turbulent kinetic energy of 0.1 m²/s² and dissipation rate of 0.01 m²/s³, using wall functions (kqRWallFunction, epsilonWallFunction, nutkWallFunction) at all walls. Configure fvDOM radiation model with nPhi=3, nTheta=5, tolerance=1e-3, maxIter=10, and constant absorption/emission coefficients of 0.5, applying greyDiffusiveRadiation and MarshakRadiation boundary conditions with emissivity=1.0. Set fluid properties for air with molecular weight 28.9 kg/kmol, specific heat 1000 J/kg·K, dynamic viscosity 1.8e-05 Pa·s, Prandtl number 0.7, using perfectGas equation of state with gravity vector (0,0,-9.81) m/s². Run steady-state simulation from time 0 to 1000 seconds with timestep of 1 second, outputting results every 100 timesteps using PIMPLE solver with residual control tolerances of 1e-2 for p_rgh and 1e-3 for U, h, G, and turbulence variables.

Conduct a buoyant natural convection heat transfer simulation using buoyantFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm and k-epsilon turbulence model. The domain is a 2D rectangular channel with dimensions 10x5x1 units scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.1 (making actual dimensions 1.0x0.5x0.1 meters). Use a structured mesh of 50x40x1 cells. Set boundary conditions as follows: floor and ceiling walls with no-slip velocity, kqRWallFunction for turbulent kinetic energy, epsilonWallFunction for turbulent dissipation, nutkWallFunction for turbulent viscosity, compressible::alphatWallFunction for thermal diffusivity, and zeroGradient for temperature; inlet patch with fixed velocity of 0.1 m/s in x-direction, fixed temperature of 300 K, fixed turbulent kinetic energy of 0.1 m²/s², and fixed epsilon of 0.01 m²/s³; outlet patch with inletOutlet velocity and temperature conditions, and zeroGradient for epsilon; fixedWalls as empty type for 2D simulation. Use air as working fluid with molecular weight 28.96 kg/kmol, constant specific heat 1004.4 J/kg·K, dynamic viscosity 1.831e-05 Pa·s, and Prandtl number 0.705 under perfectGas equation of state. Set gravity acceleration to -9.81 m/s² in y-direction, reference pressure to 1e5 Pa, and initial conditions of uniform velocity 0.1 m/s in x-direction, temperature 300 K, and pressure 1e5 Pa. Run simulation from time 0 to 2500 seconds with timestep of 1 second using steadyState time scheme, and output results every 500 timesteps.

Conduct a buoyant natural convection simulation using buoyantFoam solver with Boussinesq approximation. The domain is a 3D rectangular room with dimensions 10x5x10 units (convertToMeters factor of 1), meshed with 20x10x20 cells using uniform grid spacing. Set initial temperature field to 300K throughout the domain, then use setFields to create a hot source region from (4.5,-1000,4.5) to (5.5,1e-5,5.5) at 600K temperature. Apply no-slip boundary conditions on all walls (floor, ceiling, and fixedWalls), with floor and ceiling having fixed temperature of 300K and fixedWalls having zero gradient temperature boundary condition. Use fixedFluxPressure for p_rgh on all boundaries. Implement RAS turbulence modeling with k-epsilon model, setting initial turbulent kinetic energy to 0.1 m²/s² and dissipation rate to 0.01 m²/s³. Configure PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 2 pressure correctors, momentum predictor enabled, and reference pressure of 0 at cell 0. Set fluid properties for air with molecular weight 28.9 g/mol, reference density 1 kg/m³, thermal expansion coefficient 3e-03 K⁻¹, dynamic viscosity 1e-05 Pa·s, Prandtl number 0.7, and specific heat 712 J/kg·K. Run simulation from time 0 to 2000 seconds with timestep of 2 seconds, outputting results every 100 timesteps, and gravity acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in y-direction.

Conduct a buoyant natural convection heat transfer simulation using buoyantFoam solver with RAS k-epsilon turbulence modeling. The domain is a rectangular enclosure with dimensions 10.06 x 10.0 x 5.0 units (convertToMeters = 1), meshed with 20x20x10 cells using simple grading. The simulation models an igloo-like structure with internal heat sources representing two fridge-freezers. Set initial temperature to 265K throughout the domain with wall boundaries maintained at 265K using fixedValue conditions, while the fridge-freezer surfaces (twoFridgeFreezers_seal_0 and twoFridgeFreezers_herring_1) are heated to 303K. Apply no-slip velocity conditions on all walls with initial zero velocity field. Use symmetry boundary conditions on maxY, minX, maxX, minY, and maxZ faces, with the ground face as a wall. Configure the Boussinesq equation of state with reference density 1 kg/m³, reference temperature 300K, and thermal expansion coefficient 3e-03 K⁻¹. Set fluid properties including dynamic viscosity 1e-05 Pa·s, Prandtl number 0.7, specific heat 712 J/kg·K, and molecular weight 28.9 g/mol. Apply gravitational acceleration -9.81 m/s² in z-direction. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 2 correctors, steady-state time scheme, timestep of 1 second, simulation end time of 4000 seconds, and output results every 100 timesteps. Initialize turbulent kinetic energy at 0.1 m²/s² and dissipation rate at 0.01 m²/s³ with appropriate wall functions.

Perform a buoyant natural convection heat transfer simulation using buoyantFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm and kOmegaSST turbulence model. The domain is a 3D rectangular cavity with dimensions 76mm x 2180mm x 520mm (convertToMeters factor of 0.001). Use a structured mesh of 35x150x15 cells in x, y, and z directions respectively. Apply no-slip boundary conditions for velocity on all walls (frontAndBack, topAndBottom, hot, cold), with the hot wall maintained at fixed temperature of 307.75K and cold wall at 288.15K, while topAndBottom and frontAndBack walls have zero gradient temperature conditions. Set fixedFluxPressure boundary conditions for p_rgh on all walls with initial uniform pressure of 1e5 Pa. Initialize the domain with uniform temperature of 293K, zero velocity, turbulent kinetic energy of 3.75e-04 m²/s², and epsilon of 4e-06 m²/s³. Use air as working fluid with molecular weight 28.96 kg/kmol, specific heat capacity 1004.4 J/kg·K, dynamic viscosity 1.831e-05 Pa·s, and Prandtl number 0.705, modeled as perfect gas. Apply gravity of -9.81 m/s² in y-direction. Run steady-state simulation for 1000 timesteps with deltaT of 1 and output results every 50 timesteps.

Perform a steady-state natural convection heat transfer simulation using buoyantFoam solver with Boussinesq approximation for a 3D rectangular room geometry with dimensions 10×5×10 units (convertToMeters factor of 1). The domain uses a 20×10×20 mesh grid with simple grading. Apply no-slip boundary conditions on all walls (floor, ceiling, and fixedWalls), with temperature boundary conditions of 300K fixed value on floor and ceiling, and zero gradient on fixedWalls. Initialize the domain with uniform temperature of 300K and use setFields to create a hot zone at coordinates 4.5≤x≤5.5, -1000≤y≤1e-5, 4.5≤z≤5.5 with temperature of 600K. Set gravity to -9.81 m/s² in y-direction. Use RAS k-epsilon turbulence model with wall functions (epsilonWallFunction, kqRWallFunction, nutkWallFunction). Apply PIMPLE algorithm with residual control tolerances of 1e-2 for p_rgh, 1e-3 for velocity and enthalpy. Set physical properties for air with molecular weight 28.9, reference density 1 kg/m³ at T0=300K, thermal expansion coefficient beta=3e-03 K⁻¹, specific heat Cp=1000 J/kg·K, dynamic viscosity mu=1e-05 Pa·s, and Prandtl number Pr=0.7. Run simulation from time 0 to 2000 with timestep of 1 and output results every 100 timesteps using steadyState time scheme.

Conduct a buoyant natural convection simulation using buoyantFoam solver to study Bernard cells formation in a rectangular domain with dimensions 9×1×2 units (convertToMeters factor of 1). The domain represents a 2D channel with 90×10×1 mesh cells where the floor boundary is heated to 301K, the ceiling is cooled to 300K, and the side walls have zero gradient temperature boundary conditions. Initialize the fluid with uniform temperature of 300K and small velocity perturbation of 1e-4 m/s in x-direction. Use Boussinesq approximation with reference density of 1 kg/m³, reference temperature of 300K, thermal expansion coefficient of 1e-3 K⁻¹, dynamic viscosity of 1e-3 Pa·s, Prandtl number of 1, and specific heat at constant volume of 712 J/kg·K. Apply laminar flow simulation with gravity acting in negative y-direction at 9.81 m/s². Set all walls with no-slip velocity boundary conditions, fixedFluxPressure for p_rgh, and front/back faces as empty for 2D simulation. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 2 correctors, no momentum predictor, Euler time scheme, and run simulation from time 0 to 1000 seconds with timestep of 1 second, outputting results every 50 seconds.

Conduct a buoyant natural convection heat transfer simulation using buoyantFoam solver with RAS k-epsilon turbulence modeling. The domain is a 3D rectangular room with dimensions 10 units length × 5 units height × 10 units width (convertToMeters factor of 1). Use a structured mesh with 20×10×20 cells in x, y, and z directions respectively. Apply no-slip boundary conditions on all walls (floor, ceiling, and fixedWalls) with wall functions for turbulent quantities. Set temperature boundary conditions with fixedValue of 300K on floor and ceiling, and zeroGradient on fixedWalls. Initialize the domain with uniform temperature of 300K and create a hot region using setFields in the box from (4.5, -1000, 4.5) to (5.5, 1e-5, 5.5) with temperature of 600K. Use fixedFluxPressure boundary conditions for p_rgh on all walls with reference pressure of 1e5 Pa. Set fluid properties as air with molecular weight 28.9, constant specific heat Cp=1000 J/kg·K, dynamic viscosity μ=1.8e-05 Pa·s, and Prandtl number 0.7 using perfectGas equation of state. Apply gravity acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in y-direction. Run simulation from time 0 to 2000 seconds with timestep of 2 seconds using PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector and 2 correctors, outputting results every 100 timesteps.

Conduct a conjugate heat transfer simulation using chtMultiRegionFoam solver for a heated duct system with multi-region coupling between fluid and solid domains. The geometry consists of a rectangular duct with dimensions 50.001 x 60.001 x 150.001 units (convertToMeters factor of 0.001, making actual dimensions 50.001mm x 60.001mm x 150.001mm), meshed with 20x24x60 cells using simpleGrading. The simulation involves three regions: a fluid region and two solid regions (metal and heater). Use PIMPLE algorithm with adjustable time stepping starting from deltaT of 1e-3, maximum Courant number of 1.0, maximum diffusion number of 10.0, running from time 0 to 20 seconds with output every 1 second using adjustableRunTime write control. The case is configured for parallel decomposition into 4 subdomains using hierarchical method with distribution (1 1 4) in xyz order.

Conduct a conjugate heat transfer simulation using chtMultiRegionFoam solver for a reverse burner configuration with two coupled regions: a fluid region (gas) and a solid region (solid). Use PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector for pressure-velocity coupling. The simulation runs from time 0 to 6 seconds with an initial timestep of 1e-5 seconds and adaptive timestepping enabled with maximum Courant number of 0.2 and maximum diffusion number of 5.0. Output results every 0.1 seconds using adjustable runtime control. Include heat transfer rate (Qdot) function monitoring for the gas region. Configure for parallel processing using hierarchical decomposition method with 4 subdomains arranged in a 1x4x1 distribution along xyz axes.

Perform a conjugate heat transfer simulation using chtMultiRegionFoam solver for a 2D cooling cylinder configuration with fluid-solid interaction. The domain consists of two regions: a fluid region and a solid cylindrical region defined by a cylinder with center at (0,0,0) and radius specified by the cylinderRadius parameter from blockMeshDict, extending from z=-100 to z=100. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector for pressure-velocity coupling. The simulation runs from time 0 to 20 seconds with a fixed timestep of 0.01 seconds, outputting results every 0.1 seconds using adjustable run time control. Set maximum Courant number to 5, maximum diffusion number to 200, and maximum timestep to 1 second. Include function objects to monitor patch-averaged temperature on the fluid_to_solid interface and patch-averaged velocity at the inlet. The case involves heat transfer between the fluid and solid regions through the coupled fluid_to_solid boundary interface.

Perform a conjugate heat transfer simulation of a shell-and-tube heat exchanger using chtMultiRegionFoam solver with three regions: shell fluid, tube fluid, and solid. The domain geometry spans -1.7501 to 1.7501 in x-direction, -1.0001 to 1.0001 in y-direction, and -0.3751 to 5.3751 in z-direction with convertToMeters factor of 0.04. Use a structured mesh with 40x115x70 cells and simple grading. Configure mapped wall boundary conditions between regions with shell_to_solid and tube_to_solid interfaces for conjugate heat transfer coupling. Set simulation time from 0 to 1000 seconds with timestep of 1 second, using adjustable run time write control with output interval of 100 seconds. Apply PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector and include residual monitoring functions for pressure (p_rgh), velocity (U), and enthalpy (h) fields in all fluid regions, and enthalpy in the solid region. Use binary write format with 6-digit precision and disable time step adjustment.

Perform a conjugate heat transfer simulation using chtMultiRegionFoam solver for a multi-region heat exchanger domain consisting of fluid regions (air and porous) and solid regions. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector. The simulation runs from time 0 to 2000 seconds with a timestep of 1 second, outputting results every 50 timesteps. Configure the case for parallel processing using scotch decomposition method with 4 subdomains. The simulation starts from the latest available time and uses general time format with 6-digit precision for both writing and time representation.

Perform a conjugate heat transfer simulation using chtMultiRegionFoam solver for a cooling sphere configuration. The domain consists of a spherical solid region (copper material) centered at coordinates (0,0,0) embedded within a fluid region (air material). Set initial temperature to 296 K and initial pressure to 1e5 Pa for both regions. The simulation uses PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector iteration. Run the simulation from time 0 to 1 second with a timestep of 5e-4 seconds, outputting results every 0.05 seconds. The case is configured for parallel decomposition into 4 subdomains using scotch method. The solid region is defined as a cellZone created from a spherical cellSet, while the remaining domain represents the fluid region for conjugate heat transfer analysis between the copper sphere and surrounding air.

Perform a European call option pricing simulation using financialFoam solver to solve the Black-Scholes partial differential equation. The computational domain is a 1D financial grid extending from 0 to 1 in the x-direction (scaled by convertToMeters factor of 200), with minimal thickness of 0.2 units in y-direction and 0.1 units in z-direction, discretized using 500 cells in x-direction and 1 cell each in y and z directions. Apply boundary conditions with fixedValue of 0 at the lowValue boundary (left face at x=0) representing out-of-the-money options, and fixedGradient of 60 at the highValue boundary (right face at x=1) representing deep in-the-money options, while defaultFaces are set as empty boundaries. Configure the simulation with financial properties including strike price of 40, risk-free interest rate (r) of 0.1, volatility (sigma) of 0.2, dividend yield (s) of 0, and additional parameters xi of 0.1 and eta of 0. Run the simulation from startTime 0 to endTime 0.5 with timestep deltaT of 0.002, outputting results every 50 timesteps using PBiCGStab solver with DILU preconditioner and tolerance of 1e-05 for the option value field V.

Perform a steady-state heat conduction simulation using laplacianFoam solver on a flange geometry. The domain is a 3D rectangular block with dimensions 0.06m × 0.06m × 0.04m (from -0.03 to 0.03 in x and y directions, -0.03 to 0.01 in z direction) with convertToMeters factor of 1. Use a structured mesh with 20×16×12 cells in x, y, and z directions respectively. The flange STL geometry defines four boundary patches: patch1 (wall) and patch3 (rings) with zeroGradient temperature boundary conditions, patch2 (plate) with fixed temperature of 273K, and patch4 (outlet) with fixed temperature of 573K. Set initial temperature field to uniform 273K throughout the domain. Use thermal diffusivity (DT) of 4e-05 m²/s. Run the simulation from time 0 to 3 seconds with timestep of 0.005s and output results every 0.1s. Employ PCG solver with DIC preconditioner for temperature field with tolerance of 1e-06 and 2 non-orthogonal correctors in the SIMPLE algorithm. Use Euler time discretization, Gauss linear gradient schemes, and Gauss linear corrected laplacian schemes for temperature diffusion.

Perform a scalar transport simulation using scalarTransportFoam solver on the classic pitzDaily geometry, which is a 2D backward-facing step channel with inlet, outlet, upperWall, lowerWall, and frontAndBack patches (designated as empty for 2D simulation). Set boundary conditions with a fixed scalar value T=1 at the inlet, zeroGradient conditions at the outlet and both walls, while the internal field is initialized uniformly to T=0. Use a diffusion coefficient DT of 0.01 m²/s. Configure the simulation to run from startTime 0 to endTime 0.1 seconds with a timestep deltaT of 0.0001 seconds, outputting results every 50 timesteps. Apply Euler time discretization scheme, Gauss linear gradient schemes, linearUpwind divergence scheme for scalar transport div(phi,T), and corrected Laplacian schemes. Use PBiCGStab solver with DILU preconditioner for the scalar field T with tolerance 1e-06 and zero relative tolerance, with no non-orthogonal correctors in the SIMPLE algorithm.

Perform a potential flow simulation around a cylinder using potentialFoam solver. The domain is a 2D geometry with a cylinder obstacle where the left boundary has a uniform fixed velocity of 1 m/s in the x-direction, the right boundary has fixed pressure value of 0, the top and bottom boundaries use symmetryPlane conditions, the cylinder surface uses symmetry boundary condition, and defaultFaces are set as empty for 2D simulation. The simulation uses steady-state time discretization with Gauss linear gradient schemes, bounded Gauss linear divergence schemes for velocity, and Gauss linear corrected Laplacian schemes. The pressure solver uses GAMG with DIC smoother, tolerance of 1e-06 and relative tolerance of 0.01, with 3 non-orthogonal correctors for the potential flow algorithm. The velocity field has dimensions [0 1 -1 0 0 0 0] and pressure field has dimensions [0 2 -2 0 0 0 0], both initialized uniformly to zero in the internal field.

Perform a dense particle flow simulation using denseParticleFoam solver for a rectangular channel with dimensions 15mm x 150mm x 450mm (scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.001). The domain represents a vertical fluidized bed with air as the continuous phase having density 1.2 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1.568e-05 m²/s under laminar flow conditions. Set boundary conditions as follows: bottom patch with interstitial inlet velocity of 1.875 m/s in z-direction for air phase, top patch with fixed pressure value of 0 Pa and pressure inlet-outlet velocity condition, walls with no-slip velocity and fixed flux pressure conditions, and front/back faces as symmetry planes. Use a structured mesh of 1x15x45 cells with simple grading. Apply PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 2 correctors, momentum predictor enabled, and reference pressure of 0 Pa at cell 0. Include gravity acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in z-direction. Run simulation from time 0 to 5 seconds with timestep of 2e-4 seconds and output results every 0.01 seconds using Euler time scheme and Gauss linear spatial discretization schemes.

Perform a dense particle cyclone separation simulation using denseParticleFoam solver with Large Eddy Simulation (LES) turbulence modeling using kEqn model. The domain is a rectangular cyclone chamber with dimensions 1.1 x 1.1 x 2.1 meters (convertToMeters = 1), extending from -0.55 to 0.55 in x and y directions, and -1 to 1.1 in z direction. Use a structured hexahedral mesh with 33x33x63 cells providing uniform grid resolution. Set boundary conditions with fixed velocity inlet at -10 m/s in x-direction on the right face, fixed pressure outlet (0 Pa) at the top face, and no-slip wall conditions for all remaining surfaces. Configure air as the continuous phase with density of 1.2 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity of 1.568e-05 m²/s, with gravity acting downward at -9.81 m/s². Apply PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 2 pressure correctors, momentum predictor enabled, and 0 non-orthogonal correctors. Run simulation from time 0 to 7 seconds with timestep of 2e-4 seconds, outputting results every 0.1 seconds using binary format with 6-digit precision.

Perform a dense particle fluidization simulation using denseParticleFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm (1 outer corrector, 2 correctors, momentum predictor enabled). The domain is a rectangular column with dimensions 15mm x 150mm x 450mm (convertToMeters 0.001), representing a fluidized bed geometry with vertices from (-7.5, -75, 0) to (7.5, 75, 450) in the mesh coordinate system. Use a structured mesh of 2x30x90 cells in x, y, and z directions respectively. Set boundary conditions as follows: bottom patch with interstitialInletVelocity of (0, 0, 1.875) m/s for air inlet, top patch with pressureInletOutletVelocity and fixedValue pressure of 0 Pa for outlet, walls with noSlip velocity and fixedFluxPressure, and frontAndBack patches as symmetry planes. Configure air as the continuous phase with density of 1.2 kg/m³, kinematic viscosity of 1e-05 m²/s, and laminar flow simulation. Apply gravitational acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in z-direction. Run simulation from time 0 to 5 seconds with timestep of 2e-05 seconds, outputting results every 0.01 seconds using binary format with Euler time scheme and Gauss linear spatial schemes.

do a dense particle flow simulation using denseParticleFoam solver for an injection channel geometry with two inlet streams. The domain has walls with no-slip boundary conditions, a lowerInlet with fixed velocity of (18.7939, 6.8404, 0) m/s, an upperInlet with fixed velocity of (18.7939, -6.8404, 0) m/s, an outlet with inletOutlet boundary condition, and frontAndBack faces with symmetry boundary conditions. Use fixedFluxPressure boundary condition for walls and inlets with fixedValue pressure of 0 at the outlet. Set air density to 1.2 kg/m³ with kinematic viscosity of 1e-05 m²/s under laminar flow conditions. Run simulation from time 0 to 0.1 seconds with timestep of 1e-4 seconds and output results every 0.001 seconds. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 2 correctors, momentum predictor enabled, and reference pressure cell 0 with value 0. Apply Euler time scheme with Gauss linear gradient schemes and linearUpwindV divergence scheme for momentum transport.

Perform a dense particle flow simulation using denseParticleFoam solver to model Lagrangian particle dynamics in a vertical column. The domain is a rectangular column with dimensions -9.2 to 9.2 in x-direction, -9.2 to 9.2 in y-direction, and 0 to 300 in z-direction with convertToMeters factor of 0.001 (making it an 18.4mm x 18.4mm x 300mm column). Use a mesh with 1x1x40 cells providing fine resolution in the vertical direction. Apply symmetry boundary conditions on all four side faces, no-slip wall conditions on both top and bottom faces, and fixedFluxPressure boundary conditions for pressure on top and bottom walls. Set the continuous phase as air with density of 1.2 kg/m³, constant kinematic viscosity of 1e-05 m²/s, and laminar flow simulation. Include gravitational acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in the z-direction. Run the simulation from time 0 to 1 second with a timestep of 2e-4 seconds, outputting results every 0.01 seconds. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 2 correctors, momentum predictor enabled, and reference pressure cell at 0 with reference value of 0. Initialize the domain with zero velocity and zero pressure throughout.

do a lagrangian particle simulation using particleFoam solver for a hopper geometry. The domain represents a 2D hopper with dimensions 300mm length, 500mm height, and 6.2mm depth (scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.001). The geometry consists of two hexahedral blocks forming a funnel shape with sloped walls converging to a narrow outlet region between x-coordinates 135mm to 165mm at the bottom. Apply no-slip boundary conditions to all 'walls' and 'frontAndBack' surfaces, with zero gradient velocity boundary condition at the 'outlet'. Set initial velocity field to zero throughout the domain. Use a mesh with 20x40x1 cells for the upper block and 20x8x1 cells for the lower funnel section. Run the simulation from time 0 to 0.25 seconds with a timestep of 5e-5 seconds, outputting results every 0.05 seconds. Set fluid density (rhoInf) to 1.2 kg/m³, kinematic viscosity (nu) to 1e-05 m²/s, and gravity acceleration to -9.81 m/s² in the y-direction. Use laminar flow simulation without turbulence modeling.

Perform a Lagrangian particle tracking simulation using particleFoam solver for a hopper emptying process. The domain represents a 2D hopper geometry with dimensions scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.001 (millimeter scale), featuring a funnel-shaped hopper that narrows from 300mm width at the top to approximately 135mm at the throat, with total height of 577.9mm and thickness of 6.2mm in the z-direction. The mesh consists of 3 hexahedral blocks with grid resolution of 24x50x1, 24x8x1, and 24x6x1 cells respectively. Boundary conditions include no-slip walls for the hopper surfaces and front/back faces, zero gradient velocity conditions at both inlet (top opening) and outlet (bottom opening). Physical properties specify air with density of 1.2 kg/m³, dynamic viscosity of 1.2e-05 Pa·s, kinematic viscosity of 1e-05 m²/s, and gravity acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in the y-direction. The simulation uses laminar flow model, runs from time 0 to 5 seconds with timestep of 5e-5 seconds, and outputs results every 0.02 seconds for particle trajectory analysis during the hopper emptying process.

Perform a multiphase Lagrangian particle simulation of a 2D mixer vessel using particleFoam solver with dynamic mesh motion. The domain consists of a cylindrical mixer vessel with rotating rotor and stator components, where the rotor rotates at 6.2832 rad/s (1 Hz) about the z-axis and the stator counter-rotates at -6.2832 rad/s. The simulation involves four phases: water (alpha=0.7, density=1000 kg/m³, viscosity=1e-06 m²/s), air (alpha=0.1, density=1 kg/m³, viscosity=1.48e-05 m²/s), oil (alpha=0.1, density=500 kg/m³, viscosity=5e-4 Pa·s), and mercury (alpha=0.1, density=13529 kg/m³, viscosity=8.6e-4 Pa·s), all initially at 300K temperature. Boundary conditions specify movingWallVelocity for the rotor patch, noSlip conditions for the stator patch, and movingWallSlipVelocity for the nonCouple interface with zeroGradient conditions for all phase fractions and temperatures, fixedFluxPressure for p_rgh, and calculated pressure boundaries. The simulation runs from time 0 to 0.25 seconds with a timestep of 2e-5 seconds, outputting results every 0.01 seconds using binary format. Use laminar flow model for all phases with gravity set to (0 -9.81 0) m/s², initial pressure of 1e5 Pa, and PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 3 correctors, and no non-orthogonal corrections.

Conduct a 3D buoyant reacting combustion simulation using buoyantReactingFoam solver with Large Eddy Simulation (LES) turbulence modeling using kEqn model. The domain is a cubic combustion chamber with dimensions 1.0m x 1.0m x 1.0m (convertToMeters = 1), discretized with a 60x60x60 uniform grid. The inlet boundary at the base center (region -0.1 ≤ x ≤ 0.1, -0.001 ≤ y ≤ 0.005, -0.1 ≤ z ≤ 0.1) supplies pure methane (CH4 mass fraction = 1.0) with fixed velocity of 0.01 m/s in the y-direction and temperature of 300K. The base uses no-slip wall conditions with zero gradient for species and temperature. The outlet at the top applies fixed pressure (101325 Pa) with inletOutlet conditions for velocity, temperature (300K), and species. The side walls use pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocity and inletOutlet for temperature and species. Initial conditions include atmospheric pressure (101325 Pa), ambient temperature (300K), air composition (O2 = 0.23301, N2 = 0.76699), and turbulent kinetic energy k = 1e-4 m²/s². The simulation uses infinitelyFastChemistry combustion model with coefficient C = 5.0, radiation modeling with greyDiffusiveRadiation and MarshakRadiation boundary conditions, gravity acceleration of -9.8 m/s² in y-direction, adjustable time stepping with maxCo = 0.6, initial timestep of 0.001s, maximum timestep of 0.1s, total simulation time of 4.0s, and output every 0.1s.

Conduct a 2D buoyant reacting combustion simulation using buoyantReactingFoam solver with LES turbulence modeling and kEqn subgrid-scale model. The domain is a rectangular combustion chamber with dimensions 1.0m width × 1.0m height × 0.02m depth (convertToMeters = 1), meshed with 150×150×1 cells making it effectively 2D. The inlet patch (located at the base center from -0.0529m to 0.0529m) introduces pure methane (CH4 mass fraction = 1.0) at 300K with fixed velocity of 0.05 m/s in the y-direction. The base boundary has no-slip velocity condition with zeroGradient for temperature and species. The outlet (top boundary) and sides use pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocity and inletOutlet conditions for temperature (300K), turbulent kinetic energy (1e-4 m²/s²), and species concentrations. The ambient air composition is N2 (0.76699) and O2 (0.23301) mass fractions. Initial conditions include uniform pressure of 101325 Pa, temperature of 300K, and atmospheric composition throughout the domain. The simulation uses infinitelyFastChemistry combustion model with radiation modeling enabled, gravity set to -9.8 m/s² in y-direction, and runs from 0 to 3.0 seconds with adaptive timestep (maxCo = 0.5, initial deltaT = 0.001s) outputting results every 0.1 seconds.

Perform a buoyant reacting flow simulation with Lagrangian particle tracking and surface film modeling using buoyantReactingFoam solver. The domain is a rectangular geometry with dimensions 0.1m x 0.05m x 0.1m (convertToMeters factor of 0.1 applied to base dimensions of 1 x 0.5 x 1). Use a structured mesh of 20x10x20 cells. The initial gas mixture consists of 77% N2 and 23% O2 at 300K temperature and 100000 Pa pressure with zero initial velocity. Boundary conditions include: top patch with pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocity and inletOutlet for species (H2O, N2, O2) and temperature, prghTotalPressure for p_rgh; walls patch (region0_to_wallFilm_walls) with noSlip velocity, fixedValue temperature at 300K, zeroGradient for species, and fixedFluxPressure for p_rgh; sides patches with symmetry conditions. Include gravity acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in z-direction. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 2 correctors, no non-orthogonal correctors, and momentum predictor enabled. Inject Lagrangian particles at position (0.005, 0.0025, 0.009) with initial velocity (0, 0, -5) m/s, diameter 0.001m, density 1000 kg/m³, temperature 300K. Enable surface film modeling on walls with Newtonian viscosity, surface tension 0.07 N/m, wet film thickness 1e-4m, and laminar momentum transport with friction coefficient 0.005. Run simulation from time 0 to 1 second with adaptive timestep starting at 1e-4 seconds, maximum Courant number 0.3, maximum timestep 1e-3 seconds, and output every 0.01 seconds using adjustable runtime control.

Conduct a buoyant reacting flow simulation with surface film modeling using buoyantReactingFoam solver. The domain is a 3D rectangular channel with dimensions 0.75 x 1.0 x 1.0 units (convertToMeters = 1), discretized with a structured mesh of 180x1x240 cells in the x, y, and z directions respectively. Initialize the domain with atmospheric air composition (N2: 0.77, O2: 0.23, H2O: 0.0) at 300K temperature and 100000 Pa pressure with zero initial velocity. Apply pressureInletOutletVelocity boundary conditions at inlet, outlet, and sides patches with 300K fixed temperature, while the filmWalls patch (region0_to_wallFilmRegion_wallFilmFaces) uses noSlip velocity and 300K fixed temperature. Implement a coupled surface film region with laminar momentum transport, surface tension coefficient of 0.07 N/m, thermocapillary forces, and distributionContactAngle model with normal distribution (expectation 75°, variance 100, range 50-100°). Use PIMPLE algorithm with 2 correctors, no non-orthogonal correctors, momentum predictor enabled, and laminar flow simulation. Set gravity to -9.81 m/s² in y-direction, run simulation from 0 to 3 seconds with adaptive timestep (initial 1e-4s, maximum 1e-3s, maxCo 0.1), and output results every 0.02 seconds using binary format.

Perform a buoyant reacting foam simulation using buoyantReactingFoam solver with Lagrangian particle tracking and surface film modeling. The domain is a rectangular box with dimensions 1m x 1m x 1.5m (convertToMeters = 1) containing four hot box regions defined by exclusion zones at coordinates (0.4,0.1,0.1)-(0.6,0.3,0.3), (0.4,0.1,0.4)-(0.6,0.3,0.6), (0.4,0.4,0.1)-(0.6,0.6,0.3), and (0.4,0.4,0.4)-(0.6,0.6,0.6). Use an 80x80x120 structured mesh with gravity set to (0,0,-9.81) m/s². Initialize the domain with atmospheric pressure (100000 Pa), temperature of 300K, and air composition (N2=0.77, O2=0.23, H2O=0). Apply no-slip wall boundary conditions with fixed temperature of 300K on all walls, and implement mapped boundary conditions on region interfaces for coupled heat transfer. Set the bottom surface as 'wallFilm' for surface film modeling with 0.001m thickness. Use k-epsilon turbulence model with wall functions, PIMPLE algorithm with 2 correctors, and run from time 0 to 2 seconds with adaptive timestep starting at 1e-04s (maxCo=0.2, maxDeltaT=0.002s). Output results every 0.1 seconds using adjustable runtime control and include multicomponent mixture thermodynamics with perfectGas equation of state and Sutherland transport properties.

Conduct a reactive flow simulation using reactingFoam solver with RAS k-epsilon turbulence modeling for a membrane separation system. The domain is a rectangular box with dimensions 5.0 x 2.4 x 6.0 units (convertToMeters = 1), meshed with 50x24x60 cells using blockMesh. The system features two inlet streams: inletSleeve with velocity (1,0,0) m/s containing 77% N2 and 23% O2, and inletPipe with velocity (0,0,1) m/s containing 50% CH4 and 50% N2. Apply outlet boundary conditions with pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocity and totalPressure at 1e5 Pa for pressure. The membrane surfaces (membraneSleeve and membranePipe) use semiPermeableBaffleMassFraction boundary conditions with mass transfer coefficient c=0.1 for CH4, and specieTransferVelocity for velocity coupling. Wall boundaries have no-slip conditions and zeroGradient for temperature and species. Set initial conditions: uniform temperature 293 K, pressure 1e5 Pa, turbulent kinetic energy 0.00375 m²/s², and dissipation rate 0.012 m²/s³. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 2 correctors, momentum predictor enabled, and adjustable timestep with initial deltaT=1e-3 s, maxCo=1, running from 0 to 10 seconds with output every 0.1 seconds. Configure the thermo model as hePsiThermo with multiComponentMixture, perfectGas equation of state, and Sutherland transport properties for the three-species system (CH4, N2, O2) with N2 as default specie.

Conduct a reactive combustion simulation using reactingFoam solver with RAS k-epsilon turbulence modeling and EDC combustion model. The domain is an axisymmetric burner configuration with wedge geometry where the fuel inlet (inletfuel) has fixed velocity of 42.2 m/s in z-direction with fuel composition of H2 (0.046496), CH4 (0.245642), and N2 (0.707861) at temperature 292K, the air inlet (inletair) has fixed velocity of 0.3 m/s in z-direction with air composition of O2 (0.231843), N2 (0.763149), and H2O (0.005008) at temperature 292K, the outlet uses pressureInletOutletVelocity and totalPressure boundary conditions at 101325 Pa, wall boundaries (leftside, burnerwall, burnertip) have no-slip velocity conditions with wall functions for turbulence and thermal properties, and an ignition region is initialized with temperature 2200K in the box region from (0.002, -0.01, 0.005) to (0.02, 0.01, 0.055). Use PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 2 correctors, maximum Courant number 0.25, maximum timestep 1e-4, and local time stepping. The simulation runs from time 0 to 10000 with adaptive timestep starting at 1 and outputs results every 1000 time units. Include radiation modeling with Marshak boundary conditions and gravity acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in z-direction.

Perform a reactive combustion simulation using reactingFoam solver for the Sandia Flame D configuration. The domain is an axisymmetric wedge geometry representing a turbulent methane-air diffusion flame with a pilot. The simulation includes three inlets: inletCH4 with methane fuel at 49.6 m/s velocity and 294 K temperature (CH4 mass fraction 0.1561, O2 0.1966, N2 0.6473), inletAir with coflow air at 0.9 m/s velocity and 291 K temperature (O2 0.23, N2 0.77), and inletPilot with hot combustion products at 11.4 m/s velocity and 1880 K temperature containing combustion species (H2O 0.0942, CO2 0.1098, OH 0.0028, etc.). Apply no-slip boundary conditions on wallTube, zero gradient conditions on wallOutside, and pressure outlet at the outlet with total pressure 100000 Pa. Use k-epsilon RAS turbulence model with wall functions and turbulent intensity values of 4.58% for CH4 inlet, 4.71% for air inlet, and 6.28% for pilot inlet. Implement EDC combustion model with GRI chemical mechanism including species transport for CH4, O2, N2, H2O, CO2, CO, H2, OH, H, and O. Set initial conditions with uniform temperature 300 K, pressure 100000 Pa, and air composition throughout the domain except for the fuel region. Use PIMPLE algorithm with local time stepping, maximum time step 1e-4 s, maximum Courant number 0.25, and run simulation from time 0 to 1500 s with output every 1500 s. Include radiation modeling with Marshak boundary conditions and gravity acceleration -9.81 m/s² in z-direction.

Perform a 2D laminar combustion simulation using reactingFoam solver for a counterflow flame configuration. The domain is a rectangular channel with dimensions 0.02m x 0.02m x 0.02m (convertToMeters = 1) meshed with 100x40x1 cells, effectively making it 2D with empty frontAndBack boundaries. Set up counterflow boundary conditions with fuel inlet (left boundary) having fixed velocity of 0.1 m/s in positive x-direction, fixed temperature of 293K, and pure CH4 mass fraction of 1.0, while air inlet (right boundary) has fixed velocity of 0.1 m/s in negative x-direction, fixed temperature of 293K, with O2 mass fraction of 0.23 and N2 mass fraction of 0.77. Configure outlet boundaries (top and bottom) with pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocity, totalPressure boundary condition, and inletOutlet conditions for species mass fractions. Initialize the domain with uniform pressure of 1e5 Pa, temperature of 2000K, and N2 mass fraction of 1.0. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 2 correctors, no momentum predictor, and 0 non-orthogonal correctors. Enable laminar combustion model with EulerImplicit chemistry solver, initial chemical timestep of 1e-7s, and include detailed chemical kinetics. Run simulation from 0 to 0.5 seconds with adaptive timestep starting at 1e-6s, maximum Courant number of 0.4, and output results every 0.05 seconds.

Conduct a laminar counterflow flame combustion simulation using reactingFoam solver with GRI chemical mechanism and TDAC reduction. The domain is a 2D rectangular channel with dimensions 0.02m x 0.02m x 0.02m (convertToMeters factor of 1), meshed with 100x40x1 cells using a structured grid. The fuel inlet (left boundary at x=0) has a fixed velocity of 0.1 m/s in the positive x-direction with pure methane (CH4 mass fraction = 1.0) at 293K temperature, while the air inlet (right boundary at x=0.02m) has a fixed velocity of 0.1 m/s in the negative x-direction with air composition (O2 mass fraction = 0.23, N2 mass fraction = 0.77) at 293K temperature. The top and bottom boundaries serve as outlets with pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocity, totalPressure boundary condition for pressure (1e5 Pa), and inletOutlet conditions for species mass fractions. The frontAndBack faces are designated as empty for 2D simulation. Initialize the domain with uniform pressure of 1e5 Pa, uniform temperature of 2000K, and N2 mass fraction of 1.0. Use PIMPLE algorithm with momentumPredictor off, 1 outer corrector, 1 corrector, maxCo = 1, and maxDeltaT = 1e-4. Run the simulation from time 0 to 1500 seconds with initial timestep of 1 second using localEuler time scheme, and output results every 20 time units. Enable laminar combustion model with chemistry on, using ode solver with seulex method, and include heat release rate (Qdot) calculations.

Conduct a 2D laminar reacting flow counter-flow flame simulation using reactingFoam solver with GRI mechanism and TDAC reduction. The domain is a rectangular channel with dimensions 0.02m x 0.02m x 0.02m (convertToMeters = 1) meshed with 100x40x1 cells. Set fuel inlet boundary (left face) with CH4 mass fraction of 1.0, fixed velocity of 0.1 m/s in positive x-direction, and temperature of 293K. Configure air inlet boundary (right face) with O2 mass fraction of 0.23, N2 mass fraction of 0.77, fixed velocity of -0.1 m/s (counter-flow), and temperature of 293K. Apply pressureInletOutletVelocity and inletOutlet conditions for velocity and species at outlet boundaries (top and bottom faces), with zero gradient pressure boundary conditions at fuel and air inlets and total pressure at outlets. Initialize internal field with uniform pressure of 1e5 Pa and temperature of 2000K. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 2 correctors, no momentum predictor, and 0 non-orthogonal correctors. Set adaptive time stepping with initial deltaT of 1e-6s, maximum Courant number of 0.4, simulation end time of 0.5s, and output every 0.05s. Enable chemistry with ode solver using seulex method, initial chemical time step of 1e-7s, and include Qdot function for heat release rate monitoring.

Conduct a 2D laminar counter-flow flame combustion simulation using reactingFoam solver with a rectangular domain of dimensions 0.02m x 0.02m x 0.02m (convertToMeters factor of 1) discretized with a 100x40x1 grid. Set up counter-flowing streams with fuel inlet (left boundary) having CH4 mass fraction of 1.0, velocity of 0.1 m/s in positive x-direction, and temperature of 293K, while air inlet (right boundary) has O2 mass fraction of 0.23, N2 mass fraction of 0.77, velocity of -0.1 m/s (negative x-direction), and temperature of 293K. Apply zeroGradient pressure boundary conditions at both inlets, totalPressure condition at the outlet (top and bottom boundaries), and pressureInletOutletVelocity for outlet velocity. Initialize the domain with uniform pressure of 1e5 Pa, temperature of 2000K, and zero species concentrations except N2 (uniform 1). Use PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 1 pressure corrector, no momentum predictor, maximum Courant number of 1, and maximum timestep of 0.01s. Run the simulation from time 0 to 1000s with initial timestep of 1s using localEuler time scheme, outputting results every 20s. Enable laminar combustion model with EulerImplicit chemistry solver, initial chemical timestep of 1e-07s, and include multi-component transport properties with Sutherland viscosity model and Janaf thermodynamic data for perfectGas equation of state.

Perform a 2D laminar reacting flow combustion simulation using reactingFoam solver with GRI chemical mechanism. The domain is a rectangular channel with dimensions 0.02m × 0.02m × 0.02m (length × height × width) with convertToMeters factor of 1, meshed with 100×40×1 cells using a single cell in the z-direction for 2D flow characteristics. Set up a counter-flow flame configuration where the fuel inlet (left boundary) has CH4 mass fraction of 1.0, velocity of 0.1 m/s in positive x-direction, and temperature of 293K, while the air inlet (right boundary) has O2 mass fraction of 0.23, N2 mass fraction of 0.77, velocity of -0.1 m/s (counter-flow), and temperature of 293K. Apply zeroGradient pressure boundary conditions at fuel and air inlets, totalPressure condition at outlets (top and bottom boundaries), and pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocity at outlets. Initialize the internal field with uniform pressure of 1e5 Pa and temperature of 2000K. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 2 correctors, no momentum predictor, and 0 non-orthogonal correctors. Set timestep of 1e-6s with adjustable time stepping (maxCo = 0.4), run from time 0 to 0.5s, and output results every 0.05s. Enable laminar combustion model with ODE chemistry solver using seulex method, absolute tolerance of 1e-8, relative tolerance of 0.1, and initial chemical timestep of 1e-7s.

Perform a reacting flow simulation using reactingFoam solver with Lagrangian particle tracking in a vertical channel geometry. The domain features a 2D channel with symmetry planes at front and back boundaries, walls on the sides, separate central and side inlets, and an outlet at the top. Boundary conditions specify flowRateInletVelocity with mass flow rates of 0.00379 kg/s for the central inlet and 0.00832 kg/s for the side inlets using turbulent boundary layer profiles, fixedValue pressure of 100000 Pa at the outlet with fixedFluxPressure at inlets and walls, no-slip conditions at walls, and species concentrations with H2O at 0.01 and air at 0.99 at inlets. Temperature boundary conditions set the central inlet to 573K and side inlets to 473K with zeroGradient at walls. Use k-omega SST turbulence model with turbulent intensity of 5% and mixing length of 0.007m at inlets. The simulation runs from time 0 to 0.5 seconds with initial timestep of 1e-05 seconds, adjustable timestep enabled with maximum Courant number of 5 and maximum timestep of 1e-03 seconds, outputting results every 0.01 seconds. Apply PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 3 correctors, buoyancy forces with gravity of -9.81 m/s² in y-direction, and include Lagrangian cloud particle tracking with sample frequency of 1 and maximum 1000000 positions.

Conduct a reactive flow simulation with Lagrangian particle tracking using reactingFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm (1 outer corrector, 2 correctors, no non-orthogonal corrections). The domain is a 2D combustion chamber with cyclic boundaries on left and right sides, featuring an explicit porous filter zone with Darcy-Forchheimer resistance coefficients d=(500000, -1000, -1000) and f=(0, 0, 0). Set inlet boundary conditions with fixed velocity of 5 m/s in x-direction, temperature of 350 K, oxygen mass fraction of 0.23, nitrogen mass fraction of 0.77, and zero water vapor. Apply no-slip wall conditions with fixed temperature of 400 K and Marshak radiation boundary conditions with emissivity of 1.0. Set outlet with zero gradient velocity, fixed pressure of 100000 Pa, and zero gradient for species. Initialize the domain with uniform pressure of 100000 Pa, temperature of 350 K, and turbulent kinetic energy k=0.0938 m²/s² and dissipation rate epsilon=0.0449 m²/s³ using k-epsilon RAS turbulence model. Include a mass source at location (2.75, 0.5, 0) with square pulse injection (start=0.2s, duration=2s) at rate 1e-4 kg/s, injecting pure water vapor at 100000 J/kg enthalpy with 50 m/s upward velocity. Configure Lagrangian particle injection with 4 parcel streams starting at x=0.1 with y-positions of 0.32, 0.44, 0.56, 0.68, each having 0.5 m/s x-velocity, varying y-velocities, 0.001m diameter, 1000 kg/m³ density, and initial temperature of 300 K. Run simulation from 0 to 5 seconds with adaptive timestep (initial 0.001s, max Courant number 1.0) and output every 0.1 seconds using binary format.

Conduct a reactive combustion simulation using reactingFoam solver with Lagrangian particle tracking for the Aachen bomb combustion chamber. The domain is a rectangular combustion chamber with dimensions 20mm x 20mm x 100mm (scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.001 from base dimensions -10 to 10 in x, -10 to 10 in z, and 0 to 100 in y direction). Use a structured hexahedral mesh with 41x41x100 cells providing uniform grid resolution. All boundaries are designated as 'walls' with no-slip velocity conditions (fixedValue uniform (0 0 0)), zeroGradient pressure and temperature boundary conditions, and appropriate wall functions for turbulence (epsilonWallFunction, kqRWallFunction, nutkWallFunction, alphatWallFunction). Initialize the domain with uniform conditions: pressure 5e+06 Pa, temperature 800 K, zero velocity, turbulent kinetic energy 1 m²/s², turbulent dissipation rate 90 m²/s³, nitrogen mass fraction 0.766, oxygen mass fraction 0.234, and zero for other species. Apply gravity acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in the y-direction. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 2 correctors, no non-orthogonal correctors, momentum predictor enabled, and transonic set to false. Employ k-epsilon RAS turbulence model with PaSR combustion model (Cmix = 1.0) and ODE chemistry solver with seulex method. Run simulation from time 0 to 0.01 seconds with adaptive timestep starting at 2.5e-06 seconds, maximum Courant number 0.1, and output results every 5e-05 seconds using binary format.

Conduct a reacting combustion simulation using reactingFoam solver with Lagrangian particle tracking for coal and limestone clouds. The domain is a 2D L-shaped combustion chamber with dimensions: main section 0.5m x 0.5m, narrow inlet section 0.05m x 0.5m, and narrow outlet section 0.05m x 0.5m, with thickness 0.1m (convertToMeters 1.0). Use a structured mesh with 5x50x1 cells in the inlet, 40x50x1 cells in the main chamber, and 5x50x1 cells in the outlet. Initialize with air composition (N2=0.77, O2=0.23) at 400K temperature and 100000 Pa pressure, with zero initial velocity throughout the domain. Apply noSlip boundary conditions on all walls (top, bottom, walls), symmetryPlane on the symmetry face, and empty on frontAndBack faces for 2D simulation. Set wall temperatures to fixedValue 400K with zeroGradient for all species concentrations. Use k-epsilon RAS turbulence model with initial k=37.5 m²/s² and epsilon=5390.5 m²/s³. Include radiation modeling with P1 model, buoyancy forces with gravity -9.81 m/s² in y-direction, and PaSR combustion model. Position coal particles at 27 locations between y=0.5-0.7m and x=0.005-0.045m, limestone particles at 18 locations between y=0.45-0.55m and x=0.0075-0.0475m, all at z=0.05m. Apply ignition constraint at sphere center (0.125, 0.375, 0.05) with 0.005m radius, heating to 2000K from t=0.1s to t=0.5s. Run simulation from t=0 to t=0.5s with initial timestep 0.0001s, adaptive timestepping with maxCo=1.0, and output every 0.0025s using PIMPLE algorithm with 3 correctors and transonic formulation.

Conduct a reacting flow simulation using reactingFoam solver with Lagrangian particle tracking in a vertical channel geometry. The domain features symmetry planes at front and back boundaries, with two separate inlet patches (inletCentral and inletSides), outlet, and wall boundaries. Set inletCentral with mass flow rate of 0.00379 kg/s at 573 K temperature, and inletSides with mass flow rate of 0.00832 kg/s at 473 K temperature, both using turbulent boundary layer velocity profiles. Apply fixed pressure of 100000 Pa at outlet with inletOutlet conditions for other variables, and no-slip conditions at walls with zero gradient for pressure and temperature. Initialize the domain with uniform pressure of 100000 Pa, temperature of 473 K, and species mass fractions of 0.99 for air and 0.01 for H2O. Use k-omega SST turbulence model with turbulent intensity of 5% and mixing length of 0.007 m at inlets. Employ PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 2 correctors, adaptive time stepping with maximum Courant number of 2.5 and maximum timestep of 1 second. Run simulation from time 0 to 300 seconds with output every 10 timesteps, using local Euler time scheme and upwind divergence schemes for convective terms. Include buoyancy forces with gravity vector (0, -9.81, 0) m/s² and Lagrangian cloud tracking with particle diameter, velocity, and temperature fields monitored.

Conduct a reacting flow Lagrangian particle simulation using reactingFoam solver in a cubic box domain with dimensions 1x1x0.1 units scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.1 (resulting in actual dimensions of 0.1x0.1x0.01 meters). Use a 5x5x5 mesh grid with PIMPLE algorithm (2 correctors, 0 non-orthogonal correctors). Set boundary conditions as follows: inlet with fixed velocity of (0, 1e-8, 0) m/s and fixed temperature of 473K, outlet with zero gradient velocity and fixed pressure of 100000 Pa, walls with no-slip velocity condition and zero gradient temperature, and symmetry planes for front and back faces. Initialize the domain with air mass fraction of 0.99, H2O mass fraction of 0.01, uniform temperature of 473K, and uniform pressure of 100000 Pa, with initial velocity field at rest. Include Lagrangian particle cloud with initial particle position at (0.05, 0.05, 0.005) meters. Configure radiation modeling using Marshak boundary conditions with emissivity of 1.0 at walls and inlet. Set simulation time parameters: start time 0, end time 0.5 seconds, initial timestep 1e-3 seconds with adjustable timestepping enabled (maxCo=5, maxDeltaT=1e-3), and output interval every 0.1 seconds. Use laminar flow model with buoyancy forces disabled (gravity set to zero), multicomponent mixture thermodynamics with perfectGas equation of state, and include species transport for air and H2O with combustion model set to none.

Conduct a steady-state reacting flow simulation using reactingFoam solver with Lagrangian particle tracking in a vertical channel geometry. The domain features symmetry planes at front and back boundaries, with two separate inlet regions (inletCentral and inletSides), an outlet, and wall boundaries. Set inletCentral boundary conditions with flowRateInletVelocity at mass flow rate of 0.00379 kg/s and temperature of 573K, while inletSides uses mass flow rate of 0.00832 kg/s at 473K temperature. Apply pressureInletOutletVelocity at outlet with totalPressure boundary condition at 100000 Pa, and noSlip conditions on walls with zeroGradient temperature. Initialize the domain with uniform pressure of 100000 Pa, temperature of 473K, and species mass fractions of 0.99 for air and 0.01 for H2O. Use k-omega SST turbulence model with turbulent intensity of 5% and mixing length of 0.007m at inlets. Configure PIMPLE algorithm with 1 corrector and 0 non-orthogonal correctors, applying relaxation factors of 0.3 for pressure and 0.7 for velocity and enthalpy. Set simulation time from 0 to 500 seconds with timestep of 1 second, outputting results every 20 timesteps. Include buoyancy force with gravity of -9.81 m/s² in y-direction, enable Lagrangian cloud tracking, and use heRhoThermo with multiComponentMixture for combustible gas mixture with perfectGas equation of state.

Perform a 0D chemical kinetics combustion simulation using chemFoam solver to model the auto-ignition of n-heptane (NC7H16) in air. The simulation represents a homogeneous reactor with initial conditions of 0.090909 mole fraction n-heptane, 1.0 mole fraction oxygen, and 3.76 mole fraction nitrogen at an initial pressure of 5.06625e+06 Pa and temperature of 800 K. Use adaptive time stepping starting with deltaT of 1e-07 seconds with maximum allowed timestep of 1e-03 seconds, running from startTime 0 to endTime 0.001 seconds with output intervals every 5e-5 seconds. The thermodynamic model employs heRhoThermo with multiComponentMixture using Sutherland transport properties, JANAF thermodynamic data, sensible enthalpy formulation, and perfect gas equation of state with N2 as the default species. Chemistry is enabled with ODE solver using seulex method with absolute tolerance of 1e-12 and relative tolerance of 1e-1, and initial chemical timestep of 1e-7 seconds. Species transport equations are solved using PBiCGStab solver with DILU preconditioner and tolerance of 1e-12.

Perform a zero-dimensional chemical kinetics simulation using chemFoam solver to analyze hydrogen combustion chemistry. The simulation models a homogeneous reactor with initial conditions of H2, N2, and O2 species at molar fractions of 1, 3.76, and 1 respectively, representing a stoichiometric hydrogen-air mixture at initial pressure of 202650 Pa and temperature of 1000 K. Use heRhoThermo with multiComponentMixture, sutherland transport properties, janaf thermodynamics, sensibleEnthalpy energy formulation, and perfectGas equation of state with N2 as the default species. The chemistry solver uses ODE integration with seulex solver, absolute tolerance of 1e-12, relative tolerance of 1e-1, and initial chemical timestep of 1e-7. Run the simulation from time 0 to 0.001 seconds with adaptive timestepping starting at 1e-05 seconds and maximum timestep of 1 second, outputting results every 5e-04 seconds using PBiCGStab solver with DILU preconditioner for species transport equations.

do a homogeneous chemical reactor simulation using chemFoam solver to study the combustion of iso-octane (IC8H18) in air. The simulation represents a 0-dimensional reactor (single cell) with initial conditions of 800 K temperature and 5.06625e+06 Pa pressure. The initial mixture composition is specified on a mole fraction basis with IC8H18 at 0.08, N2 at 3.76, and O2 at 1.0. Use heRhoThermo with multiComponentMixture, sutherland transport properties, janaf thermodynamics, sensibleEnthalpy energy formulation, and perfectGas equation of state with N2 as the default species. Enable chemistry with ode solver using seulex method with absolute tolerance of 1e-12 and relative tolerance of 1e-1. Set initial chemical timestep to 1e-07 seconds with adaptive timestepping enabled, maximum timestep of 1e-05 seconds, and run from time 0 to 0.01 seconds. Configure species transport equations to use PBiCGStab solver with DILU preconditioner and tolerance of 1e-12. Output results every 5e-4 seconds using adjustableRunTime write control and Euler temporal discretization scheme.

Perform a chemical kinetics simulation of isooctane (IC8H18) combustion using chemFoam solver with TDAC (Tabulation of Dynamic Adaptive Chemistry) method. The simulation models a homogeneous reactor with initial conditions of 800 K temperature and 5.06625e+06 Pa pressure, containing a stoichiometric mixture with mole fractions of 0.08 IC8H18, 1.0 O2, and 3.76 N2. Use heRhoThermo with multiComponentMixture, perfectGas equation of state, Sutherland transport model, and JANAF thermodynamic properties. Configure chemistry solver with ODE integration using seulex method with absolute tolerance of 1e-12 and relative tolerance of 1e-1, initial chemical timestep of 1e-07, and species reduction focusing on CO, IC8H18, and HO2. Set adaptive timestepping with initial timestep of 1e-07, maximum timestep of 1e-05, simulation end time of 0.01 seconds, and output every 5e-4 seconds. Use Euler temporal discretization scheme and PBiCGStab solver with DILU preconditioner and tolerance of 1e-12 for species transport equations.

Conduct a zero-dimensional chemical kinetics simulation using chemFoam solver to analyze combustion chemistry of a methane-air mixture. The simulation is a homogeneous reactor problem with initial conditions of 50% CH4, 37.6% N2, and 10% O2 by mole fraction at an initial pressure of 1.36789e+06 Pa and temperature of 1000 K. Use a perfectGas equation of state with multiComponentMixture, sutherland transport properties, and janaf thermodynamic data. Set the chemistry solver to ode with seulex integration method, absolute tolerance of 1e-12, relative tolerance of 1e-1, and initial chemical timestep of 1e-7. Configure the simulation to run from time 0 to 0.07 seconds with adaptive timestepping starting at 1e-05 seconds and maximum timestep of 1e-4 seconds. Use PBiCGStab solver with DILU preconditioner for species transport equations with tolerance of 1e-12. Output results every 0.01 seconds using adjustable runtime control and Euler temporal discretization scheme.

Perform a Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) combustion analysis of an internal combustion engine using XiFoam solver with k-epsilon turbulence model. The simulation models a layered engine geometry with bore diameter of 0.092m, stroke length of 0.08423m, connecting rod length of 0.147m, and clearance of 0.00115m. The domain includes three main boundaries: piston (with movingWallVelocity boundary condition and fixed temperature of 433K), liner (noSlip walls at 373K), and cylinderHead (noSlip walls at 383K). Initialize the domain with uniform pressure of 100000 Pa, temperature of 373K, turbulent kinetic energy of 4 m²/s², turbulent dissipation rate of 450 m²/s³, fuel fraction (ft) of 0.0623, flame wrinkling factor (Xi) of 1, and laminar flame speed (Su) of 0.4 m/s. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 2 correctors and 1 non-orthogonal corrector. Set engine RPM to 1500 with user time functionality. Run simulation from -180 to 60 crank angle degrees with initial timestep of 0.25 degrees, switching to 0.025 degrees after -15 degrees crank angle. Output results every 5 time units with maximum Courant number of 0.2.

Perform a homogeneous combustion simulation using XiFoam solver with RAS turbulence modeling and Launder-Sharma k-epsilon model. The domain is a 2D rectangular geometry with dimensions 70 x 35 x 1 units scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.001 (making it 70mm x 35mm x 1mm). Use a structured mesh with 70 x 35 x 1 cells in x, y, and z directions respectively. All boundaries (left, right, top, bottom) are set as symmetryPlane boundary conditions, while frontAndBack faces are empty for 2D simulation. Initialize the domain with uniform conditions: velocity U = (0,0,0) m/s, pressure p = 118000 Pa, temperature T = 300 K, unburnt temperature Tu = 300 K, laminar flame speed Su = 0.434 m/s, mixture fraction ft = 0.06, regress variable b = 1, flame wrinkling factor Xi = 1, turbulent kinetic energy k = 1.5 m²/s², turbulent dissipation rate epsilon = 375 m²/s³, and zero values for turbulent viscosity nut and fuel mass fraction fu. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 2 outer correctors, 1 corrector, and 0 non-orthogonal correctors.
