Set simulation time from 0 to 0.005 seconds with timestep of 5e-06 seconds, outputting results every 20 timesteps. Configure the mixture as homogeneous with stoichiometric air-fuel mass ratio of 15.675, reactant molecular weight of 29.4649, product molecular weight of 28.3233, and transport properties with viscosity mu = 1e-5 and Prandtl number Pr = 1.

Perform a premixed combustion flame propagation simulation using PDRFoam solver with obstacles and pressure relief system. The domain contains blocked regions defined by boxes at coordinates (2.4,2.4,0) to (3,3,1) and (0,0,0) to (0.6,0.6,1), with blocked faces at (1,1,0.99) to (2,2,1), and a pressure relief baffle system with cyclic boundary conditions at (1.0,1.99,0) to (2.0,2.09,0.6). Use k-epsilon turbulence model with PDRkEpsilon variant including drag effects (Csu=0.5, Csk=0.05) and transport-based flame wrinkling model with instability correlation. Initialize propane-air mixture with equivalence ratio ft=0.0623, unburned temperature Tu=300K, burned gas marker b=1, flame wrinkling factor Xi=1, laminar flame speed Su=0.5 m/s, turbulent kinetic energy k=1.5 m²/s², and dissipation rate epsilon=0.1 m²/s³. Set pressure to 100000 Pa with waveTransmissive boundary conditions at outer boundaries (gamma=1.3), zeroGradient conditions at ground and blocked faces, and activePressureForceBaffleVelocity at baffle wall with opening time 0.01s and threshold 8000 Pa. Place ignition source at location (1.5,1.5,0.5) with diameter 0.1m starting at 1e-05s for duration 0.05s with strength 60. Run simulation from 0 to 0.2s with adaptive timestep (initial 5e-06s, maxCo=0.2) using PIMPLE algorithm with 2 correctors, and output results every 0.01s.

Perform a compressible multiphase ball valve simulation using compressibleInterFoam solver with RAS turbulence modeling. The domain represents a ball valve geometry with a rotating spherical ball element that oscillates between open and closed positions according to a time-dependent motion profile. The inlet boundary uses pressureInletOutletVelocity with an initial velocity of 6 m/s in the x-direction and prghTotalPressure of 1.18e5 Pa, while the lowerOutlet and upperOutlet boundaries employ prghEntrainmentPressure at 1e5 Pa with pressureInletOutletVelocity conditions. Wall boundaries have movingWallVelocity with no-slip conditions and fixedFluxPressure. The simulation involves water (alpha.water = 1 initially throughout domain) and vapor phases with water at 300 K temperature, using realizableKE and kOmegaSST turbulence models with turbulent intensity of 5% and mixing length of 0.1 m. The ball valve rotates with omega = -39.27 rad/s following a prescribed motion table from 0 to 0.1 seconds, transitioning from closed (0-0.02s) to open (0.04-0.06s) and back to closed (0.08-0.1s). Use PIMPLE algorithm with 3 outer correctors, 1 corrector, and momentum predictor disabled. Run simulation from 0 to 0.1 seconds with adaptive timestep (deltaT = 1e-5, maxCo = 0.25, maxAlphaCo = 0.25) and output results every 1e-3 seconds. Water properties include kinematic viscosity nu = 1e-05 m²/s, and the system includes phase change modeling with SchnerrSauer cavitation model at saturation pressure pSat = 2364 Pa.

Perform a compressible multiphase dam break simulation using compressibleInterFoam solver with RAS k-epsilon turbulence modeling. The domain is a 2D rectangular tank where water initially occupies a rectangular region from 0 ≤ x ≤ 0.1461 and 0 ≤ y ≤ 0.292, with air filling the remaining space above and to the right of the water column. Apply no-slip boundary conditions on the leftWall, rightWall, and lowerWall surfaces, while the atmosphere boundary uses pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocity, prghTotalPressure for pressure, and inletOutlet conditions for turbulence parameters. Set initial pressure p_rgh to 1e5 Pa, temperature to 300 K for both phases, and turbulence parameters k=0.1 m²/s², epsilon=0.1 m²/s³, and omega=11.1 s⁻¹. Use water properties with density 1000 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1e-06 m²/s, air properties with density 1 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1.48e-05 m²/s, gravitational acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in y-direction, and surface tension coefficient of 0.07 N/m. Run the simulation from time 0 to 1 second with initial timestep 0.001 seconds, adaptive time stepping enabled with maxCo=1 and maxAlphaCo=1, and output results every 0.05 seconds using PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 3 pressure correctors, and interface compression using vanLeer scheme with compression factor 1.

Perform a compressible two-phase multiphase simulation using compressibleInterFoam solver to model liquid climbing behavior on a rotating rod. The domain is an axisymmetric cylindrical geometry with dimensions: inner radius (rod) of 6.35 units, outer radius (vessel) of 152.25 units, and total height of 110 units, scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.001 (making actual dimensions 6.35mm, 152.25mm, and 110mm respectively). Use an 80x80x1 structured mesh with non-uniform grading in radial and vertical directions. The rod boundary has rotatingWallVelocity with rotation axis (0 1 0), origin at (0 0 0), and angular velocity of 13.2 rad/s, while the vessel walls have noSlip boundary conditions. The atmosphere boundary uses pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocity, prghTotalPressure for pressure, and inletOutlet for other fields. Initially, liquid (alpha.liquid = 1) occupies the region 0 ≤ x ≤ 1, 0 ≤ y ≤ 0.0771, -1 ≤ z ≤ 1, with the remaining domain filled with air (alpha.liquid = 0). Physical properties include liquid density of 890 kg/m³, liquid viscosity of 1.64e-3 m²/s, air density of 1.2 kg/m³, air viscosity of 1.533e-5 m²/s, surface tension of 0.0309 N/m, and gravity of -9.81 m/s² in y-direction. The liquid phase uses Maxwell viscoelastic model with nuM = 0.01476 and lambda = 0.018225. Run simulation from time 0 to 25 seconds with initial timestep of 1e-3 seconds, adjustable timestep with maxCo = 1, maxAlphaCo = 1, and output results every 0.5 seconds using PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector and 2 pressure correctors.

Conduct a compressible multiphase simulation using compressibleInterFoam solver for a 2D depth charge explosion scenario. The domain is a rectangular channel with dimensions 1 meter wide by 2 meters tall and 0.2 meters thick (scaled by convertToMeters factor of 1), meshed with 80x160x1 cells. Initially, water (alpha.water = 1) fills the entire domain at pressure 1e5 Pa and temperature 300 K, except for a spherical explosive charge centered at (0.5, 0.5, 0) with radius 0.1 meters containing high-pressure air at 1e6 Pa and temperature 578 K (alpha.water = 0), and air above y=1 meter (alpha.water = 0). Apply no-slip boundary conditions on all walls with zeroGradient for alpha.water and temperature, fixedFluxPressure for p_rgh, and empty conditions for front and back faces. Use water properties with liquid thermodynamics and air as perfect gas with molecular weight 28.9, Cp 1007 J/kg-K, dynamic viscosity 1.84e-05 Pa-s, and Prandtl number 0.7. Include gravity acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in y-direction and surface tension effects between phases. Run laminar simulation from time 0 to 0.5 seconds with adaptive timestep starting at 0.0001 seconds, maximum Courant numbers of 0.5 for both velocity and alpha fields, and output results every 0.01 seconds using adjustable runtime control.

Perform a compressible multiphase underwater explosion simulation using compressibleInterFoam solver. The domain is a 3D rectangular box with dimensions 1x2x1 meters (convertToMeters 1) meshed with 80x160x80 cells. Initialize water throughout the domain (alpha.water = 1) at atmospheric pressure (1e5 Pa) and temperature 300K, except for a spherical explosive charge centered at (0.5, 0.5, 0.5) with radius 0.1 meters containing high-pressure gas (1e6 Pa) at elevated temperature (578K) with alpha.water = 0, and an air region above y=1 with alpha.water = 0. Apply no-slip boundary conditions for velocity and fixedFluxPressure for p_rgh on all walls, with zeroGradient for alpha.water and temperature. Set gravity to -9.81 m/s² in y-direction, surface tension coefficient to 0.07 N/m, and use laminar flow with water properties (molecular weight 18.0, viscosity 3.645e-4 Pa·s, Cv 4195 J/kg·K) and air properties (molecular weight 28.9, viscosity 1.84e-05 Pa·s, Cp 1007 J/kg·K). Run simulation from 0 to 0.5 seconds with adaptive timestep (initial 0.0001s, maxCo 0.5, maxAlphaCo 0.5) and output every 0.01 seconds using Euler temporal discretization and interface compression schemes for phase capturing.

Perform a compressible multiphase film flow simulation using compressibleInterFoam solver with VoF surface film coupling. The domain is a 2D rectangular geometry with dimensions 50mm width by 100mm height scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.001, creating a thin film region. Use an 80x80x1 cell mesh with graded spacing (10x expansion ratio in width direction). Initialize liquid phase (alpha.liquid = 1) in the lower region from 0≤y≤0.08 and 0≤x≤1, with air filling the remaining domain. Set boundary conditions: plate wall (left boundary) with noSlip velocity and zeroGradient for alpha and temperature, bottom inlet with flowRateOutletVelocity of 2e-6 m³/s, vessel wall (right boundary) as symmetryPlane, and atmosphere (top boundary) with pressureInletOutletVelocity and inletOutlet conditions. Use initial pressure of 1e5 Pa, temperature of 300K, and gravity of -9.81 m/s² in y-direction. Configure liquid properties as water with surface tension coefficient of 0.0309 N/m, air density of 1.2 kg/m³ with dynamic viscosity of 1.84e-05 Pa·s. Apply PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 2 correctors, and no momentum predictor. Run simulation from time 0 to 5 seconds with timestep of 1e-3 seconds, outputting results every 0.1 seconds using laminar flow model and surface film transfer with VoFPatchTransfer model.

Conduct a 2D compressible multiphase sloshing tank simulation using compressibleInterFoam solver with dynamic mesh motion. The domain represents a tank with walls boundary and empty front/back faces for 2D simulation. Initialize water phase (alpha.water = 1) in the lower region from z = -100 to z = 0 and air phase (alpha.water = 0) in the upper region using setFieldsDict box specification. Apply movingWallVelocity boundary condition to walls with SDA (Ship Design and Analysis) motion function including heave amplitude of 3.79, sway amplitude of 2.34, roll amplitude range of 0.10472 to 0.22654, and period parameters Tp = 13.93 and Tpn = 11.93. Set initial temperature to 300 K for both phases, initial pressure to 1e6 Pa, and zero initial velocity. Use water properties with density 998.2 kg/m³, viscosity 1e-06 m²/s, and air properties with density 1 kg/m³, viscosity 1.48e-05 m²/s. Apply gravity acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in z-direction with zero surface tension. Run simulation from time 0 to 40 seconds with initial timestep of 0.0001 seconds, adaptive timestepping enabled with maximum Courant numbers maxCo = 0.5 and maxAlphaCo = 0.5, and output results every 0.05 seconds. Use Euler time discretization, vanLeer schemes for convection terms with interface compression for alpha transport, and include pressure probes at locations (0, 9.95, 19.77) and (0, -9.95, 19.77) with wall pressure monitoring.

Perform a multiphase mixing vessel simulation using driftFluxFoam solver with Multiple Reference Frame (MRF) capabilities. The domain is a 2D cylindrical mixer vessel geometry with a rotating impeller zone (rotor) and stationary outer walls (stator), with front and back faces designated as empty for 2D flow characteristics. The MRF rotor zone rotates about the z-axis at origin (0,0,0) with angular velocity of 6.2831853 rad/s (1 rpm). Initial phase distribution includes water with volume fraction alpha.water = 0.7, sludge with alpha.sludge = 0.001, oil with alpha.oil = 0.1, mercury with alpha.mercury = 0.1, and air with alpha.air = 0.1. Boundary conditions specify fixedValue velocity of (0,0,0) m/s at the rotor surface, noSlip conditions at the stator walls, zeroGradient for all phase volume fractions and pressure at both rotor and stator surfaces, and fixedFluxPressure for p_rgh. Physical properties include water with density 996 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1.7871e-06 m²/s, sludge with density 1996 kg/m³ using BinghamPlastic viscosity model, and initial temperatures of 300 K for all phases. Use RAS turbulence modeling with buoyantKEpsilon model, initial turbulent kinetic energy k = 0.01 m²/s² and dissipation rate epsilon = 0.007 m²/s³. The simulation runs from time 0 to 10 seconds with initial timestep of 1e-3 seconds, adjustable timestep enabled with maximum Courant number of 1, and results output every 0.25 seconds using PIMPLE algorithm with 3 correctors and no momentum predictor.

Perform a multiphase drift-flux simulation using driftFluxFoam solver to model sludge settling in a horizontal channel. The domain is a 2D channel with dimensions 8.65 units length, 1 unit height, and 0.2 units thickness (effectively 2D with empty frontAndBack boundaries), using convertToMeters factor of 1. The mesh consists of two blocks: a lower section (200x4x1 cells) from y=0 to y=0.1, and an upper section (200x36x1 cells) from y=0.1 to y=1. Set inlet boundary conditions with fixed velocity of 0.0191 m/s in x-direction, fixed sludge volume fraction alpha.sludge of 0.001, fixed turbulent kinetic energy k of 0.00015 m²/s², and fixed turbulent dissipation rate epsilon of 1.50919e-06 m²/s³. Configure outlet with pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocity, inletOutlet for alpha.sludge, k, and epsilon, and fixed pressure p_rgh of 0. Apply no-slip conditions on bottomWall and endWall, slip conditions on top boundary. Use water phase properties with density 996 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1.7871e-06 m²/s, and sludge phase with density 1996 kg/m³ and BinghamPlastic viscosity model (BinghamCoeff 0.0005966, BinghamExponent 1050.8, muMax 10). Implement buoyantKEpsilon RAS turbulence model with gravity vector (0, -9.81, 0) m/s². Configure simple relative velocity model with Vc=2.241e-4, a=285.84, a1=0.1. Run simulation from time 0 to 6400 seconds with initial timestep 0.1 seconds, adjustable timestep enabled (maxCo=5, maxDeltaT=1), using PIMPLE algorithm with 3 correctors and no momentum predictor, outputting results every 50 seconds.

Do a 3D multiphase tank sedimentation simulation using driftFluxFoam solver with RAS turbulence modeling. The simulation involves two phases: water (continuous phase) with density 1000 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1.78e-06 m²/s, and sludge (dispersed phase) with density 1042 kg/m³ using BinghamPlastic viscosity model with coefficients coeff=0.00023143, exponent=0.17926, BinghamCoeff=7.845e-07, BinghamExponent=95.25, and muMax=10. Apply gravity acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in the y-direction. Set inlet boundary (INLE1) with fixed sludge volume fraction of 0.002, turbulent kinetic energy k=0.000259 m²/s², and turbulent dissipation rate epsilon=1.973e-07 m²/s³. Configure multiple outlet boundaries (OUTL9, OUTL10, OUTL11, OUTL12) with zeroGradient conditions and one outlet (OUTL15) with inletOutlet boundary conditions. Apply slip boundary conditions at symmetry plane (SYMP3) and wall functions (epsilonWallFunction, kqRWallFunction, nutkWallFunction) for all wall patches (WALL6, WALL7, WALL8, WALL61-70). Use buoyantKEpsilon turbulence model with Cg coefficient of 0.85. Implement PIMPLE algorithm with 3 correctors, no momentum predictor, and simple relative velocity model with parameters Vc=2.241e-4, a=8.84, a1=0.1. Run simulation from time 0 to 8000 seconds with timestep of 0.5 seconds, outputting results every 50 seconds using binary format.

Perform a Large Eddy Simulation (LES) cavitating flow analysis using cavitatingFoam solver for a 3D throttle geometry. The simulation models multiphase flow with water and vapor phases, where water has density 830 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 7.831e-06 m²/s, and vapor has density 0.14 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 4.252e-05 m²/s. Apply totalPressure boundary condition at the inlet with p0 = 300e5 Pa, fixedValue pressure at the outlet of 100e5 Pa, noSlip conditions on walls and frontBack surfaces, and zeroGradient velocity conditions at inlet and outlet. Initialize the domain with uniform pressure 300e5 Pa, zero velocity field, turbulent kinetic energy of 10 m²/s², and zero vapor fraction throughout. Use LES turbulence modeling with kEqn model and smooth delta function. Set saturation pressure pSat = 4500 Pa with liquid saturation density rholSat = 830 kg/m³. Run simulation from time 0 to 0.0001 s with adaptive timestep starting at 1e-08 s, maintaining maxCo = 0.5 and maxAcousticCo = 50. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 3 correctors and output results every 5e-06 s. Configure turbulent intensity of 0.05 at inlet with kqRWallFunction for walls and nutUSpaldingWallFunction for turbulent viscosity boundaries.

Perform a multiphase cavitating flow simulation using cavitatingFoam solver with LES turbulence modeling employing the kEqn model. The domain represents a throttle geometry with inlet conditions of total pressure 300e5 Pa, outlet fixed pressure 100e5 Pa, no-slip walls, and empty frontBack boundaries for 2D simulation. Set initial density to 845 kg/m³ at inlet and 835 kg/m³ at outlet with vapor fraction initially zero throughout the domain. Use water properties with kinematic viscosity 7.831e-06 m²/s and density 830 kg/m³, and vapor properties with kinematic viscosity 4.252e-05 m²/s and density 0.14 kg/m³. Configure thermodynamic properties with saturation pressure 4500 Pa, liquid compressibility 5e-07 m²/s², vapor compressibility 2.5e-06 m²/s², and saturated liquid density 830 kg/m³. Apply PIMPLE algorithm with 3 correctors and 0 non-orthogonal correctors, using adjustable time stepping with initial timestep 1e-08 s, maximum Courant number 0.5, maximum acoustic Courant number 50, simulation end time 0.002 s, and output interval 0.0001 s. Initialize turbulent kinetic energy to 10 m²/s² with 5% turbulence intensity at inlet and omega to 77200 s⁻¹ with mixing length 0.0005 m at inlet, using wall functions for near-wall treatment.

Conduct a multiphase bubble column simulation using multiphaseEulerFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm. The domain is a rectangular column with dimensions 0.15m width × 1.0m height × 0.1m depth (convertToMeters = 1), meshed with 25×75×1 cells. Initially, water occupies the region 0≤x≤0.15, 0≤y≤0.701, 0≤z≤0.1 with air above it. At the inlet (bottom), specify equal volume fractions of air and water (alpha.air = 0.5, alpha.water = 0.5) with air velocity of 0.1 m/s in y-direction and water velocity of 0 m/s. The outlet (top) uses inletOutlet boundary conditions with pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocities. Walls have no-slip conditions (U = 0) and zeroGradient for volume fractions. Air properties include molecular weight 28.9 g/mol, Cp = 1007 J/kg·K, dynamic viscosity 1.84e-05 Pa·s, and Prandtl number 0.7 using perfectGas equation of state. Water properties include molecular weight 18 g/mol, Cv = 4195 J/kg·K, dynamic viscosity 3.645e-4 Pa·s, Prandtl number 2.289, and rPolynomial equation of state. Set air temperature to 300K and water temperature to 350K. Use gravity acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in y-direction. Apply turbulence modeling with k = 3.75e-5 m²/s² and epsilon = 1.5e-4 m²/s³ for both phases. Run simulation from time 0 to 100 seconds with timestep 0.005s, outputting results every 1 second. Use PIMPLE with 3 outer correctors, 1 corrector, and 0 non-orthogonal correctors, with pressure limiting constraint minimum 1e4 Pa.

Conduct a multiphase evaporating reacting bubble column simulation using multiphaseEulerFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm (5 outer correctors, 1 corrector, 0 non-orthogonal correctors). The domain is a rectangular column with dimensions 0.15m width × 1.0m height × 0.1m depth using convertToMeters factor of 1, meshed with 25×75×1 cells. Initially, liquid water occupies the region 0≤x≤0.15, 0≤y≤0.501, 0≤z≤0.1 with alpha.liquid=0.99 and alpha.gas=0.01, while the upper region contains gas with alpha.gas=1.0. Boundary conditions specify: inlet (bottom) with fixed gas velocity (0,0.1,0) m/s, liquid velocity (0,0,0) m/s, alpha.gas=0.5, alpha.liquid=0.5, gas temperature 400K, and gas composition AIR=0.9, CO=0.1; outlet (top) with inletOutlet conditions and prghPressure; walls with noSlip velocity and zeroGradient for scalars. The simulation uses RAS k-epsilon turbulence model for gas phase (k=3.75e-5, epsilon=1.5e-4) and laminar model for liquid phase. Initial pressure is 10e5 Pa, both phases at 400K temperature. Gas phase includes multicomponent mixture (AIR, CO, H2O, Ydefault) with PaSR combustion model and EulerImplicit chemistry solver. Run from time 0 to 100 seconds with timestep 0.001s, outputting results every 1 second with maxCo=0.5.

Perform a multiphase Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) using multiphaseEulerFoam solver for a liquid-gas flow system. The domain is a wedge-shaped axisymmetric geometry with front and back boundaries as wedge patches. The liquid phase has an initial volume fraction of 0.9433 and gas phase 0.0567, both with uniform inlet velocity of 0.916 m/s in the x-direction and initial temperature of 303 K. Boundary conditions include: mapped inlet conditions for velocities, volume fractions, and turbulence quantities with set averages; inletOutlet outlet conditions; no-slip walls for liquid velocity, slip walls for gas velocity, and zeroGradient walls for volume fractions; fixedFluxPressure for inlet and walls with prghPressure at outlet set to 1e5 Pa. Physical properties specify liquid density of 995.7 kg/m³ with viscosity 7.99e-04 Pa·s and gas density of 1.17 kg/m³ with viscosity 1.868e-05 Pa·s. Use kOmegaSSTSato turbulence model for liquid phase with initial k=0.01 m²/s², omega=0.01 s⁻¹, epsilon=0.001 m²/s³, and laminar model for gas phase. Run simulation from time 0 to 2.0 seconds with initial timestep of 0.001 seconds, adjustable timestep enabled with maxCo=0.25, and output every 1 second using PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector and 1 corrector step.

Conduct a multiphase wall boiling simulation using multiphaseEulerFoam solver with RAS turbulence modeling. The domain is a 2D axisymmetric channel with length 3.5 m and radius 0.0096 m, meshed with 350x40x1 cells (convertToMeters factor of 1). The simulation models liquid-gas phase change with initial liquid temperature of 341.67 K, gas temperature of 341.65 K, and system pressure of 2.62e6 Pa. Boundary conditions include: inlet with mapped boundary conditions for both phases with liquid velocity of 1.75175 m/s and zero gas velocity, outlet with inletOutlet/pressureInletOutletVelocity conditions, heated wall with fixedMultiPhaseHeatFlux for liquid phase and copiedFixedValue temperature coupling for gas phase, and wedge boundaries for front/back faces to maintain 2D axisymmetric geometry. The liquid phase uses kOmegaSSTSato turbulence model with initial k=0.01 m²/s², omega=0.01 s⁻¹, and epsilon=0.001 m²/s³, while gas phase uses laminar flow. Initial volume fraction is alpha.liquid=1 and alpha.gas=0 throughout the domain. Wall boiling parameters include Lavieville partitioning model with alphaCrit=0.2, LemmertChawla nucleation site model, TolubinskiKostanchuk departure diameter model, and KocamustafaogullariIshii departure frequency model. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 1 corrector, and 1 energy corrector, with Euler time discretization and linearUpwind divergence schemes for momentum and energy transport.

Conduct a multiphase fluidized bed simulation using multiphaseEulerFoam solver with RAS turbulence modeling. The domain is a 2D rectangular channel with dimensions 0.15m width × 1m height × 0.02m depth (effectively 2D with empty frontAndBackPlanes), using a convertToMeters factor of 1. Use a structured mesh of 30×200×1 cells in x, y, and z directions respectively. Initialize the particle bed region from 0≤x≤0.15, 0≤y≤0.5 with air volume fraction of 0.45 and particle volume fraction of 0.55, while the upper region has air volume fraction of 1.0. Set inlet boundary conditions with interstitialInletVelocity of (0 0.25 0) m/s for air, fixed air temperature of 300K, turbulent kinetic energy k=1 m²/s², dissipation rate epsilon=10 m²/s³, and fixedFluxPressure for p_rgh. Apply pressureInletOutletVelocity at outlet with inletOutlet conditions for temperature (300K), k, and epsilon, plus prghPressure boundary condition. Use noSlip velocity conditions and zeroGradient temperature on walls. Configure air as perfect gas with molecular weight 28.9 kg/kmol, Cp=1007 J/kg·K, dynamic viscosity 1.84e-05 Pa·s, and Prandtl number 0.7, while particles have constant density 2500 kg/m³, diameter 3e-4 m, Cp=6000 J/kg·K, and molecular weight 100 kg/kmol. Apply k-epsilon turbulence model for air and kineticTheory model for particles with restitution coefficient 0.8. Set initial temperatures of 600K for both phases, pressure of 1e5 Pa, and gravity acceleration -9.81 m/s² in y-direction. Run simulation from 0 to 2 seconds with timestep 2e-4 seconds and output interval 0.01 seconds using Euler time scheme and appropriate multiphase discretization schemes.

Conduct a multiphase Eulerian bubble pipe simulation using multiphaseEulerFoam solver with RAS turbulence modeling. The domain is an axisymmetric pipe geometry with dimensions 0.025m radius, 1.0m height (from z=-0.1 to z=0.9), and convertToMeters factor of 1. Use a 30x1x200 mesh with grading factor 0.375 in radial direction. The simulation involves three phases: water (continuous phase with density 997 kg/m³, viscosity 3.645e-4 Pa·s), air1 and air2 (dispersed phases with density from perfect gas law, viscosity 1.84e-05 Pa·s). Initial conditions set water velocity at 1.6 m/s in z-direction with alpha.water=1 throughout domain, while both air phases initially have zero velocity and alpha=0. Boundary conditions include: inlet with mapped boundary conditions for all phases maintaining water velocity 1.6 m/s and temperature 300K, outlet with pressureInletOutletVelocity and inletOutlet conditions, walls with noSlip for water and slip for air phases. Include mass source injection of air1 at 6e-7 kg/s in cellZone near inlet (0≤x≤0.005, 0≤z≤0.01). Use k-omega SST Sato turbulence model for water phase and laminar model for air phases. Apply PIMPLE algorithm with 2 outer correctors, 2 correctors, gravity acceleration -9.81 m/s² in z-direction, and initial pressure 1e5 Pa.

Conduct a multiphase Eulerian-Eulerian pipe bend simulation using multiphaseEulerFoam solver with RAS turbulence modeling. The domain consists of a pipe bend geometry with inlet, outlet, and wall boundaries. The simulation models water as the continuous phase (alpha.water = 0.999) with density 997 kg/m³, dynamic viscosity 8.9e-4 Pa·s, specific heat 4181 J/kg·K, and particles as the dispersed phase (alpha.particles = 0.001) with density 1400 kg/m³ and specific heat 1000 J/kg·K. Both phases have initial temperature of 300 K. At the inlet, apply fixed velocity of (0, 0.5, 0) m/s for both phases, fixed alpha values, and fixed temperature. At the outlet, use zeroGradient conditions for velocities, alpha fields, and temperatures. Wall boundaries have noSlip condition for water velocity, slip condition for particle velocity, and zeroGradient for temperatures and alpha fields. The water phase uses RNGkEpsilon turbulence model with turbulent kinetic energy k = 0.00081 m²/s², dissipation rate epsilon = 0.00136 m²/s³, turbulence intensity 5% at inlet, and mixing length 0.02 m. Particles use phasePressure model for granular flow. Pressure field p_rgh uses fixedFluxPressure at inlet and walls, prghPressure at outlet with reference pressure 1e5 Pa. Include gravity acceleration (0, 0, -9.81) m/s². Use Euler time scheme with vanLeer for phase transport and limitedLinear schemes for momentum and scalar transport.

Perform a multiphase wall boiling simulation using multiphaseEulerFoam solver with RAS turbulence modeling. The domain is a 2D axisymmetric channel geometry with length 3.5 m and radius 0.0096 m, meshed with 350 cells in the axial direction and 40 cells in the radial direction, with convertToMeters factor of 1. The simulation models liquid-gas two-phase flow where the liquid phase initially occupies the entire domain (alpha.liquid = 1, alpha.gas = 0) with liquid inlet velocity of 1.743138395 m/s and gas velocity of 1.96244 m/s. Boundary conditions include: inlet with mapped boundary conditions for velocities and turbulence properties, outlet with inletOutlet/pressureInletOutletVelocity conditions, wall boundaries with specialized wall boiling functions including nucleation site modeling (LemmertChawla), departure diameter modeling (TolubinskiKostanchuk), and departure frequency modeling (KocamustafaogullariIshii), and wedge boundaries for axisymmetric geometry. Initial conditions specify liquid temperature of 341.67 K, gas temperature of 341.65 K, pressure of 2.62e6 Pa, turbulent kinetic energy of 0.01 m²/s², turbulent dissipation rate of 0.001 m²/s³, and interfacial area density (kappai) of 13333 m⁻¹. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 1 corrector, and 1 energy corrector, kOmegaSSTSato turbulence model for liquid phase and laminar model for gas phase, with Euler time discretization scheme and specialized wall boiling heat transfer models including alphatWallBoilingWallFunction with Lavieville partitioning model.

Perform a multiphase wall boiling simulation using multiphaseEulerFoam solver with Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) turbulence modeling. The domain is a 2D axisymmetric channel with length 3.5 meters and radius 0.0096 meters (convertToMeters = 1), meshed with 350 cells in the axial direction and 40 cells in the radial direction using grading of 0.5 in the radial direction. The simulation models liquid-gas flow with initial liquid velocity of 1.75175 m/s in the axial direction, liquid temperature of 341.67 K, gas temperature of 341.65 K, and system pressure of 2.62e6 Pa. Boundary conditions include: mapped inlet with average liquid velocity 1.75175 m/s and zero gas fraction, pressureInletOutletVelocity outlet, no-slip wall condition for liquid with slip condition for gas, and wall boiling heat transfer using alphatWallBoilingWallFunction with Lavieville partitioning model, LemmertChawla nucleation site model, TolubinskiKostanchuk departure diameter model, and KocamustafaogullariIshii departure frequency model. The liquid phase uses kOmegaSSTSato turbulence model with initial turbulent kinetic energy of 0.01 m²/s², specific dissipation rate of 0.01 s⁻¹, and turbulent viscosity of 0.0001 m²/s, while the gas phase uses laminar flow modeling. The simulation employs Euler time discretization with vanLeer schemes for phase transport and linearUpwind schemes for momentum and energy transport, and includes gravity acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in the axial direction.

Perform a multiphase wall boiling simulation using multiphaseEulerFoam solver with three phases (liquid, gas, and gas2) representing polydisperse bubble groups. The domain is a 2D axisymmetric channel with length 3.5 m and radius 0.0096 m, meshed with 350 cells in the axial direction and 40 cells in the radial direction using convertToMeters factor of 1. The liquid phase initially occupies the entire domain with velocity 1.75175 m/s in the x-direction and temperature 341.67 K, while both gas phases start with zero volume fraction. Boundary conditions include: inlet with mapped boundary conditions for all phases maintaining liquid velocity and zero gas fractions, outlet with inletOutlet conditions, wall with no-slip for liquid and slip for gas phases with specialized wall boiling heat transfer using fixedMultiPhaseHeatFlux and alphatWallBoilingWallFunction incorporating nucleation site models (LemmertChawla), departure diameter models (TolubinskiKostanchuk), and departure frequency models (KocamustafaogullariIshii). The simulation operates at pressure 2.62e6 Pa with RAS turbulence using kOmegaSSTSato model for the liquid phase and laminar flow for gas phases. Physical properties are defined using tabulated thermodynamic data for a fluid with molecular weight 120.914 g/mol, with gravity acting in the negative x-direction at -9.81 m/s². The simulation uses Euler time discretization with PIMPLE algorithm and various specialized schemes for multiphase flow including vanLeer for volume fraction transport and linearUpwind for momentum equations.

Conduct a multiphase Eulerian-Eulerian gas-solid flow simulation using multiphaseEulerFoam solver for an L-bend geometry. The domain is a 2D channel with empty frontAndBack boundaries. The gas phase (air) has density 1.2 kg/m³, viscosity 1.84e-05 Pa·s, and specific heat 1007 J/kg·K, while the solid phase has density 2480 kg/m³, particle diameter 462e-6 m, specific heat 6000 J/kg·K, and maximum packing fraction 0.65. At the inlet, specify gas volume fraction 0.7 with zero velocity, solid volume fraction 0.3 with downward velocity -0.2 m/s, temperature 300 K for both phases, turbulent kinetic energy 1e-4 m²/s², and dissipation rate 1e-3 m²/s³. Apply zero velocity no-slip conditions at walls with Johnson-Jackson particle slip model (restitution coefficient 0.2, specularity coefficient 0.1, friction coefficient 0.25). Set outlet with zero gradient for solid properties and inletOutlet for gas properties. Use RAS turbulence with k-epsilon model for gas phase and kinetic theory model for solids with Syamlal viscosity and conductivity models, SyamlalRogersOBrien pressure model, and Schaeffer frictional stress model. Apply gravity -9.81 m/s² in y-direction, GidaspowErgunWenYu drag model, and RanzMarshall heat transfer. Run simulation from time 0 to 1.9 seconds with initial timestep 1e-4, adaptive timestepping with maximum Courant number 0.1, and output results every 0.1 seconds using Euler temporal discretization and vanLeer schemes for phase fractions.

Conduct a multiphase evaporating bubble column simulation using multiphaseEulerFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm (5 outer correctors, 1 corrector, 0 non-orthogonal correctors). The domain is a rectangular column with dimensions 0.15m width × 1m height × 0.1m depth using a 25×75×1 mesh grid with convertToMeters factor of 1. Initialize the liquid phase (H2O) occupying the region 0≤x≤0.15, 0≤y≤0.501, 0≤z≤0.1 with alpha.liquid=0.99 and alpha.gas=0.01, while the remaining domain contains gas phase with alpha.gas=1 and alpha.liquid=0. Set inlet boundary conditions with alpha.liquid=0.5, alpha.gas=0.5, air.gas=0.9, CO.gas=0.1, zero velocity for liquid phase, and gas velocity of (0 0.1 0) m/s, with temperatures of 350K for both phases. Apply outlet conditions with inletOutlet type for all phases, pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocities, and prghPressure for p_rgh. Use noSlip conditions for wall velocities and zeroGradient for species and temperatures at walls. Set initial pressure to 1e5 Pa, liquid viscosity of 3.645e-4 Pa·s, and include gravity acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in y-direction. Run simulation from time 0 to 100 seconds with timestep of 0.0025s and output results every 1 second using laminar flow models for both phases with species transport including air and H2O evaporation.

Conduct a four-phase dam break simulation using multiphaseEulerFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm. The domain is a 2D rectangular geometry with dimensions 4 × 4 × 0.1 units scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.146, creating an effective domain of 0.584m × 0.584m × 0.0146m. Initially, water occupies the region 0 ≤ x ≤ 0.1461, 0 ≤ y ≤ 0.292, oil occupies 0.1461 ≤ x ≤ 0.2922, 0 ≤ y ≤ 0.292, mercury occupies 0 ≤ x ≤ 0.1461, 0 ≤ y ≤ 0.1, and air fills the remaining domain. Boundary conditions include noSlip walls for leftWall, rightWall, and lowerWall with alphaContactAngle conditions (90° contact angles between all phase pairs), pressureInletOutletVelocity at the atmosphere patch for phase velocities, inletOutlet for phase fractions at atmosphere (air inlet value 1, others 0), fixedFluxPressure for p_rgh at walls, and prghTotalPressure at atmosphere with p0 = 1e5 Pa. Physical properties: water (ρ = 1027 kg/m³, μ = 3.645e-4 Pa·s), oil (ρ = 684 kg/m³, μ = 3.76e-4 Pa·s), mercury (ρ = 13529 kg/m³, μ = 1.522e-3 Pa·s), air (perfect gas, μ = 1.84e-05 Pa·s), with surface tensions of 0.07 N/m between all phase pairs. Use laminar flow simulation with gravity g = -9.81 m/s² in y-direction, temperature T = 300K for all phases, simulation time from 0 to 6 seconds with adaptive timestep (initial Δt = 0.0001s, maxCo = 0.5, maxAlphaCo = 0.5), and output every 0.02 seconds using PIMPLE with 3 correctors and vanLeer scheme for alpha transport.

Conduct a multiphase titania synthesis simulation using multiphaseEulerFoam solver for modeling the chemical vapor deposition process in a cylindrical reactor. The domain is an axisymmetric cylindrical geometry with radius 0.015875 m and length 0.44 m (convertToMeters = 1), meshed with 220 cells in axial direction, 1 cell circumferentially, and 16 cells radially using wedge boundary conditions. The vapor phase consists of Ar (97.59%), TiCl4 (0.857%), and O2 (1.55%) entering through the inlet with mass flow rate of 2.173893e-07 kg/s and temperature of 296 K, while the outlet maintains zero gradient conditions and total pressure of 1e5 Pa. The wall boundary applies a temperature profile from experimental data file "validation/exptData/wallTemperature" with no-slip conditions for vapor and slip conditions for particles. The particle phase (TiO2) has density 4230 kg/m³, specific heat 684.246 J/kg·K, and viscosity 1e-7 Pa·s, with initial volume fraction of 0 at inlet and 1.0 internally. Include irreversible Arrhenius reactions for TiCl4 oxidation (A=8.29e4, Ta=10680) and surface deposition (A=4.9e1, Ta=8993) with laminar flow and chemistry modeling. Run simulation from time 0 to 10 seconds with adaptive timestep (initial 1e-4 s, maximum 1e-3 s, maxCo=0.8) and output results every 1 second with population balance tracking for particle size distribution at the outlet zone.

Perform a multiphase Eulerian bubble column simulation using multiphaseEulerFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm (3 outer correctors, 1 corrector, no non-orthogonal correctors). The domain is a 2D rectangular column with dimensions 0.15m width × 1m height × 0.1m depth using a 25×75×1 cell mesh with convertToMeters factor of 1. Initially, water occupies the region 0≤x≤0.15, 0≤y≤0.701, 0≤z≤0.1 with air above it. Boundary conditions specify: inlet (bottom) with air velocity 0.1 m/s in y-direction and water velocity 0 m/s, both phases at volume fraction 0.5, air temperature 300K and water temperature 350K; outlet (top) with inletOutlet conditions; walls with no-slip velocity conditions and zeroGradient for scalar fields; frontAndBackPlanes as empty for 2D simulation. Air properties: molecular weight 28.9 g/mol, viscosity 1.84e-05 Pa·s, Cp 1007 J/kg·K, Prandtl number 0.7, modeled as perfect gas. Water properties: molecular weight 18 g/mol, viscosity 3.645e-4 Pa·s, Cv 4195 J/kg·K, Prandtl number 2.289, with polynomial density correlation. Both phases use laminar momentum transport. Gravity acts downward at -9.81 m/s². Initial pressure 1e5 Pa with IATE interfacial area transport (kappai.air = 2000 m⁻¹). Run from time 0 to 100 seconds with timestep 0.005s, output every 1 second, maximum Courant number 0.5.

Perform a laminar multiphase Eulerian simulation using multiphaseEulerFoam solver for air injection into a water-filled rectangular domain. The domain is a 2D channel with dimensions 0.15m (width) x 1m (height) x 0.1m (depth) using a convertToMeters factor of 1, meshed with 25x75x1 cells. Initially, water (alpha.water = 1) occupies the region 0≤x≤0.15, 0≤y≤0.701, 0≤z≤0.1 while air (alpha.air = 1) fills the remaining upper portion. Apply wall boundary conditions with no-slip velocity (U = 0) and zeroGradient for phase fractions on the bottom and side walls, and outlet boundary conditions with inletOutlet for phase fractions and pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocities at the top boundary. Inject air at point (0.075, 0.2, 0.05) with a mass flow rate of 1e-3 kg/s, downward velocity of -10 m/s, and temperature of 300K using a square pulse starting at t=0.1s for 5s duration. Set air properties with molecular weight 28.9, viscosity 1.84e-05 Pa·s, Cp=1007 J/kg·K using perfectGas equation of state, and water properties with molecular weight 18, viscosity 3.645e-4 Pa·s, Cv=4195 J/kg·K using rPolynomial equation of state. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 3 outer correctors, 1 corrector, and 0 non-orthogonal correctors, running from t=0 to t=10s with adaptive timestep (initial 0.005s, maxCo=0.25), outputting results every 0.1s with gravity acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in y-direction.

Conduct a multiphase steam injection simulation using multiphaseEulerFoam solver with thermal phase change capabilities. The domain is a rectangular channel with dimensions 0.15m x 1m x 0.1m (convertToMeters = 1) discretized with a 25x75x1 grid. Initialize the domain with water at 360K temperature and uniform upward velocity of 0.1 m/s, while steam phase starts with zero volume fraction and 372.76K temperature. Apply inlet boundary conditions with water volume fraction of 1.0, steam volume fraction of 0.0, both phases having 0.1 m/s upward velocity, and fixed steam temperature of 372.76K with zero gradient water temperature. Set outlet conditions as inletOutlet for volume fractions and pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocities. Use no-slip wall conditions with zero gradient for volume fractions, fixed water temperature of 360K, and zero gradient steam temperature. Include a mass source term injecting steam at point (0.075, 0.2, 0.05) with 1e-3 kg/s flow rate, 10 m/s upward velocity, and 3.7e6 J/kg enthalpy starting at t=1s. Set initial pressure to 1e5 Pa with saturation conditions at 372.76K. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 3 outer correctors, 1 corrector, and 2 energy correctors. Run simulation from t=0 to t=10s with adaptive timestep starting at 1e-3s, maximum Courant number of 0.25, and output every 0.1s. Apply laminar flow model for both phases with surface tension of 0.07 N/m, SchillerNaumann drag model, and RanzMarshall heat transfer correlation.

Conduct a multiphase bubble column evaporating and dissolving simulation using multiphaseEulerFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm. The domain is a 2D rectangular column with dimensions 0.15m width × 1.0m height × 0.1m depth (convertToMeters = 1), meshed with 25×75×1 cells. Initialize liquid phase (water) in the lower region from 0≤x≤0.15, 0≤y≤0.501, 0≤z≤0.1 with alpha.liquid = 1, and gas phase (air) occupying the remaining upper region with alpha.gas = 1. Set inlet boundary conditions with gas velocity of (0, 0.1, 0) m/s at 350K temperature, liquid alpha = 0.5, and gas alpha = 0.5. Apply inletOutlet conditions at the outlet with pressureInletOutletVelocity for both phases, and no-slip wall conditions (velocity = 0) with zeroGradient for scalar fields. Use laminar flow for both phases with liquid properties: water density via rPolynomial equation of state, viscosity 3.645e-4 Pa·s, Cv 4195 J/kg·K, and gas properties: air with perfectGas equation of state, viscosity 1.84e-05 Pa·s, Cv 724.8 J/kg·K. Set initial pressure to 1e5 Pa, gravity acceleration -9.81 m/s² in y-direction, timestep 0.0025s, simulation duration 100s with output every 1s, using 5 outer correctors and 1 corrector in PIMPLE algorithm with species transport for air and water in both phases.

Conduct a three-phase multiphase Eulerian simulation using multiphaseEulerFoam solver for a fluidized bed system. The domain is a rectangular channel with dimensions 0.15m width, 1m height, and 0.1m depth, with convertToMeters factor of 1. Use a structured mesh of 25x75x1 cells in x, y, z directions respectively. Initially, air occupies the entire domain (alpha.air = 1), while a solid bed region is defined from 0≤x≤0.15, 0.3333≤y≤0.6501, -0.1≤z≤0.1 with volume fractions alpha.solid = 0.6 and alpha.air = 0.4. The top boundary uses inletOutlet conditions for air and water phases with pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocities and prghTotalPressure for pressure, while walls have noSlip velocity conditions and fixedFluxPressure. Include a mass source at point (0.075, 0.925, 0.05) with square wave water injection at 0.5 kg/s amplitude and 0.5 Hz frequency. Set initial temperature to 300K for all phases, pressure to 1e5 Pa, and gravity to -9.81 m/s² in y-direction. Use air properties: molecular weight 28.9 g/mol, Cp 1007 J/kg·K, viscosity 1.84e-05 Pa·s; water properties: molecular weight 18 g/mol, Cv 4195 J/kg·K, viscosity 3.645e-4 Pa·s; solid properties: density 2500 kg/m³, Cp 6000 J/kg·K. Apply PIMPLE algorithm with 3 outer correctors, 1 corrector, and laminar flow model. Run simulation from 0 to 20 seconds with timestep 0.002s and output every 0.1s.

Conduct a multiphase Eulerian titania synthesis simulation using multiphaseEulerFoam solver to model the chemical vapor deposition process of TiO2 particle formation from TiCl4 and O2 reaction. The domain is an axisymmetric cylindrical reactor with radius 0.015875 m and length 0.44 m (convertToMeters = 1), discretized with 220 cells in the axial direction, 1 cell in the circumferential direction, and 16 cells in the radial direction using wedge boundary conditions. At the inlet, specify a mass flow rate of 2.173893e-07 kg/s for the vapor phase with inlet composition of 97.59% Ar, 0.857% TiCl4, and 1.552% O2, with inlet temperature fixed at 296 K for both vapor and particle phases. The outlet uses zero gradient conditions for velocities and species, with prghTotalPressure boundary condition at 1e5 Pa. The wall boundary implements a temperature profile from experimental data file "validation/exptData/wallTemperature", no-slip condition for vapor velocity, and slip condition for particle velocity. Initialize the domain with uniform pressure of 1e5 Pa, temperature of 296 K, and zero particle volume fraction. Use laminar flow model for both phases with Euler implicit chemistry solver for the irreversible Arrhenius reaction (A=8.29e4, Ta=10680 K) converting TiCl4 and O2 to TiO2 particles and Cl2. Set particle density to 4230 kg/m³ with specific heat of 684.246 J/kg·K. Run simulation from time 0 to 10 seconds with adaptive timestep starting at 1e-4 s (maxCo=0.8, maxDeltaT=1e-3 s) and output results every 1 second with population balance tracking for particle size distribution analysis.

Conduct a multiphase LES nozzle flow simulation using interFoam solver with kEqn turbulence model. The domain is a 2D axisymmetric nozzle geometry with wedge boundary conditions on front and back faces. Set inlet boundary with fixed velocity of 460 m/s in x-direction and alpha.fuel value of 1 (pure fuel injection). Apply no-slip boundary conditions on walls with zeroGradient for pressure. Use atmosphere boundary as pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocity and prghTotalPressure with p0=0 for pressure, with inletOutlet condition for alpha.fuel (inletValue=0). Initialize internal field with zero velocity and alpha.fuel=0 throughout domain except at inlet. Set fuel properties: density=840 kg/m³, kinematic viscosity=5.952e-06 m²/s; air properties: density=20 kg/m³, kinematic viscosity=8.5e-07 m²/s. Use surface tension coefficient sigma=0.0261 N/m between phases. Run simulation from startTime=0 to endTime=4e-05 seconds with initial timestep=1e-08 seconds, adjustable timestepping enabled with maxCo=0.5, maxAlphaCo=0.5, and maxDeltaT=1e-08. Output results every 1e-06 seconds using adjustableRunTime writeControl. Apply Euler temporal discretization, Gauss linear for gradients and laplacians, interfaceCompression vanLeer scheme for alpha transport, and limitedLinear schemes for turbulent quantities.

Perform a multiphase turbulent flow simulation using interFoam solver with RAS k-epsilon turbulence model in an angled duct geometry containing a porous zone. The domain features four boundary patches: inlet with flowRateInletVelocity at 0.1 kg/s mass flow rate and turbulent boundary layer profile, outlet with pressureInletOutletVelocity and fixed pressure boundary conditions, solid walls with noSlip velocity and epsilonWallFunction/kqRWallFunction for turbulence, and porosityWall with slip velocity conditions. The simulation involves two phases - water (density 1000 kg/m³, viscosity 1e-06 m²/s) entering at the inlet with alpha.water = 1, and air (density 1 kg/m³, viscosity 1.48e-05 m²/s) initially filling the domain with alpha.water = 0, with surface tension coefficient of 0.07 N/m. Initial conditions include uniform pressure of 1e5 Pa, temperature of 293 K, turbulent kinetic energy of 1 m²/s², turbulent dissipation rate of 200 m²/s³, and turbulence intensity of 0.05 at inlet with mixing length of 0.005 m. The porous zone uses DarcyForchheimer model with Darcy coefficient d = (2e8 -1000 -1000) and coordinate system rotated 45 degrees. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 3 correctors, adjustable time stepping with initial deltaT of 0.001 s, maximum Courant numbers of 1, simulation time from 0 to 10 seconds, and output every 0.1 seconds with gravity acting in negative y-direction at -9.81 m/s².

Perform a multiphase marine hydrodynamics simulation of a planing hull using interFoam solver with Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) turbulence modeling. The simulation domain contains water and air phases with a hull geometry defined by w3.stl surface file, where water initially occupies the region from z=-999 to z=0.065 and air fills the space above. Boundary conditions include: inlet with fixed velocity of -4.598 m/s in x-direction and fixed alpha.water value of 0, outlet with variableHeightFlowRate for alpha.water and outletPhaseMeanVelocity for velocity with mean velocity 4.598 m/s, atmosphere patch with inletOutlet conditions, and hull patch with movingWallVelocity, interfaceCompression for alpha.water, and wall functions for turbulence. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 3 outer correctors, 1 corrector, momentum predictor disabled, and mesh motion enabled. Physical properties: water density 997 kg/m³ with kinematic viscosity 1.09e-06 m²/s, air density 1 kg/m³ with kinematic viscosity 1.48e-05 m²/s, gravity -9.81 m/s² in z-direction, and zero surface tension. Turbulence modeling uses kOmegaSST with initial k=0.0005 m²/s², omega=240 s⁻¹, and nut=5e-07 m²/s². Hull roughness parameters: Ks=100e-6 m and Cs=0.5. Enable rigid body motion with hull mass 16.146 kg, allowing translation in z-direction and rotation about y-axis. Run simulation from time 0 to 5 seconds with adaptive timestep starting at 1e-4 seconds, maximum Courant numbers of 5, maximum timestep 0.002 seconds, and output every 1.0 seconds. Include forces calculation on hull patch and rigid body state monitoring.

Perform a multiphase floating object simulation using interFoam solver with RAS k-epsilon turbulence modeling. The domain is a rectangular tank with dimensions 1x1x1 meters (convertToMeters factor of 1) discretized with a 20x20x30 grid. Initially, water (density 998.2 kg/m³, viscosity 1e-06 m²/s) occupies the region from z=0 to z=0.5368 throughout the domain, with an additional water region from x=0.7 to x=1.0, y=0.8 to y=1.0, extending from z=0 to z=0.651. Air (density 1 kg/m³, viscosity 1.48e-05 m²/s) fills the remaining volume above the water surface. Boundary conditions include no-slip walls for stationaryWalls (bottom and four vertical sides), atmospheric pressure conditions at the top surface (atmosphere patch), and movingWallVelocity conditions for the floatingObject patch with dynamic mesh capabilities. The simulation runs from time 0 to 6 seconds with an initial timestep of 0.01 seconds using adjustable timestepping (maxCo=1, maxAlphaCo=1), outputting results every 0.1 seconds. Gravity is set to -9.81 m/s² in the z-direction, surface tension is neglected (sigma=0), and the simulation includes rigid body motion tracking with six degrees of freedom.

do a multiphase dam break simulation with porous baffle using interFoam solver with RAS k-epsilon turbulence model. The domain is a 2D rectangular channel where water initially occupies the region 0<=x<=0.1461, 0<=y<=0.292, 0<=z<=-1 to 1 (effectively 2D with empty front and back faces). Create a porous baffle at location x=0.3042 spanning from y=0.0493 to y=0.2077 using cyclic boundary conditions with porousBafflePressure having Darcy coefficient D=10, inertial coefficient I=5, and length=0.15. Boundary conditions include no-slip walls for leftWall, rightWall, and lowerWall, pressureInletOutletVelocity at atmosphere boundary, fixedFluxPressure for walls, and prghTotalPressure at atmosphere. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 3 outer correctors, 1 corrector, and no momentum predictor. Physical properties are water density 1000 kg/m³ with viscosity 1e-06 m²/s, air density 1 kg/m³ with viscosity 1.48e-05 m²/s, surface tension 0.07 N/m, and gravity -9.81 m/s² in y-direction. Run simulation from time 0 to 1 second with initial timestep 0.001, adaptive timestepping enabled with maxCo=0.1, maxAlphaCo=0.1, and output every 0.05 seconds.

do a multiphase weir overflow simulation using interFoam solver with RAS k-epsilon turbulence model. The domain represents a 2D channel with water initially occupying the region -100<=x<=0, 0<=y<=20, -100<=z<=100 (effectively a reservoir upstream of the weir). Use PIMPLE algorithm with 3 correctors and no momentum predictor. Boundary conditions include: inlet with variableHeightFlowRateInletVelocity and variableHeightFlowRate for alpha.water, outlet with inletOutlet for velocity and zeroGradient for alpha.water, lowerWall with noSlip velocity and zeroGradient for alpha.water, and atmosphere with pressureInletOutletVelocity and inletOutlet for alpha.water with prghTotalPressure p0=0. Physical properties: water density 1000 kg/m³ with kinematic viscosity 1e-06 m²/s, air density 1 kg/m³ with kinematic viscosity 1.48e-05 m²/s, surface tension 0.07 N/m, and gravity -9.81 m/s² in y-direction. Run simulation from time 0 to 60 seconds with initial timestep 0.001 seconds using adjustable timestepping with maxCo=0.2, maxAlphaCo=0.2, and maxDeltaT=1 second, outputting results every 2 seconds. Use alpha subcycles of 2 and 1 alpha corrector for volume fraction solution.

Perform a multiphase Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) of a ship hull (DTC hull) moving through waves using interFoam solver with k-omega SST turbulence model. The simulation involves a water-air interface with water density of 998.8 kg/m³ and viscosity of 1.09e-06 m²/s, and air density of 1 kg/m³ with viscosity of 1.48e-05 m²/s. The domain includes an inlet with waveAlpha and waveVelocity boundary conditions generating Stokes2 waves with wavelength of 3 meters and amplitude of 0.04 meters, an outlet with variableHeightFlowRate for alpha and outletPhaseMeanVelocity for velocity, an atmosphere patch with inletOutlet conditions, and a hull patch with movingWallVelocity and zeroGradient for alpha. The hull is a rigid body with mass 412.73 kg, center of mass at (2.929541, 0, 0.2), and constrained to heave (Pz) and pitch (Ry) motions with translational damping coefficient of 8596 and rotational damping coefficient of 11586. Initial water level is set at z=0.244 meters with mean velocity UxMean of -1.668 m/s. The simulation uses PIMPLE algorithm with 3 outer correctors, adjustable time stepping with initial deltaT of 0.0001 seconds, maximum Courant numbers of 10 and 5 for velocity and alpha respectively, runs from time 0 to 20 seconds, and outputs results every 5 seconds with interface surface extraction every 0.01 seconds. Turbulence parameters include initial k=0.00015 m²/s², omega=2 s⁻¹, and nut=5e-07 m²/s with hull surface roughness Ks=100e-6 meters.

Perform a multiphase Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) of a mixer vessel using interFoam solver with k-epsilon turbulence model. The domain is a rectangular vessel with dimensions 0.6m x 0.6m x 1.55m (convertToMeters factor of 1) meshed with 50x50x100 cells. The simulation involves two phases: oil (density 300 kg/m³, viscosity 1.2e-05 m²/s) and water (density 1027 kg/m³, viscosity 1e-06 m²/s) with surface tension coefficient of 0.027 N/m. Initially, oil occupies the entire domain with water filling the region -4≤x≤4, -4≤y≤4, -1≤z≤0.74 through setFields. Boundary conditions include: oil inlet with fixed velocity (0 0 0.2) m/s and alpha.oil=1, outlet with pressureInletOutletVelocity and fixed pressure 125000 Pa, vessel walls with noSlip condition, rotating shaft with rotatingWallVelocity around z-axis at omega=-5 rad/s, stirrer and baffles with movingWallVelocity, and sparger with noSlip. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 2 outer correctors, 1 corrector, momentumPredictor on, and correctPhi enabled. The simulation runs from time 0 to 5.0 seconds with adaptive timestep (maxCo=1.5, maxAlphaCo=1, maxDeltaT=1) starting at deltaT=0.001, outputting results every 0.025 seconds. Gravity is set to (0 0 -9.81) m/s² and the rotating cellZone uses solidBody motion solver with rotatingMotion at -5 rad/s around the z-axis.

Conduct a multiphase Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) of a rotating propeller using interFoam solver with k-epsilon turbulence model and PIMPLE algorithm. The domain is a rectangular box with dimensions 0.6m x 1.02m x 0.6m (x: -0.3 to 0.3, y: -0.81 to 0.21, z: -0.3 to 0.3) with convertToMeters factor of 1. The mesh consists of 12x20x12 cells with the propeller geometry imported from STL files including inner cylinder, outer cylinder, and propeller blades. Water initially occupies the entire domain with alpha.water = 1, and vapor phase properties are defined with nu = 0.0004273 m²/s and density = 0.02308 kg/m³, while water has nu = 9e-07 m²/s and density = 1000 kg/m³. Boundary conditions specify inlet velocity ramping from 0 to -15 m/s in y-direction over 0.01s using uniformFixedValue table, pressureInletOutletVelocity at outlet, noSlip condition on outerCylinder walls, movingWallVelocity on propeller surfaces, and movingWallSlipVelocity on nonCouple interfaces. The propeller rotates about y-axis with angular velocity ramping from 0 to 628 rad/s over 0.01s then reducing to 419 rad/s at 0.03s using solidBody motion solver. Turbulence parameters include k = 0.06 m²/s² and epsilon = 0.0495 m²/s³ at inlet with wall functions applied. Pressure field uses p_rgh = 1e5 Pa with fixedFluxPressure on walls and prghTotalPressure at outlet. Run simulation from 0 to 0.1s with timestep of 1e-5s, adjustable timestepping enabled with maxCo = 2 and maxAlphaCo = 1, outputting results every 0.001s using PIMPLE with 3 outer correctors and correctPhi/correctMeshPhi enabled for mesh motion handling.

Conduct a multiphase water channel flow simulation using interFoam solver with RAS turbulence modeling (k-omega SST model). The domain is a 3D channel geometry with dimensions 20 units in x-direction, 20 units in y-direction (from -10 to +10), and 6 units in z-direction (from 2 to 8), with convertToMeters factor of 1. Use a structured mesh with 20x15x40 cells distributed across three blocks. Initially, water (alpha.water = 1) occupies the region from -10 ≤ x ≤ 50, -20 ≤ y ≤ 20, -10 ≤ z ≤ 2.2, with air above. Boundary conditions include: inlet with volumetric flow rate of 50 m³/s and fixed alpha.water = 1, no-slip walls, outlet with inletOutlet conditions, and atmosphere patch with inletOutlet for air exchange. Physical properties: water density 1000 kg/m³ with kinematic viscosity 1e-06 m²/s, air density 1 kg/m³ with kinematic viscosity 1.48e-05 m²/s, surface tension 0.07 N/m, and gravity -9.81 m/s² in z-direction. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 2 correctors, adaptive time stepping with initial deltaT of 0.1, maximum Courant numbers of 6, simulation time from 0 to 200 seconds, and output results every 5 seconds. Include turbulence parameters: k = 0.0001 m²/s², omega = 0.003 s⁻¹, with appropriate wall functions for turbulent quantities.

Perform a multiphase Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) of a DTC hull ship hydrodynamics simulation using interFoam solver with k-omega SST turbulence model. The domain contains a ship hull geometry with water initially occupying the region below z=0.244 and air above. Set up boundary conditions with inlet having fixed velocity of -1.668 m/s in x-direction, outlet using outletPhaseMeanVelocity with mean velocity 1.668 m/s, atmosphere patch with pressureInletOutletVelocity, and hull patch with movingWallVelocity (stationary). For turbulence, use k=0.00015 m²/s² and omega=2 1/s at inlet with wall functions on hull (rough wall with Ks=100e-6 m and Cs=0.5). Set water properties with density 998.8 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1.09e-06 m²/s, air properties with density 1 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1.48e-05 m²/s, gravity -9.81 m/s² in z-direction, and zero surface tension. Use hierarchical mesh refinement with 6 levels of boxToCell refinement zones around the hull region. Run simulation from time 0 to 4000 seconds with timestep 1 second using localEuler time scheme, output results every 100 timesteps, and calculate forces on hull patch with center of rotation at (2.929541, 0, 0.2) output every timestep.

Perform a multiphase Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) of a DTC hull ship model moving through water using interFoam solver with k-omega SST turbulence model. The simulation domain contains a ship hull with rigid body motion capabilities allowing heave (Pz) and pitch (Ry) degrees of freedom, with the hull's center of mass at coordinates (2.929541, 0, 0.2) and mass of 412.73 kg. Set up water as the primary phase with density 998.8 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1.09e-06 m²/s, and air as the secondary phase with density 1 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1.48e-05 m²/s. Initialize the water level at z=0.244 using setFieldsDict with water occupying the region from z=-999 to z=0.244. Configure boundary conditions with inlet having fixed velocity of -1.668 m/s in x-direction, outlet using outletPhaseMeanVelocity with mean velocity 1.668 m/s, atmosphere patch with pressureInletOutletVelocity, and hull patch with movingWallVelocity and rough wall functions (Ks=100e-6, Cs=0.5). Apply gravitational acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in z-direction. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 3 outer correctors, 1 corrector, momentum predictor disabled, and mesh motion on outer correctors. Set simulation time from 0 to 50 seconds with initial timestep 0.0001, adjustable timestep enabled with maximum Courant numbers of 25 (velocity) and 15 (alpha), maximum timestep 0.01, and output every 5 seconds. Include forces calculation on hull patch with center of rotation at (2.929541, 0, 0.2) and apply linear damping coefficient 8596 for translation and spherical angular damping coefficient 11586 for rotation.

Perform a 2D multiphase container discharge simulation using interFoam solver with laminar flow modeling. The domain represents a container where liquid initially occupies the region from -100 to 100 in x-direction, -100 to 100 in y-direction, and 0.0 to 0.05 in z-direction (effectively 2D due to thin z-dimension). Set boundary conditions with inletOutlet type for left, right, and atmosphere patches allowing fluid to enter/exit based on flow direction, pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocity at these boundaries, and noSlip conditions for wall patches. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 2 correctors, no momentum predictor, and no non-orthogonal correctors. Set liquid phase properties with kinematic viscosity of 0.0001 m²/s and density of 950 kg/m³, gas phase with kinematic viscosity of 1.48e-05 m²/s and density of 1 kg/m³, and surface tension coefficient of 0.07 N/m. Apply gravity acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in z-direction. Run simulation from time 0 to 1.5 seconds with initial timestep of 0.003 seconds using adjustable timestepping with maximum Courant numbers of 5 for both momentum and alpha fields, and output results every 0.02 seconds.

Conduct a 3D multiphase sloshing tank simulation with 6 degrees of freedom motion using interFoam solver. The tank domain extends from -100 to 100 units in x and y directions, with water initially filling the region from z = -100 to z = 0, and air occupying the space above (z > 0). Apply movingWallVelocity boundary conditions to all walls with the tank undergoing prescribed 6DoF motion defined by translation-rotation table data from constant/6DoF.dat file, with center of gravity at (0,0,0). Set water properties as density 998.2 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1e-06 m²/s, air properties as density 1 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1.48e-05 m²/s, with zero surface tension between phases and gravity acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in z-direction. Use laminar flow simulation with Euler temporal discretization, vanLeerV scheme for momentum convection, and interfaceCompression vanLeer scheme for alpha transport with compression factor 1. Run simulation from time 0 to 40 seconds with initial timestep 0.01 seconds, adaptive timestepping enabled with maximum Courant numbers of 0.5 for velocity and 0.5 for alpha, maximum timestep of 1 second, and output results every 0.05 seconds using binary format. Include pressure probes at locations (0, 9.95, 19.77) and (0, -9.95, 19.77) with output every timestep.

Conduct a 3D multiphase sloshing tank simulation using interFoam solver with laminar flow modeling. The tank domain extends from -100 to 100 units in x and y directions and from -100 to approximately 40 units in z direction. Initially, water (alpha.water = 1) occupies the lower region from z = -100 to z = 0, while air fills the upper region from z = 0 to the top of the domain. Apply movingWallVelocity boundary conditions to all walls with solidBody motion using SDA (Ship Design and Analysis) motion function featuring center of gravity at (0,0,0), lambda of 50, roll amplitudes between 0.10472 and 0.22654 rad, heave amplitude of 3.79 units, sway amplitude of 2.34 units, and wave periods of 13.93s primary and 11.93s secondary. Use fixedFluxPressure boundary conditions for p_rgh and zeroGradient for alpha.water on all walls. Set water properties with density 998.2 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1e-06 m²/s, air properties with density 1 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1.48e-05 m²/s, and zero surface tension between phases. Apply gravitational acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in z-direction. Run simulation from time 0 to 40 seconds with adaptive timestep starting at 0.05s, maximum Courant numbers of 0.5 for both velocity and alpha fields, and output results every 0.05s. Include pressure probes at locations (0, 9.95, 19.77) and (0, -9.95, 19.77) with output every timestep.

do a laminar multiphase dam break with obstacle simulation using interFoam solver. The domain is a cubic geometry with dimensions 1x1x1 meters (convertToMeters factor of 1). Use a 32x32x32 grid mesh. Initially, water occupies the region 0<=x<=0.6, 0<=y<=0.1875, 0<=z<=0.75 with an obstacle created by removing cells in the box region 0.375<=x<=0.625, 0.375<=y<=0.625, 0<=z<=0.25. Boundary conditions specify the top face as 'atmosphere' patch with inletOutlet type for alpha.water and pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocity, while all other faces are 'walls' with zeroGradient for alpha.water and no-slip conditions for velocity. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 3 correctors, no momentum predictor, and pressure reference point at (0.51, 0.51, 0.51). Physical properties include water with density 1000 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1e-06 m²/s, air with density 1 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1.48e-05 m²/s, surface tension coefficient 0.07 N/m, and gravity acceleration -9.81 m/s² in z-direction. The simulation runs from time 0 to 2 seconds with adaptive timestep starting at 0.001 seconds, maximum Courant numbers of 0.5 for both velocity and alpha fields, and output every 0.02 seconds. Include dynamic mesh refinement with maximum 2 refinement levels and up to 200000 cells based on alpha.water field values between 0.001 and 0.999.

Perform a multiphase wave simulation using interFoam solver with a rectangular domain of dimensions 1200 x 600 x 20 units (convertToMeters factor of 1). The domain represents a wave tank with the left boundary configured as a wave inlet using waveVelocity and waveAlpha boundary conditions generating Airy waves with 300 unit wavelength and 2.5 unit amplitude, the right boundary as an outlet with outletPhaseMeanVelocity (UnMean = 2 m/s) and zeroGradient for alpha.water, the bottom as a no-slip wall, and the top as an open boundary with inletOutlet conditions. Use a structured mesh of 67x40x1 cells with laminar flow simulation. Set water properties with density 1000 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1e-06 m²/s, and air properties with density 1 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1.48e-05 m²/s. Apply gravity acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in the y-direction with zero surface tension between phases. Configure PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 3 correctors, and momentum predictor enabled. Run simulation from time 0 to 200 seconds with timestep 0.05 seconds, outputting results every 1 second. Include isotropic damping starting at x=1200 with halfCosineRamp scaling over 600 units duration and lambda=0.5. Initialize the domain with uniform air (alpha.water = 0) and mean velocity of 2 m/s in x-direction.

Perform a capillary rise multiphase simulation using interFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm. The domain is a 2D vertical rectangular channel with dimensions 1mm width × 20mm height × 1mm depth (convertToMeters factor of 1e-3). Use a structured mesh of 20×400×1 cells in x, y, and z directions respectively. Initially, water (alpha.water = 1) occupies the lower region from 0≤x≤1, 0≤y≤8e-3, -1≤z≤1 in the scaled coordinate system, with air filling the remaining upper portion. Set boundary conditions as: inlet (bottom) with inletOutlet for alpha.water (value=1, inletValue=1), pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocity, and fixedValue pressure (p_rgh=0); atmosphere (top) with zeroGradient for alpha.water, pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocity, and fixedValue pressure (p_rgh=0); walls (left and right) with constantAlphaContactAngle (theta0=45°), noSlip velocity, and fixedFluxPressure; front and back faces as empty for 2D simulation. Use water properties: density=1000 kg/m³, kinematic viscosity=1e-06 m²/s; air properties: density=1 kg/m³, kinematic viscosity=1.48e-05 m²/s; surface tension coefficient=0.0707106 N/m; gravity acceleration=-10 m/s² in y-direction. Run simulation from time 0 to 0.5 seconds with adaptive timestep (initial deltaT=1e-5, maxCo=0.2, maxAlphaCo=0.2, maxDeltaT=1), output results every 0.05 seconds using adjustableRunTime control, and employ laminar flow with PIMPLE settings of 3 correctors and no momentum predictor.

Perform a 3D multiphase sloshing tank simulation using interFoam solver with dynamic mesh motion and adaptive mesh refinement. The tank domain extends from -100 to 100 units in x and y directions with water initially occupying the region from z = -100 to z = 0, while air occupies the space above (z > 0). The tank walls use movingWallVelocity boundary conditions with fixedFluxPressure for pressure and zeroGradient for the water volume fraction. Apply solidBody motion using SDA (Ship Design and Analysis) function with center of gravity at (0,0,0), roll amplitude between 0.1-0.2, heave amplitude of 4 units, sway amplitude of 2.4 units, and wave periods of 14s primary and 12s secondary. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 3 correctors, no momentum predictor, reference pressure of 1e5 Pa at point (0,0,0.15), and adjustable timestep with initial deltaT of 0.01s, maximum Courant numbers of 0.5 for both velocity and alpha fields. Set water properties with density 998.2 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1e-06 m²/s, air density 1 kg/m³ and viscosity 1.48e-05 m²/s, with gravity -9.81 m/s² in z-direction and zero surface tension. Enable adaptive mesh refinement based on alpha.water field with refinement levels between 0.001-0.999, maximum 1 refinement level, and maximum 200000 cells. Run simulation from 0 to 10 seconds with output every 0.05 seconds and probe pressure measurements at locations (0,9.95,19.77) and (0,-9.95,19.77).

Conduct a 3D multiphase wave simulation using interFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm. The domain represents a wave tank with water and air phases where water has density 1000 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1e-06 m²/s, while air has density 1 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1.48e-05 m²/s. Generate Airy waves with wavelength 300 units, amplitude 2.5 units, and wave angle 0.5235987755982988 radians propagating in the x-direction from the inlet boundaries. Apply waveAlpha and waveVelocity boundary conditions at inlet and inletSide patches, inletOutlet condition for alpha.water at the top boundary with inletValue 0, pressureInletOutletVelocity at the top for velocity, noSlip condition at the bottom boundary, zeroGradient for alpha.water at bottom, fixedFluxPressure for p_rgh at inlet/inletSide and bottom, and prghTotalPressure with p0=0 at the top. Use laminar flow simulation with gravity acceleration (0 0 -9.81) m/s². Set simulation time from 0 to 100 seconds with timestep 0.05 seconds and output results every 1 second using adjustableRunTime writeControl. Configure PIMPLE with momentumPredictor yes, 1 outer corrector, 3 correctors, and 0 non-orthogonal correctors. Include isoSurface function for alpha.water=0.5 and enable parallel decomposition for 18 processors using hierarchical method with (3 3 2) distribution.

Perform a cavitating multiphase flow simulation around a bullet using interFoam solver. The domain is a rectangular box with dimensions 30x30x115 millimeters (convertToMeters 1e-3), discretized with a 15x15x50 grid. The bullet geometry is immersed within this domain. Set boundary conditions as follows: inlet patch with fixed velocity of 20 m/s in z-direction and fixed alpha.water value of 1, outlet patch with fixed pressure of 100000 Pa and inletOutlet condition for alpha.water, symmetry walls on all four sides, and noSlip condition on the bullet surface with fixedFluxPressure. Use two-phase flow with water (density 1000 kg/m³, viscosity 9e-07 m²/s) and vapour (density 0.02308 kg/m³, viscosity 0.0004273 m²/s) phases with surface tension coefficient of 0.07 N/m. Implement SchnerrSauer cavitation model with saturation pressure of 2300 Pa, nucleation site density of 1.6e+13 1/m³, and nucleation site diameter of 2.0e-06 m. Run simulation from 0 to 0.05 seconds with adaptive timestep starting at 1e-8 seconds, maximum Courant number of 5, maximum alpha Courant number of 2, and output results every 0.001 seconds using adjustable runtime control.

Perform a multiphase laminar sloshing simulation using interFoam solver with a cylindrical container geometry. The domain contains two phases: water (density 998.2 kg/m³, viscosity 1e-06 m²/s) and air (density 1 kg/m³, viscosity 1.48e-05 m²/s) with surface tension coefficient of 0.07 N/m. Initialize water in the lower region from -1≤x≤1, -1≤y≤1, -1≤z≤-0.06 with air occupying the remaining volume above. Apply movingWallVelocity boundary conditions to the wall with dynamic mesh motion including oscillating linear motion (amplitude 0.1 m in x-direction) and rotating motion (origin at 0,0.02,0 with axis 0,0,1) both at omega 18.8945578 rad/s. Use fixedFluxPressure for p_rgh and zeroGradient for alpha.water at the wall. Employ PIMPLE algorithm with 2 correctors, 1 non-orthogonal corrector, no momentum predictor, and pressure reference point at origin. Set gravity to zero. Run simulation from time 0 to 0.5 seconds with adaptive timestep (initial 0.001s, maxCo=2, maxAlphaCo=2) and output results every 0.02 seconds. Use snappyHexMesh for mesh generation with refinement level 1 inside the cylinder geometry and insidePoint at (1e-5, 1e-5, 1e-5).

Perform a multiphase laminar tube mixer simulation using interFoam solver with dynamic mesh motion. The domain is a rectangular tube with dimensions 1 cm × 10 cm × 1 cm (scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.01), meshed with 5×50×5 cells. Initially, water (alpha.water = 1) occupies the lower region from z = -100 to z = -0.0025 in the original coordinate system, with air filling the remaining volume. The simulation features complex dynamic mesh motion including a rotating table motion with origin at (0, 0.1, 0), axis along z-direction, and angular velocity of 6.2832 rad/s, plus an oscillating rotating motion with origin at (0, 0, 0), omega of 40 rad/s, and amplitude of 45 degrees in x-direction. All boundaries are designated as walls with movingWallVelocity boundary conditions for velocity, zeroGradient for alpha.water, and fixedFluxPressure for p_rgh. Physical properties include water with density 998.2 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1e-06 m²/s, and air with density 1 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1.48e-05 m²/s, with zero surface tension. The simulation runs from time 0 to 1 second with adaptive timestep starting at 0.0001 seconds, maintaining maximum Courant numbers of 0.5 for both momentum and alpha fields, and outputs results every 0.01 seconds using adjustableRunTime control with gravity set to -9.81 m/s² in z-direction.

Perform a 2D sloshing tank simulation with 3 degrees of freedom motion using interFoam solver. The tank geometry spans from -100 to 100 units in x and y directions with water initially occupying the region -100<=x<=100, -100<=y<=100, -100<=z<=0 and air above from 0<=z<=100. Apply empty boundary conditions to front and back faces for 2D simulation, movingWallVelocity boundary condition for tank walls with fixedFluxPressure for pressure. Use water properties of density 998.2 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1e-06 m²/s, and air properties of density 1 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity 1.48e-05 m²/s with zero surface tension. Implement SDA (Ship Design and Analysis) motion function with center of gravity at origin, lambda 50, roll amplitude max 0.2 and min 0.1, heave amplitude 4, sway amplitude 2.4, Q factor 2, and wave periods Tp 14 and Tpn 12. Set gravity to -9.81 m/s² in z-direction. Run simulation from time 0 to 40 seconds with initial timestep 0.01 seconds using adjustable timestepping with maximum Courant number 0.5 and maximum alpha Courant number 0.5. Output results every 0.05 seconds and use laminar flow model with Euler time discretization and vanLeer schemes for convection terms.

Perform a lock exchange multiphase flow simulation using twoLiquidMixingFoam solver to model the gravity-driven mixing of two liquids (sludge and water) in a rectangular channel. The domain is a 2D channel with dimensions 10 units length × 2 units height × 2 units width (convertToMeters = 1), meshed with 200×40×1 cells using a structured grid. Initially, the sludge (alpha.sludge = 1) occupies the left half of the domain from 0≤x≤5, 0≤y≤2, 0≤z≤2, while water fills the remaining space. Apply slip boundary conditions for velocity on all walls (left, right, top, bottom), zeroGradient conditions for the phase fraction alpha.sludge, and fixedFluxPressure for p_rgh on all boundaries, with empty conditions on front and back faces for 2D simulation. Set physical properties with sludge density of 1000 kg/m³ and water density of 990 kg/m³, both having kinematic viscosity of 1e-06 m²/s. Use gravity acceleration of -9.81 m/s² in the y-direction, laminar flow simulation, and PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector and 2 pressure correctors. Run the simulation from time 0 to 100 seconds with adaptive timestep starting at 0.05 seconds, maximum Courant number of 0.5, maximum alpha Courant number of 0.5, and output results every 1 second with diffusion coefficient Dab of 1e-06 m²/s between phases.

Perform a four-phase dam break simulation using multiphaseInterFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm.
