The domain is a 2D rectangular geometry with dimensions 0.2922 x 0.292 meters (assuming convertToMeters = 1). Initialize water in the region 0 ≤ x ≤ 0.1461, 0.1 ≤ y ≤ 0.292, oil in the region 0.1461 ≤ x ≤ 0.2922, 0.1 ≤ y ≤ 0.292, mercury in the region 0 ≤ x ≤ 0.1461, 0 ≤ y ≤ 0.1, and air filling the remaining domain. Apply no-slip boundary conditions on leftWall, rightWall, and lowerWall surfaces, with alphaContactAngle boundary conditions for all phase fractions using 90-degree contact angles between all phase pairs. Set the atmosphere boundary as inletOutlet for phase fractions and pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocity. Use fixedFluxPressure boundary condition for p_rgh on walls and prghTotalPressure on atmosphere. Set physical properties: water (ρ=1000 kg/m³, ν=1e-06 m²/s), oil (ρ=500 kg/m³, ν=1e-06 m²/s), mercury (ρ=13529 kg/m³, ν=1.125e-07 m²/s), air (ρ=1 kg/m³, ν=1.48e-05 m²/s), with surface tension coefficient of 0.07 N/m between all phase pairs. Apply gravity acceleration of 9.81 m/s² in negative y-direction. Run simulation from time 0 to 6 seconds with initial timestep of 0.001 seconds, using adjustable timestep with maximum Courant numbers of 0.5 for momentum and 0.5 for alpha, outputting results every 0.01 seconds using adjustableRunTime writeControl.

Perform a potential free surface flow simulation using potentialFreeSurfaceFoam solver to analyze an oscillating floating box in a water tank. The domain is a 2D rectangular tank with dimensions 10 units length by 1 unit height by 0.1 unit width (convertToMeters = 1), meshed with 200x20x1 cells using non-uniform grading (10 in x-direction, 0.1 in y-direction, 1 in z-direction). The freeSurface (top wall) uses waveSurfacePressure boundary condition, leftWall has fixedNormalSlip point displacement with normal (-1 0 0), rightWall and bottomWall are fixed walls with uniformFixedValue displacement (0 0 0), and the floatingObject has movingWallVelocity for velocity and fixedFluxPressure for pressure. The floatingObjectBottom undergoes oscillatingDisplacement with amplitude (0 -0.05 0) and omega 6.2831853 rad/s. Use PIMPLE algorithm with correctPhi enabled, momentumPredictor disabled, 1 outer corrector, 2 correctors, and 0 non-orthogonal correctors. Set kinematic viscosity nu = 1e-06 m²/s, gravity g = (0 -9.81 0) m/s², and density rhoInf = 1000 kg/m³ for force calculations. Run simulation from startTime 0 to endTime 20 seconds with initial deltaT 0.001 seconds, adjustable timestep with maxCo 0.4, and output every 0.02 seconds. Use laminar flow with displacementLaplacian mesh motion solver and inverseDistance diffusivity. The frontAndBack faces are empty boundaries for 2D simulation.

Perform a potential free surface flow simulation using potentialFreeSurfaceFoam solver to analyze an oscillating box in a 2D water tank. The domain is a rectangular channel with dimensions 10 units length × 1 unit height × 0.1 unit width (convertToMeters factor of 1), meshed with 200×20×1 cells using grading (10 0.1 1) to refine near walls. The freeSurface (top boundary at y=1) uses waveSurfacePressure boundary condition, walls (left, right, and bottom boundaries) have noSlip velocity and zeroGradient pressure conditions, and the floatingObject patch employs fixedNormalInletOutletVelocity with sinusoidal oscillation having amplitude 0.025 units in y-direction at frequency 1 Hz ramping up over 10 seconds duration. Use PIMPLE algorithm with momentumPredictor disabled, 1 outer corrector, 2 correctors, and no non-orthogonal corrections. Set kinematic viscosity nu=1e-06 m²/s, gravity g=(0 -9.81 0) m/s², and density rhoInf=1000 kg/m³ for force calculations. Run simulation from startTime 0 to endTime 20 seconds with initial timestep 0.001 seconds, adjustable timestepping enabled with maxCo=0.4 and maxDeltaT=1, outputting results every 0.02 seconds while monitoring forces on floatingObject and pool height via surfaceFieldValue function.

Perform a compressible steady-state turbulent flow simulation through an angled duct with porous media using rhoSimpleFoam solver with SIMPLE algorithm and k-epsilon turbulence model. The domain features walls with no-slip boundary conditions, a porous wall region with slip conditions, an inlet with mass flow rate of 0.1 kg/s using turbulent boundary layer profile with 5% turbulence intensity and 0.005 mixing length, and an outlet with fixed pressure of 1.0e5 Pa. Set initial conditions of uniform pressure 1.0e5 Pa, temperature 293 K, zero velocity, turbulent kinetic energy 1 m²/s², and dissipation rate 200 m²/s³. Use air properties with molecular weight 28.9 g/mol, specific heat 1005 J/kg·K, dynamic viscosity 1.82e-05 Pa·s, and Prandtl number 0.71 with perfect gas equation of state. Apply explicit porosity source with fixed coefficients alpha=(500, -1000, -1000) in a rotated coordinate system (45° rotation about z-axis) within the porosity cell zone, and constrain temperature to 350 K with fixed turbulence values k=1 m²/s² and epsilon=150 m²/s³ in the porous region. Run simulation for 1000 time steps with unit timestep, output results every 100 steps, use pressure limits with factors 0.4-1.5, and apply relaxation factors of 0.3 for pressure, 0.01 for density, and 0.7 for velocity, enthalpy, and turbulence variables.

Perform a compressible turbulent liquid flow simulation through a square bend geometry using rhoSimpleFoam solver with SIMPLE algorithm and k-epsilon turbulence model. The domain features three boundary patches: walls with no-slip velocity conditions and fixed temperature of 350K, an inlet with mass flow rate of 5 kg/s at density 1000 kg/m³ using turbulent boundary layer profile and fixed temperature of 300K with turbulence intensity of 5% and mixing length of 0.005m, and an outlet with fixed pressure of 1e5 Pa and inletOutlet conditions for other variables. Initialize the domain with uniform pressure of 1e5 Pa, temperature of 300K, turbulent kinetic energy of 1 m²/s², and dissipation rate of 200 m²/s³. Use water (H2O) as the working fluid with heRhoThermo thermodynamic model and liquid properties. Run steady-state simulation from time 0 to 500 with timestep of 1 and output results every 100 timesteps. Apply relaxation factors of 0.3 for pressure and 0.7 for velocity, enthalpy, and turbulence variables with residual control tolerances of 1e-4 for pressure and velocity and 1e-3 for turbulence and enthalpy variables.

Perform a compressible turbulent flow simulation around a NACA0012 airfoil using rhoSimpleFoam solver with SIMPLE algorithm and k-omega SST turbulence model. The domain features a NACA0012 airfoil geometry with freestream boundary conditions at the far-field and no-slip wall conditions on the airfoil surface. Set freestream velocity to 250 m/s at 0 degrees angle of attack, freestream pressure to 1e5 Pa, and temperature to 298 K. Use air as working fluid with molecular weight 28.9 g/mol, specific heat capacity 1005 J/kg-K, dynamic viscosity 1.82e-05 Pa-s, and Prandtl number 0.71. Initialize turbulent kinetic energy to 1e-3 m²/s² and specific dissipation rate to 1 s⁻¹. Run steady-state simulation for 5000 iterations with timestep of 1, outputting results every 50 iterations. Apply relaxation factors of 0.3 for pressure, 0.01 for density, and 0.7 for velocity, enthalpy, and turbulence quantities. Use GAMG solver for pressure with DIC smoother and PBiCGStab for other variables with DILU preconditioner, targeting residual control of 1e-6 for pressure and 1e-5 for velocity and turbulence variables.

Perform a compressible turbulent flow simulation using rhoSimpleFoam solver with SIMPLE algorithm for a square bend geometry. The domain uses k-epsilon turbulence model with RAS simulation type. Boundary conditions specify: walls with no-slip velocity, epsilonWallFunction for turbulent dissipation, zeroGradient pressure, and zeroGradient temperature; inlet with flowRateInletVelocity at mass flow rate of 0.5 kg/s with inlet density of 0.5 kg/m³, turbulent boundary layer profile, turbulentMixingLengthDissipationRateInlet with mixing length of 0.005 m, zeroGradient pressure, and fixed temperature of 1000 K; outlet with pressureInletOutletVelocity, fixed pressure of 110000 Pa, and inletOutlet temperature of 1000 K. Initialize the domain with uniform pressure of 110000 Pa, temperature of 1000 K, turbulent kinetic energy of 1 m²/s², and turbulent dissipation rate of 200 m²/s³. Use air properties with molecular weight of 28.9 g/mol, specific heat capacity of 1005 J/kg·K, dynamic viscosity of 1.82e-05 Pa·s, and Prandtl number of 0.71 with perfectGas equation of state. Set turbulent intensity at inlet to 5%. Run steady-state simulation from time 0 to 500 with timestep of 1 and output results every 100 timesteps. Apply SIMPLE algorithm with transonic and consistent options enabled, using GAMG solver for pressure and PBiCGStab for velocity, enthalpy, and turbulence variables with tolerance of 1e-08 and relaxation factors of 0.9 for equations except pressure.

do a compressible Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) of supersonic flow around a prism using rhoPimpleFoam solver. The domain is a 2D geometry with a prism obstacle where the flow enters at the inlet with a fixed velocity of 650 m/s in the x-direction, fixed pressure of 100000 Pa, and fixed temperature of 300 K. The outlet uses waveTransmissive boundary condition for pressure with gamma 1.3 and inletOutlet for other variables. The bottomWall and topWall use supersonicFreestream boundary conditions with pInf 100000 Pa, TInf 300 K, UInf (650 0 0) m/s, and gamma 1.28418. The prismWall has noSlip velocity condition, zeroGradient temperature, zeroGradient pressure, and wall functions for turbulence (epsilonWallFunction, kqRWallFunction, nutkWallFunction). Use k-epsilon turbulence model with initial k value of 1000 m²/s² and epsilon value of 266000 m²/s³. The fluid is air with molecular weight 28.9 g/mol, Cp 1005 J/kg·K, dynamic viscosity 1.8e-05 Pa·s, and Prandtl number 0.7, modeled as a perfect gas with sensible internal energy. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 2 outer correctors, 1 corrector, 0 non-orthogonal correctors, and transonic option enabled. Run simulation from time 0 to 0.0004 seconds with timestep 5e-07 seconds and output results every 0.0001 seconds. The defaultFaces are set as empty indicating 2D simulation characteristics.

Conduct a compressible lid-driven cavity flow simulation using rhoPimpleFoam solver with Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) turbulence modeling. The domain is a square cavity with dimensions 1x1x0.1 units scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.1, making the actual dimensions 0.1m x 0.1m x 0.01m. Use a structured mesh of 20x20x1 cells in x, y, and z directions respectively. The top wall (movingWall) has a fixed velocity boundary condition of 1 m/s in the x-direction, while the remaining walls (fixedWalls) have no-slip boundary conditions with zero velocity. The front and back faces are designated as empty for 2D flow characteristics. Set initial conditions with uniform pressure of 100000 Pa, uniform temperature of 300 K, and zero initial velocity throughout the domain. Use kOmegaSST turbulence model with initial turbulent kinetic energy k=0.00325 m²/s², omega=2.6 s⁻¹, and epsilon=0.000765 m²/s³. Configure the thermophysical properties for air with molecular weight 28.9 g/mol, specific heat Cp=1007 J/kg/K, dynamic viscosity mu=1.84e-05 Pa·s, and Prandtl number Pr=0.7. Apply pressure limits between 0.8e5 and 1.2e5 Pa using fvConstraints. Run the simulation from time 0 to 1 second with a timestep of 0.01 seconds, using PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 2 correctors, and output results every 0.1 seconds.

Conduct a compressible Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) of supersonic flow over a NACA airfoil using rhoPimpleFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm. The simulation features a 2D airfoil geometry with inlet boundary (INLE1) specified as supersonicFreestream with freestream velocity of (600, 148.16, 0) m/s at Mach number approximately 1.8, static pressure of 100000 Pa, and temperature of 300 K. The outlet boundary (OUTL2) uses waveTransmissive boundary conditions with gamma 1.3, the airfoil wall (WALL10) has no-slip velocity and adiabatic temperature conditions, and symmetry planes (SYMP3) are set as empty for 2D simulation. Use Launder-Sharma k-epsilon turbulence model with initial turbulent kinetic energy of 1000 m²/s² and dissipation rate of 25000 m²/s³. Set air properties with molecular weight 28.9 g/mol, specific heat capacity 1005 J/kg·K, dynamic viscosity 1.8e-05 Pa·s, and Prandtl number 0.7 using perfectGas equation of state. Run transonic PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 2 correctors, and 0 non-orthogonal correctors for timestep 4e-08 seconds from start time 0 to end time 0.01 seconds, outputting results every 2e-04 seconds, and calculate force coefficients on the airfoil with reference velocity 618.022 m/s, lift direction (-0.239733, 0.970839, 0), and drag direction (0.970839, 0.239733, 0).

Conduct a compressible Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) of an annular thermal mixer using rhoPimpleFoam solver with k-epsilon turbulence model. The domain is a cylindrical annular geometry with dimensions spanning from -1.1 to 1.1 in x and y directions and from -0.1 to 2.1 in z-direction with convertToMeters factor of 0.1, creating an effective domain of 0.22m x 0.22m x 0.22m. Use a 21x21x21 grid resolution. The simulation features two inlet conditions: innerInlet with velocity (0 0 0.2) m/s, temperature 233K, k=2.40e-5 m²/s², and epsilon=5.70e-5 m²/s³; outerInlet with velocity (0 0 0.1) m/s, temperature 293K, k=6.00e-6 m²/s², and epsilon=3.98e-5 m²/s³. Apply no-slip boundary conditions on staticWalls and movingWalls, with zeroGradient conditions on outlet and nonCouple patches. The fluid properties include air with molecular weight 28.9 g/mol, specific heat capacity 1005 J/kg·K, dynamic viscosity 1.82e-05 Pa·s, and Prandtl number 0.71. Use dynamic mesh motion with solidBody rotation at omega=25 rad/s about the z-axis. Run simulation from time 0 to 2 seconds with initial timestep 1e-3s, adjustable timestep enabled with maxCo=1, and output results every 0.02s using PIMPLE algorithm with 3 outer correctors and 1 corrector.

Conduct a compressible Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) of flow through an angled duct with porous media using rhoPimpleFoam solver. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 1 corrector, and 0 non-orthogonal correctors, with maximum Courant number of 0.2. The domain contains a porous zone with Darcy-Forchheimer coefficients d=(5e7, -1000, -1000) and coordinate system rotated 45 degrees about the z-axis. Boundary conditions include: inlet with mass flow rate of 0.1 kg/s using turbulent boundary layer profile and turbulent intensity of 5%, walls with no-slip condition and wall functions for turbulence (k, epsilon, nut), porosity wall with slip condition, and outlet with fixed pressure of 1e5 Pa and flux-corrected velocity. Initial conditions are velocity 47.8 m/s in x-direction, temperature 293 K, pressure 1e5 Pa, turbulent kinetic energy 1 m²/s², and dissipation rate 200 m²/s³. Fluid properties include air with molecular weight 28.9 g/mol, specific heat 1005 J/kg·K, dynamic viscosity 1.82e-05 Pa·s, and Prandtl number 0.71. Use k-epsilon turbulence model with mixing length 0.005 m at inlet. Simulation runs from time 0 to 500 seconds with adaptive time stepping (initial deltaT=1, maximum deltaT=1) and output every 50 seconds using localEuler time scheme.

Perform a compressible transient decompression tank simulation using rhoPimpleFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm (2 outer correctors, 1 corrector, transonic flow enabled). The domain is an axisymmetric 2D geometry with empty front and back boundaries representing a tank with a nozzle outlet. Initial conditions specify uniform velocity of 0 m/s throughout the domain, uniform temperature of 300 K, and uniform pressure of 10 MPa (1e+07 Pa). Boundary conditions include no-slip condition on the outer wall with fixed temperature of 300 K and zero gradient pressure, symmetry plane condition on the axis, and zero gradient velocity and temperature with fixed pressure of 0 Pa at the nozzle outlet. The working fluid is water with molecular weight of 18 g/mol, polynomial equation of state with coefficients C=(0.001278 -2.1055e-06 3.9689e-09 4.3772e-13 -2.0225e-16), constant specific heat Cv of 4185 J/kg·K, dynamic viscosity of 0.001 Pa·s, and Prandtl number of 1. Use laminar flow simulation with time step of 5e-07 seconds, end time of 0.0001 seconds, and output results every 20 time steps using Euler temporal discretization and limited linear spatial schemes for convective terms.

Do a compressible laminar flow simulation over a forward-facing step using rhoPimpleFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm. The domain is a 2D channel with dimensions spanning from x=0 to x=3, y=0 to y=1, and z=-0.05 to z=0.05 (convertToMeters factor of 1), featuring a forward step obstacle located at x=0.6 and extending from y=0 to y=0.2. The mesh consists of three blocks with total grid points of approximately 25x10x1, 25x40x1, and 100x40x1 cells respectively. Boundary conditions specify: inlet with fixed velocity of 3 m/s in x-direction, fixed pressure of 1 Pa, and fixed temperature of 1 K; outlet with zeroGradient velocity and pressure conditions; top and bottom walls as symmetryPlane; obstacle surface with noSlip velocity and zeroGradient pressure and temperature; and defaultFaces as empty for 2D simulation. Use perfect gas equation of state with molecular weight of 11640.3, constant specific heat Cp of 2.5, zero viscosity (mu=0), and Prandtl number of 1. Set PIMPLE algorithm with 2 outer correctors, 1 corrector, and transonic flow enabled. Run simulation from time 0 to 10 seconds with timestep of 0.002 seconds and output results every 0.5 seconds, including Mach number field calculations.

do a compressible laminar Helmholtz resonance simulation using rhoPimpleFoam solver. The domain represents an acoustic resonator system with an inlet, outlet, plenum chamber, walls, and symmetry planes. Set up boundary conditions with a mass flow rate inlet of 0.0001 kg/s at the inlet patch, pressureInletOutletVelocity at the outlet, no-slip wall conditions (fixedValue uniform (0 0 0)) for walls, pressureInletVelocity for the plenum, and symmetry conditions for symmetry patches. Initialize the domain with uniform velocity (0 0 0) m/s, uniform temperature of 300 K throughout, and uniform pressure of 1e5 Pa. Configure the plenum boundary with plenumPressure condition using gamma=1.4, R=287.04 J/kg-K, supply mass flow rate of 0.0001 kg/s, plenum volume of 0.000125 m³, plenum density of 1.1613 kg/m³, inlet area ratio of 1.0, inlet discharge coefficient of 0.8, and time scale of 1e-4 s. Use air as working fluid with molecular weight 28.9 g/mol, constant viscosity of 1.8e-05 Pa-s, Prandtl number of 0.7, and specific heat Cv of 712 J/kg-K modeled as perfect gas with sensible internal energy. Run simulation from time 0 to 0.05 seconds with fixed timestep of 1e-4 seconds, output results every 0.01 seconds, and use PIMPLE algorithm with 3 outer correctors, 1 corrector, momentum predictor enabled, and maximum Courant number of 0.5. Include pressure probes at locations (-0.045, 0, 0), (-0.045, 0.020, 0), (-0.010, 0, 0), (0.0125, 0, 0), and (0.0125, 0.020, 0) with output every timestep.

Perform a compressible shock tube simulation using rhoPimpleFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm. The domain is a rectangular tube with dimensions 10 units in length (-5 to 5), 2 units in height (-1 to 1), and 2 units in depth (-1 to 1), with convertToMeters value of 1. Use a grid of 1000x1x1 cells creating an effectively 1D simulation. Initialize the left region (-5≤x≤0) with high pressure conditions of 100000 Pa and temperature of 348.432 K, and the right region (0≤x≤5) with low pressure conditions of 10000 Pa and temperature of 278.746 K, both with zero initial velocity. Apply zeroGradient boundary conditions for pressure, velocity, and temperature at the sides patches, with empty boundary conditions for the front, back, top, and bottom faces. Set the simulation to run from time 0 to 0.007 seconds with a timestep of 1e-05 seconds and output results every 0.001 seconds. Use perfect gas equation of state with air properties including molecular weight of 28.9 g/mol, specific heat capacity of 1005 J/kg·K, zero viscosity for inviscid flow, and Prandtl number of 0.7. Configure PIMPLE algorithm with 2 outer correctors, 1 corrector, and transonic flow enabled.

Perform a compressible laminar flow simulation with heat transfer and scalar transport using rhoPimpleFoam solver through a blocked channel geometry. The domain is a 2D channel with inlet boundary conditions of fixed velocity 10 m/s in x-direction, fixed temperature 400 K, and fixed tracer concentration of 1, while the outlet has zero gradient velocity and tracer with fixed pressure of 1e5 Pa. The walls have no-slip velocity conditions with zero gradient temperature and tracer, and front/back faces are empty for 2D simulation. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 2 correctors and 0 non-orthogonal correctors, with adjustable time stepping starting from deltaT of 0.0001 s, maximum Courant number of 5, running from time 0 to 0.03 s with output every 0.001 s. The fluid properties include air with molecular weight 28.9 g/mol, dynamic viscosity 1.8e-05 Pa·s, Prandtl number 0.7, specific heat Cv=712 J/kg·K and Cp=1005 J/kg·K, modeled as perfect gas with initial internal field conditions of uniform velocity (10,0,0) m/s, pressure 1e5 Pa, and temperature 300 K with tracer initially at 0 concentration. Include scalar transport function for tracer field and use Euler time scheme with linearUpwind divergence schemes for convective terms.

Perform a compressible turbulent flow simulation through an angled duct with porous media using rhoPorousSimpleFoam solver with SIMPLE algorithm and k-epsilon turbulence model. The domain contains a porous zone with Darcy-Forchheimer resistance coefficients d=(5e7, -1000, -1000) and f=(0, 0, 0) oriented at 45 degrees using coordinate rotation with e1=(0.70710678, 0.70710678, 0) and e2=(0, 0, 1). Boundary conditions include: inlet with flowRateInletVelocity of 0.1 m³/s (or massFlowRate 0.1 kg/s), turbulent boundary layer profile, turbulence intensity of 5%, mixing length of 0.005 m, and fixed temperature of 293 K; outlet with inletOutlet velocity, fixed pressure of 1e5 Pa, and inletOutlet temperature; walls with noSlip velocity, zeroGradient pressure and temperature, and wall functions for turbulence; porosityWall with slip velocity condition and wall functions. Physical properties include air as perfect gas with molecular weight 28.9 g/mol, specific heat Cp=1005 J/kg·K, dynamic viscosity μ=1.82e-05 Pa·s, and Prandtl number 0.71. Initial conditions set uniform pressure 1e5 Pa, temperature 293 K, turbulent kinetic energy k=1 m²/s², and dissipation rate ε=200 m²/s³. Use steady-state simulation from time 0 to 100 with timestep 1 and output every 10 timesteps, with porous zone maintained at fixed temperature of 350 K and pressure limiting between 0.5-2.0 times reference values.

Conduct a steady-state compressible flow simulation through an angled duct using rhoPorousSimpleFoam solver with SIMPLE algorithm. The simulation should run for 1000 iterations with a timestep of 1 and output results every 100 iterations. Use k-epsilon turbulence model with bounded Gauss upwind discretization schemes for convective terms and Gauss linear corrected for diffusion terms. Apply GAMG solver for pressure with tolerance of 1e-08 and smoothSolver with GaussSeidel smoother for velocity and turbulence quantities. Set relaxation factors of 0.3 for pressure, 0.03 for density, 0.7 for velocity and turbulence parameters, and 0.5 for energy. Include pressure limiting constraints with minFactor 0.5 and maxFactor 1.5, and configure residual control targets of 1e-2 for pressure, 1e-4 for velocity, 1e-3 for energy and turbulence parameters with zero non-orthogonal correctors.

Perform a compressible high-speed flow simulation over a biconic geometry using rhoCentralFoam solver with Kurganov flux scheme. The domain is a 2D axisymmetric rectangular geometry with dimensions 1.0 x 1.0 x 0.1 units scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.1 (making actual dimensions 0.1m x 0.1m x 0.01m). Use a structured mesh of 255x127x1 cells with simple grading. Boundary conditions include: wall boundary condition on the 'cone' surface (biconic body), patch conditions on 'outlet' and 'freestream' boundaries, symmetry condition on 'centreLeft', and patch conditions on 'wedge1' and 'wedge2' faces. The simulation uses laminar flow with air as working fluid (molecular weight 28.01348 kg/kmol) modeled as perfect gas with Sutherland transport properties (As=1.458e-06, Ts=110K, Pr=0.72) and JANAF thermodynamic coefficients. Run simulation from time 0 to 1e-3 seconds with adaptive timestep starting at 1e-7 seconds, maximum Courant number of 0.5, maximum timestep of 2e-8 seconds, and output results every 5e-5 seconds. Use localEuler time discretization, vanLeer reconstruction schemes for density and temperature, vanLeerV for velocity, and include wallHeatFlux and sampling functions for post-processing along the biconic surface.

Conduct a compressible high-speed gas jet simulation using rhoCentralFoam solver with Kurganov flux scheme. The domain is a 2D axisymmetric wedge geometry with convertToMeters factor of 0.001, spanning 30mm in length and 10mm in height, discretized with 60x10x1 cells using two hexahedral blocks. Apply inlet boundary conditions at the jet nozzle (x=0, y=0-5mm), outlet conditions at the domain exit (x=30mm), freestreamInlet conditions at the upper inlet boundary (y=10mm, x=0), and freestream conditions along the top boundary (y=10mm). Use wedge boundary conditions for the axisymmetric faces with a 1-degree half-angle. Set the working fluid as air with molecular weight 28.96 kg/kmol, constant pressure specific heat Cp=1004.5 J/kg-K, Sutherland transport model with As=1.458e-06 and Ts=110.4K, and Prandtl number of 1.0. Run laminar simulation from startTime 0 to endTime 2e-05 seconds with initial timestep 1e-10 seconds, adaptive timestepping enabled with maximum Courant number 0.5, and output results at writeInterval 2e-05 seconds using Euler time discretization and vanLeer reconstruction schemes.

Perform a compressible oblique shock wave simulation using rhoCentralFoam solver with Kurganov flux scheme. The domain is a 2D rectangular channel with dimensions 4.1 x 1 x 0.1 units (convertToMeters factor of 1), meshed with 60x30x1 cells using uniform grading. Set inlet boundary conditions with fixed velocity of (2.9, 0, 0) m/s, fixed pressure of 1 Pa, and fixed temperature of 1 K. The top wall has fixed velocity of (2.61933, -0.50632, 0) m/s and fixed temperature of 1.25853 K to simulate oblique shock conditions. Apply zeroGradient conditions at the outlet for velocity, pressure, and temperature. Use symmetryPlane boundary condition at the bottom wall and empty conditions for front and back faces for 2D simulation. Set perfect gas equation of state with molecular weight of 11640.3, constant specific heat Cp of 2.5, zero viscosity (inviscid flow), and Prandtl number of 1. Run laminar simulation from time 0 to 10 with initial timestep of 0.0025, adaptive time stepping enabled with maximum Courant number of 0.2, and output results every 1 time unit using adjustable runtime control.

Conduct a compressible transient simulation of a moving cone using rhoCentralFoam solver with dynamic mesh capabilities. The domain features an axisymmetric wedge geometry with a cone that moves in the x-direction at 160 m/s initially, then transitions through different motion phases controlled by mesh-to-mesh topology changes at times 0.0015s and 0.003s. Boundary conditions include: movingWall with movingWallVelocity type, farFieldMoving and farField with noSlip conditions, fixedWall with noSlip boundary, left boundary with pressureInletOutletVelocity and totalPressure conditions, and front/back faces as wedge boundaries. Initial conditions specify uniform velocity field (0,0,0) m/s, temperature of 300K, and pressure of 1e5 Pa. The fluid is modeled as a perfect gas with molecular weight 28.9 kg/kmol, constant pressure specific heat Cp=1007 J/kg-K, dynamic viscosity μ=1e-3 Pa-s, and Prandtl number 0.7. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 2 outer correctors, 2 correctors, transonic formulation enabled, and density limits of 0.1-100 kg/m³. The simulation runs from 0 to 0.00002s with initial timestep of 1e-8s, adaptive timestepping with maxCo=0.2, and output every 5e-7s. Employ Kurganov flux scheme, Euler temporal discretization, and velocityComponentLaplacian motion solver with x-component diffusivity (1,200,0) for dynamic mesh motion.

Conduct a steady-state rotating reference frame simulation using SRFSimpleFoam solver for a mixer geometry with cylindrical domain featuring inner and outer walls, inlet and outlet boundaries, and cyclic periodic boundaries (cyclic_half0 and cyclic_half1). Set the rotating reference frame with origin at (0,0,0), rotation axis along z-direction (0,0,1), and rotation speed of 1000 rpm. Apply inlet boundary conditions with fixed velocity of (0,0,-10) m/s in absolute frame using SRFVelocity type, outlet with fixed pressure of 0 Pa and pressureInletOutletVelocity, no-slip condition on innerWall, and SRFVelocity with zero inlet value on outerWall. Use kOmegaSST turbulence model with initial turbulent kinetic energy k=0.375 m²/s², specific dissipation rate omega=3.5 s⁻¹, and turbulent dissipation rate epsilon=14.855 m²/s³. Set kinematic viscosity nu=1.5e-05 m²/s and run simulation from time 0 to 1000 with timestep of 1 and output results every 100 timesteps. Apply SIMPLE algorithm with consistent formulation, no non-orthogonal correctors, and relaxation factor of 0.9 for all equations.

Conduct a shallow water flow simulation using shallowWaterFoam solver over a square domain with dimensions 1x1x0.1 units (convertToMeters = 1) meshed with 20x20x1 cells. Set initial water depth (h) to 0.01 m uniformly and initial momentum flux (hU) to (0.001, 0, 0) m²/s. Apply a square bump disturbance at the center region (0.45≤x≤0.55, 0.45≤y≤0.55) with reduced water depth of 0.009 m and momentum flux of (0.0009, 0, 0) m²/s. Boundary conditions include slip conditions on side walls, fixed momentum flux of (0.001, 0, 0) m²/s at the inlet, zero gradient at the outlet, fixed water depth of 0.01 m at the outlet, and empty conditions for front and back faces (2D simulation). Use PIMPLE algorithm with 3 outer correctors, 1 corrector, and momentum predictor enabled. Set gravitational acceleration to -9.81 m/s² in z-direction with Earth's rotation (Omega = 7.292e-5 rad/s). Run simulation from time 0 to 100 seconds with timestep of 0.1 seconds and output results every 1 second using Crank-Nicolson time scheme with blending factor 0.9.

Perform a 2D rotating reference frame simulation using SRFPimpleFoam solver to analyze incompressible turbulent flow around a rotor geometry. The domain is a 2D configuration with front and back faces designated as empty boundaries to enforce 2D flow characteristics. The rotor boundary uses no-slip wall conditions with k-epsilon wall functions (kqRWallFunction for turbulent kinetic energy, epsilonWallFunction for dissipation rate, and nutkWallFunction for turbulent viscosity). The freestream boundary employs SRFFreestreamVelocity with inlet velocity of 1 m/s in the x-direction and inletOutlet conditions for turbulence parameters. The rotating reference frame rotates at 60 rpm about the z-axis with origin at (0,0,0). Use PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 2 pressure correctors, and zero non-orthogonal correctors. Initial turbulent kinetic energy is set to 3.75e-3 m²/s², turbulent dissipation rate to 3.75e-4 m²/s³, and kinematic viscosity to 1e-05 m²/s. The simulation runs from time 0 to 2 seconds with a timestep of 2e-4 seconds and outputs results every 2e-2 seconds using k-epsilon RAS turbulence model with Euler time discretization and limited linear schemes for convective terms.

do an incompressible laminar flow simulation through an elbow geometry using icoFoam solver with PISO algorithm. The domain represents a 2D elbow configuration with two velocity inlets and one pressure outlet, with wall boundaries defining the elbow shape and frontAndBackPlanes treated as empty for 2D simulation. Boundary conditions specify velocity-inlet-5 with fixed velocity of (1 0 0) m/s in the x-direction, velocity-inlet-6 with fixed velocity of (0 3 0) m/s in the y-direction, pressure-outlet-7 with fixed pressure of 0 Pa, and no-slip conditions for wall-4 and wall-8. Use kinematic viscosity (nu) of 0.01 m²/s. The simulation runs from time 0 to 10 seconds with a timestep of 0.05 seconds, outputting results every 20 timesteps (every 1 second). Configure PISO algorithm with 2 correctors and 2 non-orthogonal correctors, using PCG solver with DIC preconditioner for pressure (tolerance 1e-06, relTol 0.05) and smoothSolver with symGaussSeidel smoother for velocity (tolerance 1e-05).

do an incompressible lid driven cavity flow simulation using icoFoam solver. The cavity is a unit square domain with dimensions 1x1 in the x and y directions and 0.1 in the z-direction, with a convertToMeters factor of 0.1 making the actual physical dimensions 0.1m x 0.1m x 0.01m. Use a non-uniform mesh with 4 blocks each containing 10x10x1 cells and graded mesh refinement (simpleGrading factors of 2, 0.5, and combinations thereof for different blocks). The top wall ('movingWall') moves in the x-direction with a uniform velocity of 1 m/s using fixedValue boundary condition, while all other walls ('fixedWalls') have no-slip boundary conditions. Apply zeroGradient pressure boundary conditions on all walls, and designate the front and back faces as 'empty' for 2D simulation. The simulation runs from startTime 0.5 to endTime 0.7 with a timestep of 0.0025, outputting results every 40 timesteps. Use kinematic viscosity (nu) of 0.01 m²/s and employ PISO algorithm with 2 pressure correctors and no non-orthogonal correctors, with pressure reference cell 0 and reference value 0.

Perform an incompressible lid-driven cavity flow simulation using icoFoam solver with PISO algorithm. The domain is a clipped L-shaped cavity with dimensions spanning 0 to 1 in x-direction, 0 to 1 in y-direction, and 0 to 0.1 in z-direction (scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.1). The geometry consists of three hexahedral blocks: a lower-left block (12x8x1 cells), an upper-left block (12x12x1 cells), and an upper-right block (8x12x1 cells). Boundary conditions specify the lid (top walls) with a fixed velocity of 1 m/s in the x-direction, fixedWalls (remaining walls) with no-slip conditions, and frontAndBack faces as empty for 2D simulation. The simulation runs from startTime 0.5 to endTime 0.6 with a timestep of 0.005, outputting results every 20 timesteps. Use kinematic viscosity (nu) of 0.01 m²/s, PISO algorithm with 2 correctors and 0 non-orthogonal correctors, and pressure reference cell 0 with reference value 0.

Perform a steady-state incompressible turbulent flow simulation using simpleFoam solver with SIMPLE algorithm and k-omega SST turbulence model. The domain is a rectangular box with dimensions -1.26 to 1.26 in x-direction, -2.01 to 2.01 in y-direction, and -1.26 to 1.26 in z-direction with convertToMeters factor of 1. Use a structured mesh with 12x22x12 cells in x, y, and z directions respectively. Set boundary conditions with inlet having fixed velocity of (0 1 0) m/s, turbulent kinetic energy k of 0.02 m²/s², and specific dissipation rate omega of 10.0 1/s, outlet with pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocity and fixed pressure of 0 Pa, and slip boundary conditions for all slip-named patches. Set kinematic viscosity nu to 1.5e-05 m²/s². Run steady-state simulation from time 0 to 1000 with timestep of 1 and output results every 50 timesteps. Use GAMG solver for pressure with tolerance 1e-6 and smoothSolver for velocity and turbulence variables with relaxation factors of 0.95 for equations.

Perform a steady-state incompressible turbulent flow simulation for room residence time analysis using simpleFoam solver with SIMPLE algorithm and k-epsilon RAS turbulence model. The domain represents a room geometry with walls, inlet, and outlet patches. Set inlet boundary conditions with fixed velocity of 1.68 m/s in x-direction, turbulent intensity of 14%, and mixing length of 0.0168 m for turbulence quantities (k=0.08 m²/s², epsilon=0.23 m²/s³). Apply no-slip boundary conditions on walls with wall functions for turbulent quantities (epsilonWallFunction, kqRWallFunction, nutkWallFunction). Configure outlet with fixed pressure of 0 Pa, pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocity, and inletOutlet conditions for turbulence parameters. Use kinematic viscosity of 1.56225e-05 m²/s and run simulation from time 0 to 2000 with timestep of 1 and output results every 250 timesteps. Set SIMPLE residual control tolerances to 1e-3 for pressure and 1e-4 for velocity and turbulence quantities, with relaxation factors of 0.95 for velocity and 0.7 for turbulence parameters.

Perform a steady-state incompressible turbulent pipe flow simulation using simpleFoam solver with SIMPLE algorithm and realizableKE turbulence model. The domain is a cylindrical pipe with length 10 units and radius 0.5 units, with convertToMeters factor of 1, discretized using 50x5x5 cells in axial, radial, and circumferential directions respectively. Apply a coded swirl velocity inlet boundary condition at the inlet (x=0) with axial velocity of 1 m/s and tangential velocity components, turbulent intensity of 5%, and mixing length of 0.5 for epsilon calculation. Set the outlet (x=10) with totalPressure boundary condition at 0 Pa and pressureInletOutletVelocity for velocity. Apply no-slip boundary conditions on the pipe walls with appropriate wall functions for k, epsilon, and nut. Use cyclic boundary conditions for side1 and side2 patches. Set kinematic viscosity (nu) to 1e-06 m²/s, run the simulation for 1000 time units with unit timestep, and output results every 100 timesteps. Configure SIMPLE algorithm with relaxation factors of 0.3 for pressure and 0.7 for velocity and turbulence variables, with residual control tolerances of 1e-2 for pressure and 1e-3 for velocity and turbulence quantities.

Perform a steady-state incompressible Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) of external flow around a DrivAer fastback vehicle model using simpleFoam solver with kOmegaSST turbulence model. The computational domain extends from x=-10 to x=30, y=-5 to y=5, and z=0 to z=8 meters with convertToMeters factor of 1. Use a structured mesh with 40x10x8 cells in x, y, and z directions respectively. Set inlet boundary condition with fixed velocity of 16 m/s in x-direction, freestream boundaries with freestreamVelocity of 16 m/s, ground and wall patches with no-slip conditions, and rotating wheel boundaries (frontWheels at origin (0,0,0.318) and rearWheels at (2.786,0,0.318)) with rotatingWallVelocity using wheel radius of 0.318 m and calculated omega based on inlet velocity. Apply SIMPLE algorithm with residual control of 1e-4 for pressure, velocity, and turbulence quantities, using relaxation factors of 0.3 for pressure and 0.7 for velocity and turbulence equations. Set kinematic viscosity nu=1.5e-05 m²/s, turbulent kinetic energy k=0.002 m²/s², and specific dissipation rate omega=1.0 s⁻¹ at inlet. Run simulation from startTime=0 to endTime=1000 with deltaT=1 and output results every 250 timesteps, including force coefficients calculation and streamline visualization around the vehicle.

Perform a steady-state incompressible turbulent flow simulation around a motorBike geometry using simpleFoam solver with SIMPLE algorithm and k-omega SST turbulence model. The computational domain is a rectangular box with dimensions 20 units in x-direction (from x=-5 to x=15), 8 units in y-direction (from y=-4 to y=4), and 8 units in z-direction (from z=0 to z=8) with convertToMeters factor of 1. Use a structured mesh with 20x8x8 cells in x, y, and z directions respectively. Set boundary conditions as follows: inlet patch with fixed velocity of 20 m/s in x-direction, turbulent kinetic energy k=0.24 m²/s², and specific dissipation rate omega=1.78 s⁻¹; outlet patch with inletOutlet velocity condition and fixed pressure of 0 Pa; lowerWall with moving wall velocity of 20 m/s in x-direction; motorBike surfaces with no-slip wall conditions; upperWall, front, and back patches with symmetryPlane conditions. Set kinematic viscosity nu=1.5e-05 m²/s and run the simulation from time 0 to 500 with timestep of 1 and output results every 100 timesteps using relaxation factors of 0.3 for pressure, 0.5 for velocity, and 0.5 for turbulence variables.

Perform a steady-state incompressible turbulent flow simulation using simpleFoam solver with SIMPLE algorithm and k-epsilon turbulence model. The domain represents the classic Pitz-Daily backward-facing step geometry with time-varying experimental inlet conditions using timeVaryingMappedFixedValue boundary conditions for velocity, turbulent kinetic energy (k=0.375 m²/s²), and turbulent dissipation rate (epsilon=14.855 m²/s³) at the inlet, zero gradient conditions at the outlet for velocity and turbulence parameters with fixed pressure (p=0), no-slip wall conditions on upperWall and lowerWall surfaces with appropriate wall functions (epsilonWallFunction, kqRWallFunction, nutkWallFunction), and empty boundary conditions for frontAndBack faces indicating 2D simulation. Set kinematic viscosity nu=1e-05 m²/s, run simulation from time 0 to 1000 with unit timestep deltaT=1, output results every 50 timesteps, use GAMG solver for pressure with tolerance 1e-06 and smoothSolver for velocity and turbulence variables with tolerance 1e-05, apply relaxation factors of 0.3 for pressure and 0.7 for velocity and turbulence equations, and include streamline visualization starting from coordinates (-0.0205, 0.001, 0.00001) to (-0.0205, 0.0251, 0.00001) with 10 seed points.

Perform a steady-state incompressible flow simulation over a 2D airfoil using simpleFoam solver with Spalart-Allmaras turbulence model. The domain features an airfoil geometry with freestream velocity conditions of (25.75, 3.62, 0) m/s at both inlet and outlet boundaries using freestreamVelocity and freestreamPressure boundary conditions, no-slip conditions on the airfoil walls, and empty boundary conditions on frontAndBack faces for 2D simulation. Use SIMPLE algorithm with relaxation factors of 0.3 for pressure and 0.7 for velocity and nuTilda, running from startTime 0 to endTime 500 with timestep deltaT of 1 and output every 50 timesteps. Set fluid properties with constant density of 1 kg/m³ and kinematic viscosity nu of 1e-05 m²/s, initialize nuTilda field with uniform value of 0.14 m²/s, and apply nutUSpaldingWallFunction for turbulent viscosity on walls with convergence criteria of 1e-5 for all variables.

Perform a turbine siting simulation using simpleFoam solver for atmospheric boundary layer flow around wind turbines. The domain is a rectangular box with dimensions 969m x 870m x 570m (convertToMeters = 1) representing a real-world terrain section with coordinates from (581321, 4.78537e+06, 930) to (582290, 4.78624e+06, 1500). Use a 30x30x20 structured mesh with simple grading. Apply atmospheric boundary layer inlet conditions at the inlet patch with atmBoundaryLayerInletVelocity, atmBoundaryLayerInletK, and atmBoundaryLayerInletEpsilon. Set the outlet as inletOutlet type, ground as wall with no-slip conditions, terrain with wall functions (epsilonWallFunction, kqRWallFunction, nutkAtmRoughWallFunction), and sides/top as patches with appropriate boundary conditions. Include two actuation disk sources representing wind turbines: disk1 at location (581850.5-581850.8, 4785805-4785815, 1061-1071) with Cp=0.386, Ct=0.58, disk area=40m², and disk2 at location (581754-581754.4, 4785658-4785668, 1065-1075) with Cp=0.53, Ct=0.58, disk area=40m². Use SIMPLE algorithm with k-epsilon RAS turbulence model, kinematic viscosity nu=1.5e-05 m²/s, steady-state simulation running for 5000 iterations with timestep=1 and output every 50 iterations. Set solver tolerances for pressure (1e-7), velocity (1e-8), k and epsilon (1e-8) with relaxation factors of 0.3 for pressure and 0.7 for velocity and turbulence variables.

Perform a steady-state incompressible turbulent flow simulation using simpleFoam solver with kOmegaSSTLM (k-omega SST Langtry-Menter) transition turbulence model over a flat plate. The domain is a 2D channel with inlet velocity of 5.4 m/s in the x-direction, zero gradient pressure at outlet, no-slip boundary condition on the plate surface, slip conditions on the above and top boundaries, and empty conditions for frontAndBack faces indicating 2D flow. Set kinematic viscosity (nu) to 1.5e-5 m²/s, initial turbulent kinetic energy (k) to 0.047633 m²/s², specific dissipation rate (omega) to 264.63 s⁻¹, momentum thickness Reynolds number (ReThetat) to 160.99, and intermittency factor (gammaInt) to 1. Use SIMPLE algorithm with consistent formulation, run simulation from time 0 to 1000 with timestep of 1, output results every 500 timesteps, and include wall shear stress monitoring along the plate from x=0.04075 to x=3.04 at y=0.00075, plus turbulent kinetic energy monitoring at y=0.05 along the same x-range.

Perform a steady-state incompressible turbulent flow simulation around buildings using simpleFoam solver with SIMPLE algorithm and k-epsilon turbulence model. The domain contains building geometries defined by "buildings.obj" file within a computational domain bounded by a refinement box with dimensions 250x180x90 units. Set inlet boundary conditions with fixed velocity of 10 m/s in x-direction, turbulent kinetic energy k of 1.5 m²/s², and turbulent dissipation rate epsilon of 0.03 m²/s³. Apply pressureInletOutletVelocity at outlet with totalPressure boundary condition, and noSlip wall conditions with epsilonWallFunction and kqRWallFunction for turbulence quantities on building surfaces. Use kinematic viscosity nu of 1.5e-05 m²/s and run simulation from time 0 to 400 with timestep of 1, outputting results every 50 timesteps. Generate mesh using snappyHexMesh with refinement level 3 on building surfaces, level 2 inside refinement box, and level 1 for building features, with insidePoint at coordinates (1,1,1). Apply SIMPLE pressure-velocity coupling with residual control tolerances of 1e-4 for pressure, velocity, and turbulence quantities, using relaxation factors of 0.3 for pressure and 0.7 for velocity and turbulence equations.

Perform a Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) of secondary flow in a rectangular duct using simpleFoam solver with LRR turbulence model and SIMPLE algorithm. The domain is a rectangular duct with dimensions 0.1m x 0.0525m x 0.001m (length x height x width) scaled by convertToMeters factor of 1, meshed with 134x70x1 cells using simpleGrading. Apply cyclic boundary conditions at inlet and outlet faces to simulate fully developed flow, no-slip conditions on bottomWall and leftWall, and symmetryPlane conditions on topSymmetry and rightSymmetry faces. Initialize the flow field with uniform velocity of (0 0 1.95) m/s in the z-direction, turbulent kinetic energy k=0.01 m²/s², turbulent dissipation rate epsilon=0.00613 m²/s³, and Reynolds stress tensor R=(0.00497 0 0 0.00497 0 0.00497) m²/s². Set kinematic viscosity nu=1e-6 m²/s and apply meanVelocityForce constraint to maintain bulk velocity Ubar=(0 0 1.95) m/s. Run steady-state simulation for 20000 iterations with deltaT=1 and output results every 1000 iterations, using residual control tolerances of 5e-5 for pressure, 1e-5 for velocity, epsilon, and Reynolds stress components.

Conduct a Large Eddy Simulation (LES) of turbulent channel flow using pimpleFoam solver with WALE subgrid-scale model. The domain is a periodic channel with no-slip boundary conditions on the top and bottom walls (topWall and bottomWall), and cyclic boundary conditions on all other faces (sides1_half0/1, sides2_half0/1, inout1_half0/1, inout2_half0/1) to simulate fully developed turbulent flow. Initialize the flow with uniform velocity of 0.1335 m/s in the x-direction throughout the domain. Apply a mean velocity forcing constraint to maintain constant bulk velocity of 0.1335 m/s using meanVelocityForce. Set kinematic viscosity (nu) to 2e-05 m²/s. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 2 pressure correctors, and 0 non-orthogonal correctors. Run the simulation from time 0 to 1000 time units with a timestep of 0.2, outputting results every 200 timesteps (every 40 time units). Apply backward time differencing scheme for temporal discretization and linear spatial schemes for gradients and interpolation. Include field averaging functions to compute mean and fluctuating velocity components, turbulent kinetic energy, and layer-averaged statistics along the wall-normal direction for post-processing analysis of turbulent channel flow statistics.

Perform a Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) of an impeller flow using pimpleFoam solver with k-epsilon turbulence model and dynamic mesh motion. The domain consists of a rotating impeller with rotor blades and ducts, where the rotating cellZone rotates about the x-axis at 6.2832 rad/s (1 Hz) with origin at (0,0,0). Boundary conditions include pressureInletOutletVelocity at inlet and outlet patches with entrainmentPressure (p0=0), no-slip conditions for statorDuct and stationary nonCouple surfaces, movingWallVelocity for rotorDuct and rotorBlades, and movingWallSlipVelocity for rotating nonCouple surfaces. Initial conditions are uniform velocity (0,0,0) m/s, pressure 0 Pa, turbulent kinetic energy k=0.00015 m²/s², and dissipation rate epsilon=0.0002025 m²/s³. Use kinematic viscosity nu=1e-05 m²/s², timestep of 1e-3 s with adjustable time stepping (maxCo=1.0), simulation time from 0 to 5 seconds, and output results every 0.05 seconds. Apply PIMPLE algorithm with 2 outer correctors, 1 corrector, and include flow rate monitoring functions for inlet and outlet patches plus cylindrical coordinate transformation for velocity field analysis.

Perform a steady-state incompressible turbulent flow simulation around a 2D wing using simpleFoam solver with SIMPLE algorithm and k-omega SST turbulence model. The domain is a 2D extruded mesh with thickness of 0.05 units created from a 3D snappyHexMesh case, where the wing is located at center of rotation coordinates (0.4974612746, -0.01671895744, 0.125). Apply inlet boundary conditions with fixed velocity and turbulent properties, inletOutlet boundary condition at the outlet with zero inletValue for velocity, movingWallVelocity boundary condition on the wing surface with zero value, zeroGradient pressure condition at inlet and wing, and fixedValue pressure at outlet. Set kinematic viscosity nu to 1e-05 m²/s with density rhoInf of 1 kg/m³. Run simulation from time 0 to 3000 with timestep of 1, outputting results every 100 time units and force calculations every 10 timesteps on the wing patch. Use GAMG solver for pressure with tolerance 1e-7 and smoothSolver with GaussSeidel smoother for velocity and turbulence variables with tolerance 1e-8, applying relaxation factors of 0.3 for pressure and 0.7 for velocity and turbulence equations. Configure front and back patches as empty boundary type for 2D simulation characteristics.

do a wing motion simulation using pimpleFoam solver with snappyHexMesh meshing. The domain is a rectangular box with dimensions 6.2 x 4.4 x 0.2 units (convertToMeters 1), extending from x=-1.2 to x=5, y=-2.2 to y=2.2, and z=-0.1 to z=0.1. Use a structured hexahedral mesh with 36x24x1 cells and simple grading (1 1 1). Boundary conditions include patch type for topAndBottom faces (top and bottom walls), inlet patch at x=-1.2, outlet patch at x=5, and symmetric patches for front (symFront at z=0.1) and back (symBack at z=-0.1) faces. Use PISO algorithm with 2 correctors and 2 non-orthogonal correctors. Apply smoothSolver with symGaussSeidel smoother for pressure with tolerance 1e-12, and the same solver settings for velocity, energy, and turbulence variables with tolerance 1e-08. Set up parallel decomposition for 3 processors using simple method with distribution (1 3 1). Run simulation from time 0 to 100 with timestep of 1 and output results every 1 time unit. Use Euler time discretization scheme, Gauss linear gradient schemes, and limitedLinearV divergence scheme for velocity with upwind schemes for turbulence variables.

Perform a 2D incompressible wing motion simulation using pimpleFoam solver with dynamic mesh capabilities. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 2 outer correctors, 1 corrector, and 0 non-orthogonal correctors, along with phi correction enabled. Implement RAS turbulence modeling with kOmegaSST model. Set kinematic viscosity (nu) to 1e-05 m²/s. Configure the simulation to run from time 0 to 5 seconds with an initial timestep of 1e-5 seconds and adjustable timestepping enabled with maximum Courant number of 0.9. Output results every 0.01 seconds using adjustable run time control. Apply relaxation factors of 0.3 for pressure and 0.7 for velocity and turbulence equations. Use GAMG solver for pressure correction and cell displacement with Gauss-Seidel smoother, and smoothSolver with symGaussSeidel smoother for velocity and turbulence variables. Include sixDoFRigidBodyState function to monitor the wing's motion state with angle output in degrees, and enable parallel processing with domain decomposition into 4 subdomains using simple method with 2x2x1 distribution.

Do a Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) incompressible turbulent flow simulation around an elliptical obstacle using pimpleFoam solver with kkLOmega turbulence model. The domain is a 2D channel geometry with an elliptical hole obstruction, where the inlet boundary has a fixed velocity of 3.1 m/s in the x-direction, the outlet uses inletOutlet boundary condition with zero reference values, the upper boundary ('up') has symmetry conditions, the elliptical hole ('hole') has no-slip wall conditions with nutLowReWallFunction for turbulent viscosity and zeroGradient for omega, and frontAndBack faces are empty for 2D simulation. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 2 correctors, 1 non-orthogonal corrector, adjustable time stepping with maximum Courant number of 0.2, starting from time 0 to end time 1 with initial timestep of 0.001, and output results every 0.01 time units. Set kinematic viscosity (nu) to 1.86e-05 m²/s, initialize internal velocity field uniformly at 3.1 m/s in x-direction, and set initial omega field to uniform 1e-5 s⁻¹ with kl and kt turbulent kinetic energy fields initialized to zero.

Conduct a Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) incompressible flow simulation using pimpleFoam solver with kOmegaSST turbulence model. The domain is a 3D rectangular channel with dimensions 5 units length, 3 units height, and 2 units width (convertToMeters factor of 1), featuring an open boundary at the top atmosphere patch. Use a structured mesh with 100x20x1 cells in each of the three blocks stacked vertically. Set boundary conditions as follows: inlet patch with fixed velocity of 1 m/s in x-direction, fixed temperature of 1 K, fixed turbulent kinetic energy k=0.001 m²/s², and fixed specific dissipation rate omega=1 s⁻¹; outlet patch with zero gradient velocity and pressure fixed at 0 Pa; walls with no-slip velocity condition and zero gradient temperature; atmosphere patch with totalPressure boundary at 0 Pa, pressureInletOutletVelocity, and inletOutlet temperature condition. Use kinematic viscosity nu=1e-05 m²/s², PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 2 correctors, and 1 non-orthogonal corrector. Run simulation from time 0 to 100 seconds with timestep of 0.02 seconds, outputting results every 2 seconds. Include scalar transport for temperature field with unit diffusivity coefficients.

Perform a Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) of incompressible turbulent flow through a T-junction geometry using pimpleFoam solver with k-epsilon turbulence model. The domain consists of a main horizontal channel (0.2m x 0.02m x 0.02m) with two perpendicular outlet branches extending 0.2m vertically from the junction point at x=0.2m, with convertToMeters factor of 1. The mesh uses 50x5x5 cells for the main channel and 5x50x5 cells for each outlet branch. Boundary conditions specify a time-varying uniform total pressure at the inlet (10 Pa at t=0 to 40 Pa at t=1s), fixed pressure of 10 Pa at outlet1 (bottom branch) and 0 Pa at outlet2 (top branch), with no-slip conditions on all walls (defaultFaces). Use PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 2 correctors, turbulent intensity of 5% and mixing length of 0.01m at inlet, kinematic viscosity nu=1e-05 m²/s, density rho=1.2 kg/m³. Run simulation from t=0 to t=1.5s with adaptive timestep (initial deltaT=0.001s, maxCo=5) and output results every 0.1s. Include Lagrangian particle tracking with 1000 particles/second injection of 100 micron diameter particles (density 964 kg/m³) from inlet with rebound wall interaction, and monitor pressure and velocity at four probe locations including junction center and outlet branch centers.

do a Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) turbulent flow simulation using pimpleFoam solver with k-epsilon turbulence model and Local Time Stepping (LTS). The domain is a 2D backward-facing step geometry (Pitz-Daily case) with empty frontAndBack patches indicating 2D flow characteristics. Boundary conditions specify a fixed velocity of 10 m/s in the x-direction at the inlet with turbulent kinetic energy k = 0.375 m²/s² and dissipation rate epsilon = 14.855 m²/s³, zero gradient conditions at the outlet for velocity, k, and epsilon with fixed pressure of 0 Pa, and no-slip wall conditions for upperWall and lowerWall with appropriate wall functions (epsilonWallFunction, kqRWallFunction, nutkWallFunction). Use PIMPLE algorithm with 2 correctors, maximum Courant number of 1, and local Euler time scheme for adaptive time stepping with maximum deltaT of 1 second. Set kinematic viscosity nu = 1e-05 m²/s, run simulation from time 0 to 1000 seconds with initial timestep of 1 second, and output results every 10 seconds using runTime writeControl.

Perform a Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) of incompressible turbulent flow through an oscillating inlet channel using pimpleFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm. The domain consists of two connected rectangular channels: an inlet channel with dimensions 1×0.4×0.1 units (x×y×z) located at coordinates 0≤x≤1, 0.3≤y≤0.7, 0≤z≤0.1, and a main channel with dimensions 2×1×0.1 units extending from 1≤x≤3, 0≤y≤1, 0≤z≤0.1, with convertToMeters factor of 1. The inlet channel oscillates with amplitude 0.5 units in y-direction at frequency omega=3.14 rad/s using solidBody motion solver. Use a mesh of 80×40×1 cells for the inlet channel and 80×96×1 cells for the main channel. Boundary conditions specify fixed velocity of 1 m/s in x-direction at the inlet, pressureInletOutletVelocity at the outlet with fixed pressure of 0 Pa, and movingWallVelocity for all walls. Apply realizableKE turbulence model with initial turbulent kinetic energy k=3.75e-3 m²/s², turbulent dissipation rate epsilon=1.8e-3 m²/s³, and specific dissipation rate omega=5.33333 s⁻¹. Set kinematic viscosity nu=1e-6 m²/s and run simulation from time 0 to 5 seconds with adaptive timestep (maxCo=0.5, initial deltaT=0.005), outputting results every 0.05 seconds while monitoring inlet and outlet flow rates.

Perform a Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) of incompressible turbulent flow through a T-junction geometry using pimpleFoam solver with k-epsilon turbulence model. The domain consists of a main horizontal channel (0.2m x 0.02m x 0.02m) with two perpendicular outlet branches extending 0.2m vertically from the junction point at x=0.2m, with convertToMeters factor of 1. The mesh uses 50x5x5 cells for the main channel, 5x5x5 cells for the junction region, and 5x50x5 cells for each vertical outlet branch. Boundary conditions specify a time-varying uniform total pressure at the inlet (10 Pa at t=0 ramping to 40 Pa at t=1s), fixed pressure of 10 Pa at outlet1 (bottom branch) and 0 Pa at outlet2 (top branch), with no-slip conditions on all walls (defaultFaces). Use PIMPLE algorithm with 1 outer corrector, 2 correctors, and 0 non-orthogonal correctors. Set kinematic viscosity nu=1e-05 m²/s, initial turbulent kinetic energy k=0.375 m²/s², turbulent dissipation rate epsilon=200 m²/s³, and turbulence intensity of 5% at the inlet with mixing length of 0.01m. Run simulation from t=0 to t=1.5s with initial timestep of 0.001s (adjustable with maxCo=3) and output results every 0.1s, including pressure and velocity probes at four locations within the junction region.

Perform a Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) wave interaction with subsurface flow using pimpleFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm. The domain is a 3D rectangular channel with dimensions 24 meters length, 3.6 meters width (-1.8 to 1.8), and 2 meters height, with convertToMeters factor of 1. Use a structured mesh of 40x24x96 cells with two blocks: first block (20x24x72 cells) with simple grading (1 4 1) and second block (20x24x24 cells) with grading (1 4 6). Boundary conditions include: bottom wall with no-slip velocity, epsilonWallFunction, kqRWallFunction, and nutkWallFunction; top and inlet patches with waveVelocity, waveAlpha, and inletOutlet conditions for turbulence; outlet with pressureInletOutletVelocity, totalPressure, and inletOutlet for turbulence; front and back faces as symmetryPlane. Wave properties specify Stokes5 waves with wavelength 5.64m, amplitude 0.3m, phase 0.8, depth 2.7m, origin at (0 0 2.7), and wave scaling from 1 at x=18m to 0 at x=24m. Use k-epsilon turbulence model with initial k=1.4e-4 m²/s² and epsilon=1.4e-6 m²/s³. Set kinematic viscosity nu=1e-05 m²/s, gravity g=(0 0 -9.81) m/s², timestep=0.01s, endTime=100s, and output every 1 second. Configure PIMPLE with 2 outer correctors, 1 corrector, and 0 non-orthogonal correctors.

do a laminar planar Poiseuille flow simulation using pimpleFoam solver with Maxwell viscoelastic model. The domain is a 2D channel with dimensions 2 units wide by 10 units tall by 2 units deep (scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.1). Use a structured mesh with 1x40x1 cells with grading factor of 4 in the y-direction. Apply cyclic boundary conditions on left and right patches, no-slip wall boundary condition on the bottom wall, symmetryPlane condition on the centreline (top), and empty conditions on front and back faces for 2D simulation. Set kinematic viscosity nu = 0.1 m²/s, Maxwell model parameters nuM = 1 and lambda = 5. Apply a momentum source term of (5 0 0) in the x-direction throughout the domain. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 15 outer correctors, 3 correctors, momentum predictor off, and no non-orthogonal correctors. Run simulation from time 0 to 25 with timestep of 0.005 and output results every 1 time unit. Include function objects for residuals monitoring, velocity profile extraction along a vertical line from (0 0 0) to (0 1 0), and velocity probes at point (0 1 0).

Perform a laminar incompressible flow simulation using pimpleFoam solver for a non-conformal channel configuration. The domain features a channel geometry with cyclicAMI interfaces for non-conformal mesh coupling between upper and lower sections, with inlet boundary conditions set to fixed velocity of 1 m/s in the x-direction, outlet using pressureInletOutletVelocity boundary condition, no-slip walls, and slip conditions for non-couple patches. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 2 correctors and 0 non-orthogonal correctors, kinematic viscosity (nu) of 1e-4 m²/s for laminar flow simulation. Run the simulation from start time 0 to end time 1 second with a fixed timestep of 0.005 seconds, outputting results every 0.1 seconds using adjustable runtime write control, and include flow rate monitoring functions for both inlet and outlet patches with maximum Courant number limit of 5.

Perform a laminar incompressible flow simulation using pimpleFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm for a 2D backward-facing step geometry (Pitz-Daily configuration). The inlet boundary uses a coded uniformFixedValue condition implementing a pulse velocity profile with the formula 0.5*(1 - cos(2π*min(t/0.3, 1))) in the x-direction, while the outlet has zeroGradient velocity and fixedValue pressure of 0 Pa. The upperWall and lowerWall boundaries have noSlip conditions with zeroGradient pressure, and frontAndBack faces are designated as empty for 2D simulation. Set the kinematic viscosity (nu) to 1e-4 m²/s with laminar momentum transport model. Use a timestep of 0.001 seconds with adjustable time stepping enabled (maxCo = 5), run from startTime 0 to endTime 1 second, and output results every 0.02 seconds using adjustableRunTime writeControl. Configure PIMPLE algorithm with 2 correctors and 0 non-orthogonal correctors, using GAMG solver for pressure with 1e-7 tolerance and smoothSolver for velocity with 1e-5 tolerance.

Conduct a planar Couette flow simulation using pimpleFoam solver for laminar viscoelastic flow with Maxwell constitutive model. The domain is a rectangular channel with dimensions 1x1x0.1 units scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.1, making the actual dimensions 0.1x0.1x0.01 meters. Use a structured mesh of 20x20x1 cells. The top wall (movingWall) has a fixed velocity of 1 m/s in the x-direction, while the bottom wall (bottomWall) has no-slip boundary conditions. The left and right boundaries (cyc_half0 and cyc_half1) are cyclic to simulate infinite channel length, and the front and back faces are empty for 2D simulation. Set kinematic viscosity nu to 1.5e-05 m²/s with Maxwell viscoelastic model parameters: momentum diffusivity nuM of 1 and relaxation time lambda of 5. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 15 outer correctors, 3 pressure correctors, momentum predictor off, and backward time scheme. Run simulation from time 0 to 25 seconds with timestep of 0.005 seconds, outputting results every 0.5 seconds.

Perform a laminar viscoelastic planar contraction flow simulation using pimpleFoam solver with Maxwell constitutive model. The domain represents a 2D planar contraction geometry with dimensions scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.0032, where the upstream channel extends from x=-40 to x=0 with height from y=0 to y=4, the downstream channel extends from x=0 to x=30 with height from y=0 to y=1, creating a 4:1 contraction ratio, and the domain has unit thickness in z-direction (z=-1 to z=1). Apply boundary conditions with fixed inlet velocity of 0.03876 m/s in x-direction at the inlet patch, zero gradient velocity at the outlet, no-slip conditions (zero velocity) at all wall surfaces, symmetry plane condition at the centreline (y=0), zero gradient pressure at inlet and walls with fixed pressure of 0 Pa at outlet, and fixed stress tensor values at inlet with zero gradient elsewhere. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 15 outer correctors, momentum predictor off, and no non-orthogonal correctors. Set simulation time from 0 to 0.25 seconds with timestep of 2e-4 seconds and output results every 0.01 seconds. Configure physical properties with kinematic viscosity nu=1e-5 m²/s, Maxwell model parameters including polymeric viscosity nuM=0.002 and relaxation time lambda=0.03. Generate mesh with three hexahedral blocks using specified grading ratios: upstream block (40×12×1 cells), downstream block (30×12×1 cells), and upper block (40×24×1 cells) with appropriate geometric grading for flow resolution near walls and contraction region.

Perform a laminar incompressible flow simulation around an offset cylinder using pimpleFoam solver with PIMPLE algorithm. The domain is a 2D channel with a cylinder obstacle positioned off-center within the flow field. Boundary conditions specify a fixed velocity inlet of 1 m/s in the x-direction at the left boundary, zero gradient pressure outlet at the right boundary, no-slip conditions on the top and bottom walls as well as the cylinder surface, and empty conditions for front and back faces (defaultFaces) indicating 2D flow. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 5 outer correctors, 1 corrector, no momentum predictor, and no non-orthogonal correctors. The simulation runs from time 0 to 2 seconds with a timestep of 0.0025 seconds, outputting results every 0.05 seconds. Set kinematic viscosity (nu) to 0.01 m²/s for laminar flow conditions with generalized Newtonian viscosity model using CrossPowerLaw parameters (nuInf=10, m=0.4, n=3). Use Euler time scheme, least squares gradient scheme, and Gauss linear divergence schemes for numerical discretization.

Perform a steady-state incompressible turbulent flow simulation through a straight duct with porous media using porousSimpleFoam solver with SIMPLE algorithm and k-epsilon turbulence model. The domain consists of a straight duct geometry with a porous region defined by cellZone 'porosity' with Darcy-Forchheimer coefficients d=(5e7, -1000, -1000) and f=(0, 0, 0). Boundary conditions include: inlet with volumetric flow rate of 0.1 m³/s using turbulent boundary layer profile with 5% turbulence intensity and mixing length of 0.005 m, outlet with fixed pressure of 0 Pa and inletOutlet conditions for other variables, walls (front, back, walls) with no-slip velocity and wall functions for turbulence, porosityWall with slip velocity condition, and porosity region with zeroGradient for all variables. Set kinematic viscosity nu=1.5e-05 m²/s, initial temperature T=293 K with zeroGradient at walls and fixedValue at inlet. Use turbulent kinetic energy k=1 m²/s² and dissipation rate epsilon=200 m²/s³ as initial values. Run simulation from time 0 to 100 with timestep of 1 and output results every 10 timesteps using relaxation factors of 0.3 for pressure and 0.7, 0.9, 0.9 for velocity, k, and epsilon respectively.

Conduct a boundary layer wall function validation simulation using boundaryFoam solver with RAS k-epsilon turbulence model. The domain is a 2D channel geometry with dimensions 0.1 x 2.0 x 0.1 units scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.05 (resulting in actual dimensions of 0.005m x 0.1m x 0.005m). The mesh consists of 2 blocks with 1x40x1 cells each, creating a total grid of 1x80x1 cells. Boundary conditions include no-slip walls at lowerWall and upperWall with epsilonWallFunction, kqRWallFunction, and nutkWallFunction applied, cyclic boundary conditions between front and back faces, and empty conditions for defaultFaces to maintain 2D flow characteristics. Set the mean velocity Ubar to 10 m/s in x-direction, kinematic viscosity nu to 1e-05 m²/s, initial turbulent kinetic energy k to 1e-10 m²/s², initial epsilon to 1e-08 m²/s³, and initial turbulent viscosity nut to 0. Use steady-state time discretization with PISO algorithm having 2 correctors, run the simulation from time 0 to 3000 with timestep of 1, output results every 200 timesteps, and apply relaxation factors of 0.5 for velocity and 0.7 for turbulence quantities.

Perform a steady-state boundary layer flow simulation using boundaryFoam solver to analyze non-Newtonian fluid behavior in a channel. The domain is a rectangular channel with dimensions 0.1×2×0.1 units scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.05 (resulting in actual dimensions of 0.005×0.1×0.005 meters). The mesh consists of two blocks with 1×40×1 cells each, creating a total grid of 1×80×1 cells. Apply no-slip boundary conditions on the upper and lower walls, cyclic boundary conditions on the front and back faces, and empty conditions on the default faces. Set the initial velocity field to uniform (10 0 0) m/s throughout the domain with a mean velocity (Ubar) of 0.05 m/s in the x-direction. Use a generalized Newtonian laminar flow model with CrossPowerLaw viscosity model having parameters: nu0=0.01 m²/s, nuInf=10 m²/s, m=0.4 s, and n=3. Configure the simulation to run from time 0 to 1000 with a timestep of 1 and output results every 100 timesteps. Use PISO algorithm with 2 correctors, PCG solver with DIC preconditioner for velocity field, and apply relaxation factor of 0.3 for velocity equations.

Perform a turbulent boundary layer flow simulation using boundaryFoam solver with Launder-Sharma k-epsilon turbulence model. The domain is a 2D channel geometry with dimensions 0.1 x 2.0 x 0.1 units scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.05 (making actual dimensions 0.005m x 0.1m x 0.005m). The mesh consists of two blocks with 1x40x1 cells each, using grading of 100 near the lower wall and 0.01 near the upper wall to capture boundary layer effects. Initial flow field has uniform velocity of 10 m/s in x-direction throughout the domain. Boundary conditions specify no-slip walls at lowerWall and upperWall, cyclic conditions for front and back faces, and empty conditions for defaultFaces. Turbulent kinetic energy k is initialized to 0.1 m²/s² in the domain with fixedValue of 1e-10 m²/s² at walls, while epsilon is initialized to 10 m²/s³ with fixedValue of 1e-08 m²/s³ at walls. Use nutLowReWallFunction for turbulent viscosity at walls with Cmu=0.09, kappa=0.41, and E=9.8. The simulation runs from time 0 to 1000 with timestep of 1, outputting results every 100 timesteps. Set kinematic viscosity nu to 1e-05 m²/s and mean velocity Ubar to 10 m/s in x-direction. Use PISO algorithm with 2 correctors and steady-state time scheme with relaxation factors of 0.5 for velocity and 0.7 for turbulence quantities.

Perform a turbulent boundary layer wall function validation simulation using boundaryFoam solver with RAS k-epsilon turbulence model. The domain is a narrow channel with dimensions 0.005m x 0.1m x 0.005m (scaled by convertToMeters factor of 0.05 from normalized coordinates of 0.1 x 2 x 0.1). Use a structured mesh with 1x80x1 cells creating two blocks to capture the boundary layer profiles near both walls. Apply no-slip boundary conditions at the lowerWall and upperWall patches, cyclic boundary conditions for front and back faces, and empty conditions for defaultFaces to create a 2D simulation. Set initial velocity field to uniform 1 m/s in x-direction, turbulent kinetic energy k to 1e-09 m²/s², dissipation rate epsilon to 1e-08 m²/s³, and specific dissipation rate omega to 1111.11 s⁻¹. Use kinematic viscosity nu of 1e-8 m²/s and bulk velocity Ubar of 10 m/s in x-direction. Configure wall functions including epsilonWallFunction, nutkWallFunction, nutUSpaldingWallFunction, omegaWallFunction, and kqRWallFunction for proper near-wall treatment. Run steady-state simulation from time 0 to 1000 with timestep of 1 and output results every 100 timesteps using PISO algorithm with 2 correctors and relaxation factors of 0.5 for velocity and 0.7 for turbulence quantities.

Conduct a Large Eddy Simulation (LES) of incompressible turbulent flow through a backward-facing step geometry using pisoFoam solver with kEqn subgrid-scale model and cubeRootVol delta function. The domain represents the classic Pitz-Daily backward-facing step configuration with mapped inlet boundary conditions where the inlet velocity is set to uniform (10 0 0) m/s with mapped interpolation and average enforcement, turbulent kinetic energy k of 2e-05 m²/s² at the inlet, and modified viscosity nuTilda initialized to zero. Apply inletOutlet boundary conditions at the outlet with zero inletValue, fixedValue boundary conditions with zero velocity at both upperWall and lowerWall surfaces, zeroGradient pressure conditions at inlet and walls with fixedValue pressure of zero at outlet, and empty boundary conditions for frontAndBack faces indicating 2D simulation. Use kinematic viscosity nu of 1e-05 m²/s², PISO algorithm with 2 correctors and 0 non-orthogonal correctors, backward time differencing scheme, LUST scheme for momentum convection, limitedLinear schemes for turbulence quantities, and GAMG solver for pressure with 1e-07 tolerance and GaussSeidel smoother.

Do a Reynolds-Averaged Simulation (RAS) lid-driven cavity flow using pisoFoam solver with k-epsilon turbulence model. The cavity is a square with dimensions 1x1 units in the x and y directions and 0.1 units in the z-direction, scaled down by a convertToMeters factor of 0.1. Use a structured mesh of 20x20x1 cells with simple grading. The top wall (movingWall) has a fixed velocity of 1 m/s in the x-direction, while the remaining walls (fixedWalls) have no-slip boundary conditions, and the front and back faces are empty for 2D simulation. Set initial turbulent kinetic energy k to 0.00325 m²/s² and dissipation rate epsilon to 0.000765 m²/s³ with appropriate wall functions. Use PISO algorithm with 2 correctors and 0 non-orthogonal correctors, kinematic viscosity nu of 1e-05 m²/s², timestep of 0.005 seconds, simulation end time of 10 seconds, and output results every 100 timesteps.

Perform a laminar incompressible flow simulation through a porous blockage using pisoFoam solver with PISO algorithm. The domain is a rectangular channel with dimensions 8 units length (-2 to 6) by 4 units height (-2 to 2) by 0.2 units thickness (-0.1 to 0.1), creating an effectively 2D flow with convertToMeters factor of 1. Use a structured mesh of 64x32x1 cells. A porous blockage zone is defined in the central region from -0.5 to 0.5 in both x and y directions extending through the full thickness, with Darcy-Forchheimer porosity model having Darcy coefficient D=1000 and zero Forchheimer coefficients. Boundary conditions include: inlet (left face) with fixed velocity of 1 m/s in x-direction, outlet (right face) with pressureInletOutletVelocity condition, top and bottom faces as symmetryPlane, and frontAndBack faces as empty for 2D simulation. For pressure, apply zeroGradient at inlet and fixedValue of 0 at outlet. Set kinematic viscosity nu=5e-3 m²/s, run simulation from time 0 to 100 with timestep 0.05, output results every 1 time unit, use PISO with 2 correctors and 0 non-orthogonal correctors, and employ Euler time scheme with LUST divergence scheme for momentum.

Generate a mesh for a sphere geometry using blockMesh solver. The case is configured to run the blockMesh application with time parameters set from startTime 0 to endTime 10 with deltaT of 1, outputting results every 1 time step. The simulation uses ascii format with writePrecision of 6 and timeFormat set to general with timePrecision of 6. All numerical scheme dictionaries (ddtSchemes, gradSchemes, divSchemes, laplacianSchemes, interpolationSchemes, snGradSchemes) are empty as this is a mesh generation case rather than a flow simulation, with runTimeModifiable set to true and no write compression applied.

Generate a mesh for a sphere geometry using blockMesh utility. The case is named sphere7ProjectedEdges and focuses on mesh generation with projected edges for a spherical domain. The simulation runs from time 0 to 10 with a timestep of 1 and outputs results every timestep. The mesh generation utilizes blockMesh's projected edge functionality to create a high-quality hexahedral mesh around a spherical geometry, with particular attention to edge projection techniques for accurate representation of curved boundaries.

Conduct a two-phase flow simulation using interFoam solver to analyze fluid behavior in a pipe geometry. The domain consists of a pipe with wall boundaries defined by "pipe.obj" and "pipeWall.obj" surface files, with mesh generation using snappyHexMesh with castellated meshing enabled, snap on, and no boundary layers. Use PIMPLE algorithm with 2 correctors, 1 non-orthogonal corrector, momentum predictor disabled, and pressure reference point at (0,0,0) with reference value of 0.
